<h3><b style=""letter-spacing: 0px

""It's imperative that we equip our students with the skills necessary to compete in the 21st century, and Side x Side recognizes that critical thinking, creativity, and collaboration are at the top of the list."" U.S. Senator Angus King
column2:
>
“The arts, creativity and critical thinking are all integral components of education. I'm excited for our students and teachers to implement Side x Side's programming in our schools.”

>
""Creative learning promotes higher level thinking. Working with the Side x Side team taught me innovative techniques that I can incorporate into my teaching. Practicing deeper content exploration helps students learn about themselves, their hearts as well as their minds. Side x Side helps us come alive!""

>
""I have been so impressed by the Side x Side project at Reiche School. The hands-on nature of the Moving Oceans unit, working with professionals in their fields, made the learning relevant, exciting and inspiring to my daughter. This experience has inspired her to want to be a marine biologist when she grows up!""

column1: <div class=""campaignStoryVideoWrapper""><iframe class=""embedly-embed"" height=""326"" src=""https://cdn.embedly.com/widgets/media.html?src=https%3A%2F%2Fplayer.vimeo.com%2Fvideo%2F139712233&amp
","It started with the desire to make a difference in a community and in the lives of all students - one child at a time.
Who we are and what we're doing:

Side x Side is a non-profit organization that is Awakening Tomorrow's Innovators - one child at a time. We believe that the best education has creativity at its heart. This belief led to a 2013 partnership with the University of Southern Maine and the development of Side x Side Inc. in 2014.

Side x Side makes education come alive through community partnerships that bring arts into the classroom and engage all students. We work with classroom teachers, local artists and professionals, and college interns to reinforce core academic concepts through creative programming.
Research shows that arts-enriched programs:
Have greater impact on academic performance
Reach students with different learning styles
Engage struggling students and enable advanced students to flourish
Create a feeling of connection and cooperation among students
Help make schools exciting places to learn

See measured results of the 49 Turnaround Arts schools led by the President's Committee on the Arts and Humanities together with the US Department of Education, the National Endowment for the Arts and local partners. Turnaround Arts brings arts integration to a group of the lowest-performing elementary and middle schools in the country.
This year, we have become bigger than we could have imagined!
In 2014 we launched Side x Side programming in one elementary school impacting just over 300 students. This year with the continued support of the US Department of Education and other funding:
We are impacting
1,700 students in four local elementary schools. This academic year students will create...
colorful prints
240 beautiful books
250 papier-mâché sculptures
120 painted maps
2 large-scale permanent murals
6 physical theater performances
short films
10 kinetic sculptures
all
designed to reinforce learning in reading, writing, math, science and
social studies.

We are providing practical learning experiences for 15 college interns. Art and General Education students from the University of Southern Maine are interning with Side x Side classroom teachers and teaching artists. These students will become our future teachers!
We’ve established working partnerships
with...
University of Southern Maine
Portland Public Schools
Portland Museum
of Art
Portland Public Library
Maine Historical Society
Portland Ovations
Portland ConnectED
South Portland School Department.
We continuously seek
ways to build bridges between the arts and education communities.
Why we need your help:
We’ve raised 95% of our
programming and operating costs through grant writing and other fundraising
efforts. Our US Department of
Education grant supports current elementary programming, most of our teacher trainings and some operating costs.

But that last 5% is crucial for us to continue our work. Expansion of our programs and overhead costs are not covered by any of the grants we’ve secured despite how necessary they are. That's why we're turning to you. Donations will allow us to keep the lights on and continue our work so we can expand our reach to even more schools, teachers, students and communities.
lf we meet our goals, we will be able to:
•pilot a middle school arts-based program•continue to build our STEAM-focused high school program - Artronics•secure occupancy and overhead needs critical to Side x Side’s stability and growth.
How you can help:
A donation to this campaign will help us...
...so that our programming will reach even more students!

If you can’t donate today, you can still help!  Please share this campaign with your friends and family, colleagues, and acquaintances. Let them know about us and that you support our mission.http://igg.me/at/sidexside
Your generosity will guarantee Side x Side's future success and to thank you for your support we want to give you something in return. We’ve gathered some amazing donation perks:
• One-of-a-kind, artistically drawn, window Thank You! Side x Side artists will create and draw a ""visual thank you"" on the Side x Side windows on Congress Street in Portland.

• Unique Notecards featuring 3rd grade student drawings of Portland landmarks (beautiful renditions of Henry Wordsworth Longfellow - like you've never seen him before, First Parish Church, Portland Observatory, Longfellow House and Glooskap, the legendary Wabanaki warrior).
• Whimsical magnets drawn by local artist Sarah Boyden Herboldsheimer.
• ""Owl Girl""- Chapter Book by local author Mary Atkinson, for ages 6-10, plus matching t-shirt (www.maryatkinson.net) - value $30
• Artistic Calendar featuring the work of Side x Side artist Anne Ackerman.
• Stoneware Mugs with celadon glaze (gray) hand thrown by John Clark of The Clark Pottery (www.theclarkpottery.com).
• FABULOUS Framed Print of a Maine animal drawn by our very own Side x Side 1st
grade students (choose from an adorable fox, bear, lobster, owl or puffin).
• Original Drawings in ink and graphite  by Cecil Cates. Choose from Tool Bot, Pen Bot, Brush Bot, and Pencil Bot.  (cecilcates@squarespace.com) - value $150.

•  Designer  Pillows by Heidi Gerquest and Cynthia Selinger. Silk screened on linen with velvet piping with a  90% feather and 10% down insert.(www.fragmentstudios.com) - each retails at $178 Choose the “Cecely” pillow in gray or the “Beatrice” pillow in blue.

•  ""Silver Bank""- Original Pastel by Jamie Hogan, matted and framed (measuring 29.5"" x 15"") from ""Here Come the Humpbacks!"" by April Sayre, a non-fiction picture book about the migration of a mother humpback and her calf. (www.jamiehogan.com) - value $500
•  Weekend (2-nights) at a custom built Vacation House in the Maine countryside on 36 secluded acres just
15 minutes from Sunday River. It is a quiet year round
retreat with a fireplace, art books, videos, board games, DVD’s and a great music library (even records), no TV! Ping pong, foosball and air hockey in the basement.
The house borders the White Mountain National Forest and
is fully equipped. It sleeps six with 3 bedrooms. - value $550
•  ""Midcoast Cove"" - Acrylic Painting on paper with oil pastel details by Alison
Goodwin (23"" x 23"") and a week-long vacation in a custom built house in the Maine woods - combined value $5,000

If you can’t donate today, you can still help!  Please share this campaign with your friends and family, colleagues, and acquaintances. Let them know about us and that you support our mission. http://igg.me/at/sidexside

Background:
Hello, my name is Isaac and me and my coauthor are writing what we believe to be the first fictional illustrated children's book featuring the struggles of a little girl named Mercy who has autism.

The book is called Baby Mercy. I myself was diagnosed with high functioning autism and I did not know about it til years later and when I went to research the topic I found that most of the books dealing with autism were more of aimed towards adults with autism or psychology students. It seems that a lot of parents and teachers cannot talk about autism in children without scaring the kids. So I decided with my best friend to write a little book to help children of all ages learn about and how to cope with autism in an entertaining and innocent way with a timeless story to be shared with schools, families, religious organizations, and people with autism.
<div><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column3:
>I need at least $5,000 to publish and illustrate the book through Author House. The perks I will be giving out to donors will range from thank you notes to illustrations and even unreleased signed copies of the book. I plan on at least 5% of royalties and proceeds from the book sales will go to charities and schools that help provide autistic individuals with the skills they need to succeed. I believe that if this book is a success, I should give back.

The Impact

I believe this will a good step forward in helping autistic children make themselves know as not someone who disabled, but rather an effective member of a community that he or she may live in. Also this book should help with children's literacy.

column1: If you cannot give, don't feel bad you can always share this campaign with your friends and family and don't forget to research autism at your local library check forums online for more information.

I live in south-west France, which means I’m in a unique position to study my field of research: patronage of the d'Amboise family in 15th-century Languedoc.

 

The art produced and commissioned here during the 15th century is fascinating as well as beautiful, but art historians have overlooked it in favour of art made for the royal or ducal courts. It’s time to shine a light on this part of south-west France! 

 

I’m going to look at the works commissioned by the d’Amboise family, particularly Louis I, bishop of Albi at the end of the 15th century, as part of my investigation into how the motivations and artistic tastes of Albigensian prelates shaped visual culture in Languedoc. 

 

Louis I d’Amboise commissioned various extant buildings, art works and programmes by artists both local and international for Ste-Cécile cathedral in Albi and the Palais de la Berbie (now the Toulouse-Lautrec museum) and for the episcopal summer palace at nearby Combefa. 

 

These works should tell us much about the wealth of the Albi bishopric and the artistic vision of its bishops. I plan to identify whether any inventories were made for the episcopal seat in Albi. If so, what would they reveal about its bishops’ motivations? This research is long overdue, all the more so because UNESCO made Albi a World Heritage site in 2010.

 

The cost of pursuing my dream

 

Postgraduate funding is notoriously competitive, particularly in the humanities, and despite a strong PhD proposal and an unconditional offer, I was unsuccessful in my applications for funding.

 

I will continue to work as a social media manager for my existing clients and together with support from my artist husband, I can cover half my tuition fees, but without external financial help to make up the difference I simply won’t be able to pursue this degree. 

 

My earnings as a social media manager and financial help from my husband will pay for half my fees for 2016/2017: £4121. I will have to fly to St Andrews to matriculate and meet my fellow postgraduate students and staff. I’ve also built in the cost of visiting St Andrews once per term to update the School of Art History with my progress and to take advantage of the incredible research environment at St Andrews. 

 

Despite being lucky enough to live in the middle of my research location, I’ll need to visit the buildings and art works I plan to study - Albi is a 3 hour journey - plus departmental archives and the Bibliothèque Nationale de France in Paris.

 

The cost of visiting these places on a shoestring budget, plus buying books and paying for the Perks I’m offering, comes to £3070. I also have to add the fees from Indiegogo and Paypal, bringing the total to £5643. That’s my fundraising goal. 

  

 

The story so far

 

I’ve already started an online course in paleography, which will help me to understand what I’m looking at when I study medieval manuscripts and documents in our departmental archives. I’m learning basic transcribing skills and will be dusting off my old Latin dictionary to help me with translation. 

 

I’ve also started to teach myself Occitan, the language of medieval Languedoc. “Adieussiatz!”* I’ve visited Albi and Monestiés on a research recce to take reference photos of the principle art works and sites. They are incredible works of art and I can’t wait to share more with you once I officially start my research!

* Hello!

 

About me and my support team

 

I haven’t arrived at this point from nowhere. My love of art history started as a 16 year old following a trip to the Musée d’Orsay in Paris. It led to me studying art history as an undergraduate at St Andrews in the 1990s, where I gained a First Class Honours degree. I followed this with an MA in art history at the Courtauld Institute in London. 

 

I desperately wanted to channel my passion for art history into a career in museums and art galleries, but I had bills to pay so I went down a different career path, journalism. Not a bad alternative, as I met my husband at work, and it gave me the chance to earn a living from researching and writing - my other two favourite things!   

 

Fast-forward ten years, and I moved with my husband and baby to France to be nearer my family, and to re-train as a social media marketing manager.

 

On our honeymoon to Florence, with my baby daughter in tow and surrounded by beautiful Renaissance buildings, paintings and sculptures, I asked myself whether it was too late for me to go back to study. It seemed impossible. Was my brain still up to it? Would I be able to juggle work, family and study? For many years the answer was no. 

 

But I couldn’t ignore art history for ever. In 2014 I signed up for an Open University course called Renaissance Reconsidered, and the moment I started reading the course books I felt like I’d come home. 

 

I relished it all, particularly the final dissertation, to be based on a local art work. I chose the Nostre Dame de Grasse, a 15th-century sculpture of unknown origin now in the Musée des Augustins in Toulouse. Investigating this work reignited the research bug, and I knew I couldn’t stop studying when the course finished. I received a Distinction for the course and 92% for the dissertation, which made me realise yes, my brain was up to it, and I could juggle work, family and study.

 

With the support of family, friends and, crucially, Dr John Richards, one of my original tutors at St Andrews with whom I’ve stayed in touch (now senior lecturer in art history at the University of Glasgow) I decided to pursue a lifelong ambition: to study for a PhD. I found the perfect supervisor,
column3:
user_id=kmr7"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">Dr Kathryn M. Rudy, senior lecturer in art history at the University of St Andrews. She loved my proposal, saw why this research needed to be done, and why I was the ideal candidate to do it. We met when she came to France to do some archival work in Agen. She encouraged me to dig deep to maximise my potential. I now appreciate, before I’ve even officially started this research, that anything is possible if you try hard enough.

 

I had great fun with my support team creating some inventive Perks - like sourcing your name in medieval Occitan and devising a bespoke art history travel itinerary - so please have a look to see what tickles your fancy.

 

It’s incredibly difficult for me to ask for this help, but your support would mean the world to me. Even if you can’t make a financial contribution, building buzz around my campaign by sharing with your friends and contacts by email and on social media will make a huge difference. The nice people at Indiegogo provide share tools to make this easier for you. 

 

Thank you so much for reading.

Julia

In 2014 I signed up for an Open University course called Renaissance Reconsidered, and the moment I started reading the course books I felt like I’d come home.  I relished it all, particularly the final dissertation, to be based on a local art work. I chose the Nostre Dame de Grasse, a 15th-century sculpture of unknown origin now in the Musée des Augustins in Toulouse. Investigating this work reignited the research bug, and I knew I couldn’t stop studying when the course finished. I received a Distinction for the course and 92% for the dissertation, which made me realise yes, my brain was up to it, and I could juggle work, family and study. With the support of family, friends and, crucially, Dr John Richards, one of my original tutors at St Andrews with whom I’ve stayed in touch (now senior lecturer in art history at the University of Glasgow) I decided to pursue a lifelong ambition: to study for a PhD. I found the perfect supervisor, Dr Kathryn M. Rudy, senior lecturer in art history at the University of St Andrews. She loved my proposal, saw why this research needed to be done, and why I was the ideal candidate to do it. We met when she came to France to do some archival work in Agen. She encouraged me to dig deep to maximise my potential. I now appreciate, before I’ve even officially started this research, that anything is possible if you try hard enough. I had great fun with my support team creating some inventive Perks - like sourcing your name in medieval Occitan and devising a bespoke art history travel itinerary - so please have a look to see what tickles your fancy. It’s incredibly difficult for me to ask for this help, but your support would mean the world to me. Even if you can’t make a financial contribution, building buzz around my campaign by sharing with your friends and contacts by email and on social media will make a huge difference. The nice people at Indiegogo provide share tools to make this easier for you.  Thank you so much for reading.Julia",0.0,0,"1 Campaign

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
Introduction

My name is Terry Nichols and I am the wife of a veteran that served in a war zone. When he returned home from his service myself, our family and our community had little understanding of his experience in the military and as a contemporary veteran. As a result of this lack of awareness, it is difficult to support and understand our veterans.

In 2014 we founded the Communities For Veterans Foundation and in 2015 we conducted a 211 day national  awareness campaign on horseback from Victoria, BC to St.John's Newfoundland. My husband, Paul, rode over 7,000 kms in order to bring awareness and support to our contemporary veterans. We connected with thousands of veterans and tens of thousands of civilians.

I grew up with little connection to military culture and in a family where nobody that I knew had served. It was this disconnect that lead to struggles in our family when my husband returned from serving in a war zone. Education is the key!

I had the opportunity to tell ""My Sheep Story"" hundred of times as we travelled across the country to bring veterans and communities closer together. I witness the positive impact that this story had every time I told it. Some examples of the feedback that I have heard
<ul>
• I have been told by veterans that this story has changed their lives.
• I have been thanked by many for simply describing PTSD.
• I have helped community recognize their role in the wellness of our veterans.
• I have created an awareness of the important role of our military
• I have found a way to bring this awareness in a simple story suitable for all ages
I want to have ""My Sheep Story"" available as soon as possible. We are ready to go to print!
Our veterans have a desire to serve. Knowing how to support them in community will lead to stronger veterans, families, and communities.
The cost to get my book printed is $10,000. This will cover printing, illustrating and design
<ul>
• This campaign will give you the opportunity to prepurchase ""My Sheep Story"" for delivery before Christmas.
• Hand signed copy of ""MY Sheep Story""
• Opportunity to support veterans with post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and operational stress injuries (OSI)
• Help veterans come to Community For Veterans Foundation veteran transition programs
• If we do not reach our goal we will still make this happen. We are resourceful. We will find a way!
The Impact

Your contribution to this campaign will help make ""My Sheep Story"" available as soon as possible. This will bring awareness to our contemporary veterans and their families. This new awareness will lead to stronger veterans, families, and communities.
<ul>

• In order for our veterans to receive the support and understanding that they need, there needs to be a shift in the thinking and understanding in our civilian culture. It is community that is needed when our veterans leave the military.
• My goals after printing ""My Sheep Story"" include taking my story to communities to further educate. The message in this book needs to be heard. It will make a difference.

• In order to get ""My Sheep Story"" printed as soon as possible I have published it myself, am having it printed locally, designed locally, and illustrated locally. I am excited and proud to have my book available.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute to this campaign, there are other ways that you can help.
<ul>
• Spread the word of this campaign and share my information
• Give some thought to the role that our veterans have had in our freedoms and peaceful life, and find ways to acknowledge and support
We will make a difference!

Short Summary

After my first effort in 2014, to present to you in a book the traditional costumes of North Evia and the folk culture linked with it, - which was published thanks to your support! (find it in the link here)-I come back to ask you again to support the publishing of my second book on Greek Euboean Folk Civilization, dedicated on our local Euboean idiomatic Greek language.

This local language of the northern part of Evia Island is important, as it is an idiom consisting mostly of preserved ancient Greek words that were slightly amended through the years. This happened because of the area’s isolation, as until the mid 20th century the only access to northern Evia Island was by small boats, and the communication and cultural exchange with other people was little.

I first realized that my fellow citizens and I had a different manner of speaking when I was studying at the university. It was then that I discovered many of the words I used while speaking were unknown to my classmates. For me, this language seemed natural since I had grown up hearing these words from my grand-parents in my mother’s village and from my parents at home. I started collecting words and idiomatic phrases 13 years ago, and I now have  a collection of more than 3000, along with their history and the stories behind them! Each word or phrase is unique, and constitutes a nostalgic part of our Greek roots and a piece of our local history!

In the book, we chose to combine the words along with the stories in the idiomatic language, told by our grand-parents to the recorders of the early 20th century, that first tried to capture the idiom, when people talked in this way more vibrantly. I also wrote by myself in the local idiom, and include them in the book, seven theatrical act plays which can inspire Greek Teachers and be dramatized by Greek Schools or Greek Folk Dancers, to induce children to get in touch with the idiomatic language and take a look at the way of living of our ancestors, while the older ones will be reminded of nostalgic memories from the past. The book is also documented by its bibliography, consisting of about 200 references from old books and personal testimonies.

The writer, Asimina Nteliou, comes from the island of Evia in Greece, where she lives. Passionate of the Greek tradition, she is researching the authentic aspects of Greek folk civilization, photographing and recording all the wisdom and morals of the Greek islanders, before the old ones die and the knowledge is lost. Her first published book, “The Traditional Greek Costumes of North Evia” which preserved the knowledge related to the folk costumes and jewels of Evia, and links it with the customs and the ancient and byzantine origin of Greek people, was honored with the Kaftantzogleio Award 2014 by the Faculty of Philosophy of the National Kapodistrian University of Athens. She is married to Theofanis Ramiotis, a goldsmith and jewel conservator, who reproduces exact copies of the Greek traditional jewels by old techniques and designs contemporary jewels inspired from the Greek traditional culture. They both share the vision to preserve the Greek folk civilization and promote it by a series of books and expositions all over the world, highlighting it as world heritage.
<h3>What We Need &amp
My homeland, Evia, is not as famous as other Greek Islands
column2: however, it has a less known and amazing civilization. Researchers have found that the roots of the Latin alphabet, spread all over the world, are based on the ancient Chalkidean alphabet, through the Chalkis’ colonies which are located in Italy (Chalkis is the capital of Evia).

column1: Our local idiomatic Euboean Greek language, which is the evolution of the ancient one, is important and should be recorded, preserved, and not allowed to disappear. As the years pass and we Greeks mix with people from other countries, we tend to adopt mostly the foreign words rather than preserve our local ones.  In a world that we all tend to act and be the same, speaking our local idiom, makes us a bit somehow different. In this way we become a part of our homeland’s history, a fruit from our ancestors’ tree and a seed for our own children.

This book aims to be a small stone to saving and preserving the wall of the Greek North Euboean idiom and keep it safe to be transmitted to our children. In this way we can offer to our children a rare linguistic material, and introduce them to our roots and our continuity as a nation. That is why I encourage you to fund this book so it will be published and reach as many people as possible.

In order to publish this book, some essential publishing work must be done. The cost of the book's design, printing and distribution is 650 Euros or 700 USD. Furthermore, the circulation of the printed book requires printing at least a small batch of premium quality books. This is planned to cost 250 Euros or 270 USD. If the campaign is successful, it will be available in e-book format, which is estimated to cost around 350 Euros or 380 USD.

Every person that helps us gets something. Whether a thank you note on an old fashioned post card depicting Euboea, a contemporary Evia or Greece design pendant, or a valuable piece of jewelry, which will be an exact copy of the traditional art of Greece.
The Impact

Publishing this book in both printed and ebook formats is a significant way to save, learn, protect, study and continue the traditional Greek folk language and deliver it to new generations of people, which is not only a matter of a small social group, but of world heritage.

Moreover, the writer will be able through the book's presentations to sensitize people all over Greece and world, on the preservation of the Greek idioms. The same happened with her first book ""The Traditional Greek Costumes of North Evia"". The last two years people all over Greece and world learned more about the stunning Greek Folk Art and were introduced to unknown traditional Greek costumes. The presentations and their videos on Youtube and Facebook were also a great advertisement for Greek Folk Culture and Art and Evia Island. You can see the writer's presentations the last two years  in this link
<h3>Risks &amp

There is no actual risk. If anyone helps us, he/she will receive the perk of his/her choice and our gratitude. The book is planned to be published in March/April 2017 even if this campaign is unsuccessful. Any financial help, or even just sharing our campaign with your friends, is greatly appreciated and makes you a special person interested in saving our Greek heritage.
Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot fund our campaign, there are also some other way to help us. Please share our campaign with your friends and family or anyone that you think could help our goal by e-mailing them and informing them for it.
You can also show that you care by sharing this video with your friends on  Facebook, Twitter, and Google Plus.
The most people this campaign reaches the most they will be encouraged to take action!

Remember that recording and saving the Greek dialects is a burden (or responsibility) for all of us … it is our duty towards our children in times that our Greek words tend to get replaced by foreign ones. Don't hesitate to take action!

We've curated our community's beautiful illustrations in an engaging format to encourage curiosity about plants and healing, while highlighting the value and beauty of the natural world.

Coloring is a unique activity that's both educational and meditative, not to mention entertaining, for all ages! 

All proceeds support our sliding-scale herbal clinics, so you can help build community health while you relax and learn. 

The Story of our Book:

Julie Mitchell, adjunct faculty at Vermont Center for Integrative Herbalism (VCIH), initiated this project after watching our first-year botany students drawing plants to learn about their botanical characteristics. Having seen a coloring book of medicinal herbs of the Northwestern United States, she proposed the idea of compiling our own drawings, concentrating on plants of the Northeast. When asked if they would be interested in pursuing this project of sharing “beauty and medicine”, students and staff were enthusiastically supportive and so our coloring book was born.

To extend the impact and value of the project, we've added useful information about each plant, including botanical and common names, family, parts used, habitat and growth habits, at-risk status, medicinal actions, and energetic qualities. Also included in the book is a glossary of herbal terms and lists of resources for further exploration of herbal medicine, botany, plant conservation, and botanical illustration.

Learn the medicinal and botanical characteristics of 25 herbs with our community-sourced coloring book.

For this first volume, we chose to focus on the plants commonly found growing wild in the Northeast, whether native or introduced. Even if you live in other regions of the country, many of the plants we’ve included will be familiar or even found in your ecosystems, too.

We’ve divided the book into sections according to where the plants live: woodlands, fields and meadows, and wet places. Some are at-risk species that we don’t recommend harvesting for medicine, but which have an important history of use for healing, nonetheless.

The plants you’ll find in the coloring book include:

Woodlands:  black cohosh, bloodroot, goldenseal, partridge berry, sassafras, solomon’s seal, trillium, violet, wintergreen

Fields and Meadows: boneset, echinacea, elecampane, goldenrod, lobelia, plantain, poke, self heal, St. John’s wort, yarrow

Wet Places: calamus, elder, figwort, skullcap, sundew

Coloring is now being promoted as an active meditation tool, beneficial for relieving stress, whether done alone or in groups. We're already imagining this book keeping us company as we snuggle in to unwind on Winter afternoons with a cup of tea. Or maybe it's time for a wine-and-coloring evening with friends? Whatever your pleasure, just leafing through the pages to admire the skill of the artists and the beauty of the plants is already making us more relaxed!

We also hope this book will be used as a learning tool in indoor and outdoor classrooms, at kid’s camps and herb schools, and at kitchen tables by curious folks of all ages. Ultimately, we’re hoping to make learning about medicinal plants easy, inspiring, and fun.

All proceeds from this project help fund our sliding-scale herbal clinics and apothecary.

Your purchase will not only encourage personal relaxation, learning, and connection to nature, it will also help build community health through support of our mission-driven work.

Our clinics offer direct service through individualized education in self-care with herbs. We offer consultations in our professional clinic in Montpelier and in our supervised student clinics in both Montpelier and Burlington, Vermont. Our clinical services and herbs are available through sliding-scale payment, time exchange and gift
column2:
no one is turned away for lack of funds.

That’s where this project comes in: every little bit of support helps us provide more herbs and consultation time, while keeping the lights on and the apothecary stocked.

You can read more about our clinics and commitment to accessibility of care here.

More about VCIH:

Vermont Center for Integrative Herbalism (VCIH) is an educational grassroots non-profit, founded in 2007 by a group of experienced herbalists and activists, working through collaborative leadership to change what healthcare looks like.

Please visit our website for more information about community classes, intensive training programs, and our clinical services, as well as our dedicated team. For an overview of what we do at VCIH, keep reading below.

Our Mission:

We believe that herbal medicine has a vital role to play in the emerging integrative healthcare system. We're excited to be a part of this work. We know that, with our community's support, we can continue to seed the growth of a system that is grounded in nature, empowers individuals, and connects communities. Any contribution you make will support the work we do to provide direct care in our community and to educate skilled herbalists who work on the front-lines in kitchens and clinics nationwide.

Here’s what we’re up to:

Re-skilling our community, one person at a time. We inspire individuals to take care of themselves and their families and provide them with the knowledge and skills to do it. Individuals then become valuable resources in their local communities, too.

We do this by offering:

column1: • an annual intensive gardening, medicine-making and self-care apprenticeship
• an ongoing schedule of community workshops and special events
• learning gardens and a teaching kitchen
• sliding-scale community herbal clinics, offering individuals education in self-care with herbs, diet and lifestyle recommendations

Seeding the culture with change-makers. We train clinical herbalists who take their knowledge and experience to communities across the country. These herbalists replicate and expand the educational work we do in exponentially widening circles.

We achieve this through:
• a three-year clinical herbalist training program
• sliding-scale community herbal clinics in multiple locations, the primary training venue for clinical interns
• a lab and fully-stocked apothecary for intern use

Please visit our website for more details or if you have questions about our work. We'd love to hear from you.

Thanks so much for reading this far! We hope you’re inspired to buy a coloring book (or 10!) and share the beauty and wonder of medicinal plants with your family and friends.

an ongoing schedule of community workshops and special events
learning gardens and a teaching kitchen
sliding-scale community herbal clinics, offering individuals education in self-care with herbs, diet and lifestyle recommendations

Seeding the culture with change-makers. We train clinical herbalists who take their knowledge and experience to communities across the country. These herbalists replicate and expand the educational work we do in exponentially widening circles.We achieve this through:
a three-year clinical herbalist training program
sliding-scale community herbal clinics in multiple locations, the primary training venue for clinical interns
a lab and fully-stocked apothecary for intern use

Please visit our website for more details or if you have questions about our work. We'd love to hear from you.Thanks so much for reading this far! We hope you’re inspired to buy a coloring book (or 10!) and share the beauty and wonder of medicinal plants with your family and friends.",2.0,0,"4 Campaigns

The Story that Inspired Us...

 

Hi, my name is Johnson and I was born in West Africa. I moved to the United States when I was 19 to go to college. Living abroad and seeing the opportunities provided to US students showed me the vast potential for education development and expansion in my country for African youth. I started Collegestreet from my dorm room. As a young boy in Africa, I was troubled to see how kids in my village walked 10-12 miles every day to school with excitement to earn their high school diploma. Unfortunately, 90% of them will never be able to afford the opportunity to go to college.  I said to myself, ""when I grow up, I am going to find a way to help parents send their children to college!""
 

How can your contribution help pay for a university degree? 

We select education programs that offer the highest return, and recruit the most talented students. Our approach is simple:
• $50 covers one university subject for a student in Kenya
•  when the student graduates, they will repay 15% of their future salaries for 5 years or less after graduation
• This 15 percent will fund a full university degree for the next students. Over time, the money will continue to multiply to support hundreds of students along the way
• Our goal is to support 20 students this coming fall semester
• The 15 percent return from our graduate students will support over 270 new students in 7 years time

Where Are We Now?

We have introduced our program in multiple universities in Kenya and Uganda. We are now piloting our solution at Moi University in Kenya. Moi University is a public university located in the town of Eldoret in Western Kenya. They have over 47,000 undergraduate students and operate eight campuses. We are also on our final step of finalizing partnerships with 10 other universities in Kenya, 8 universities in Uganda, and 5 universities in Nigeria.

The Impact of Your Contribution

Our goal is to rigorously test every single component of our business model to ensure its viability and impact. We project the full cost of our pilot to be between $15k-$20k but our needs are staged, and thus, so is our fundraising target. Even if we don't reach our goal, we will still contribute all the money to support education. 

Until then, we need funding to cover necessary piloting expenses like:
• If we reach our goal, the money from this crowdfunding campaign will support 20 students on our educational investment program this year.
• Roundtrip air travel to Kenya and Uganda for school tours and administration meetings
• Team growth to allow us to expand to other universities in our target countries with ease

You'll get some awesome perks for donating but most importantly, you'll be helping us extend our program to more universities and more students.
 

Why Are We Doing This?

We hope with our program, a girl selling tamales can become a business owner, a street kid can become a doctor, a farm girl can become a biologist and they can all permanently break the cycle of poverty. On average, the impact is a three-fold increase in income. 

More About CollegeStreet

Collegestreet was founded in September 2015 on a college campus by students who faced issues paying for tuition and fees
column2:
Johnson as an international student and Zachery as a first-generation domestic student. The rest of the team experienced similar financial challenges first-hand as well. Thus, we are all passionate about solving issues of educational accessibility around the world. 

As a social impact startup, we are continually learning, growing, and adapting. Over the next year, we will be raising capital to expand our program and scale our model. We believe that once we have established our model using the funds from this campaign, we will attract more investors who are interested in investing in companies with scalable social impact and high growth potential.

FAQS

Is 15% too much?
We plan on providing career development, mentorship, and  reinvesting the 15% to support another new students along the way.

What if a student defaults on their repayments? We believe that building relationships is one of the best ways to prevent students from defaulting on repayments. If a default should occur, we extend the payments and work very closely with the student to find the best solution for them to make their payments.

Do you support all degree programs on your program?  We have researched the earning potential of various degrees in Africa. We are focusing on students with high earning potential - primarily STEM and some non science fields. Over time, we hope to expand our list of supported degrees.

What if a student doesn't find a job? Students are not required to repay until they find a job with a salary above a minimum payment. We provide career support to students, and we are building a network of employers in Kenya. This allows the students to connect with careers as soon as they graduate.

Our Team

We are all young, vibrant, and passionate about solving issues facing the developing world.

 


IMPORTANT: If you'd like any of these perks that we have, you must click ""Get This Perk"" when you scroll over them on the right side. If you'd just like to donate and do not want a perk, then click ""Back It"" at the top. Our perks are : a beautiful Collegestreet water bottle, a classic phone wallet(red or blue), and a fancy ""Educate African Youth"" wristbands.

column1:
Talk to us!

If you have any other questions, feel free to get in touch by email: Info@collegestreetusa.com
To learn more about our organization, please visit our website: http://www.collegestreetusa.com

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/CollegeStreetUSA/
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/collegestreetus/
Twitter: https://www.twitter.com/collegestreetUSA/

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone is in a position to contribute financially. If you support our mission, you can still help by sharing this campaign with your friends and family
column2:
it can really make a difference! Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Like us on Facebook, Instagram, tweet about us, forward our campaign on to all of your friends and invite your friends to our site.

 

Thanks for your help in making higher education accessible to deserving students!

""When girls are walking hours every week...those are hours they can't spend in school."" - John Green
Our Mission

Countless girls around the world start their day with one massive challenge: they live too far from their school. Six graders spending up to hours walking every morning, arriving with the breath of exhausted and stomach of hunger. With the road to education literally too far, many bight young minds have no other path except child marriage.
column5:
>We, a group of high school students, want to put an end to this with bicycles. 

The Story of Aanya

column1: Let's travel to the life of a girl named Aanya. She's living in the village of Debidwar, Bangladesh with her brother and single mother. Although her mother was only a maid,  it did not stop Aanya from dreaming to become a doctor. For too long, she saw the dying in her village with no one to treat them. Hence everyday, motivated and empowered by her dream, she came to school to do her best.

But to continue on to secondary education, she must journey to another school in another town. Her village school can only teach her so much. She can walk, but the road is too far. What little money her family has can barely keep food on the table, let alone to pay for daily bus rides.

No longer able to continue her education, the only path left for Aanya is for her mother to arrange an older man to marry. And so, a wedding is called. In the midst of the newly wed, Aanya's dream of becoming a doctor is destroyed. At the age of 16, she is now the belonging to someone else. No longer is Aanya controlling her own path, chasing her own dream.
column2: >BUT IT DOESN'T HAVE TO BE THIS WAY

column1: <h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
column5:
>With just a BICYCLE, Aanya can get to the school next town well under an hour. Her studies continue, her books stay open. Aanya is at the chase again. Her dream is now within her reach. That's the power of a bicycle. 

Inspiration for BIKES of HOPE

column1: In order to empower young ambitious youth like Aanya,  our group of high school students from New York, California, and Florida came together to found LyfeCycle. We started fundraising the classical way, baking cookies in our schools, putting lemonade stands in NYC. Through careful coordination with Cardiff International School in Bangladesh, we were able to establish an avenue to provide bicycles to underprivileged youths with our funds. We launched our first campaign last year with sounding success. Although that first project ended, our real work is only starting.

With our first distribution a success, we were also able to attract numerous press recognition throughout the country and attention around the local community. LyfeCycle has transformed beyond just a project by high school students and into a movement!
<span style=""font-size: 16px

column8: Ellis. Today, LyfeCycle is a fully incorporated 501(3)(c) non-profit organization with all donations

<h1><span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column11: >It doesn’t take much to make a difference. For only $75, you can support one student for years to come and help provide hope to a family, to a community, to a nation's future. By giving this one bicycle, you are opening the doors to education and accessibility to keep students in school.

column1: <div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)

With your support, we hope to send 20 bicycles to the village of Bakshar in Bangladesh. The cost of $75 will cover the purchase of one bicycle locally from the closest city and the transportation cost to the village.
We will be posting updates for you to see and hear the stories of the children selected here on Indiegogo. You can learn of their hopes and dreams, happiness and struggles.
Our Team

","""When girls are walking hours every week...those are hours they can't spend in school."" - John Green
Our Mission

Countless girls around the world start their day with one massive challenge: they live too far from their school. Six graders spending up to hours walking every morning, arriving with the breath of exhausted and stomach of hunger. With the road to education literally too far, many bight young minds have no other path except child marriage. We, a group of high school students, want to put an end to this with bicycles.    The Story of Aanya

Let's travel to the life of a girl named Aanya. She's living in the village of Debidwar, Bangladesh with her brother and single mother. Although her mother was only a maid,  it did not stop Aanya from dreaming to become a doctor. For too long, she saw the dying in her village with no one to treat them. Hence everyday, motivated and empowered by her dream, she came to school to do her best.

But to continue on to secondary education, she must journey to another school in another town. Her village school can only teach her so much. She can walk, but the road is too far. What little money her family has can barely keep food on the table, let alone to pay for daily bus rides.

No longer able to continue her education, the only path left for Aanya is for her mother to arrange an older man to marry. And so, a wedding is called. In the midst of the newly wed, Aanya's dream of becoming a doctor is destroyed. At the age of 16, she is now the belonging to someone else. No longer is Aanya controlling her own path, chasing her own dream. BUT IT DOESN'T HAVE TO BE THIS WAY

With just a BICYCLE, Aanya can get to the school next town well under an hour. Her studies continue, her books stay open. Aanya is at the chase again. Her dream is now within her reach. That's the power of a bicycle.    Inspiration for BIKES of HOPE

In order to empower young ambitious youth like Aanya,  our group of high school students from New York, California, and Florida came together to found LyfeCycle. We started fundraising the classical way, baking cookies in our schools, putting lemonade stands in NYC. Through careful coordination with Cardiff International School in Bangladesh, we were able to establish an avenue to provide bicycles to underprivileged youths with our funds. We launched our first campaign last year with sounding success. Although that first project ended, our real work is only starting.

With our first distribution a success, we were also able to attract numerous press recognition throughout the country and attention around the local community. LyfeCycle has transformed beyond just a project by high school students and into a movement!

In order to establish a more solid foundation, we move to obtain legalization with the help of one of the top law firms in the world: Kirkland & Ellis. Today, LyfeCycle is a fully incorporated 501(3)(c) non-profit organization with all donations tax-deductible.

It doesn’t take much to make a difference. For only $75, you can support one student for years to come and help provide hope to a family, to a community, to a nation's future. By giving this one bicycle, you are opening the doors to education and accessibility to keep students in school.

With your support, we hope to send 20 bicycles to the village of Bakshar in Bangladesh. The cost of $75 will cover the purchase of one bicycle locally from the closest city and the transportation cost to the village.
We will be posting updates for you to see and hear the stories of the children selected here on Indiegogo. You can learn of their hopes and dreams, happiness and struggles.
Our Team
Thank you so much :D
Other Ways You Can Help
Share this campaign with people you know who care about education and youth empowerment!
We are on Facebook (and Instagram and LinkedIn and all those cool places). Find us there. Follow us. Like us. Invite your friends to do it too.
Check out our website for updates!",11.0,0,"3 Campaigns

What does GenerationYuvaa mean?
‘Yuvaa’ in most of the Indian
languages mean Youth. We are a group of youngsters fighting against Child
begging and uplifting underprivileged children in Vishakhapatnam, a district
located in the state of Andhra Pradesh in the South India.
Why to Eradicate Child Begging and Uplift Children?
Begging prevents children from realizing their full
potential. Unfortunately, these children have a very tough time breaking out of
their helpless situation. Since begging is still considered a shame, beggars
move to places and states where their original family identity cannot be easily
recognized by people from whom they seek alms. Some beggars are professional
beggars in the sense that begging becomes a chosen profession for them. The
earnings they make through begging are carefully saved and sent home to support
the other family member However, the number of people who beg out of indigent
circumstances still appears to be very large in India. The amazing fact is that
many beggars are professional beggars and many of them are involved with
criminals. In many big cities in India beggars are much organized and do their
work with lot of planning.
Types of Child Begging:
column5: >The children directly beg the money from the public while

column1: sometimes the child is used as a medium for doing the same. Each pattern is
briefly explained below.
In Mother Child begging, the child is used as a medium for
begging. Usually the mother is seen carrying the child who is either conscious
or unconscious. Children are made unconscious by giving them some unconscious
causing drugs and then beg from the people for their recovery and taking them
to hospital.
The other side of this story is that often these children
are not their own, they were either purchased from poor families or kidnapped
from different places of India. Many of these children die or lose their mental
balance due to this regular poisoning.
Another pattern that is noticed is where the child is
begging directly by amusing people with the help of an animal like a monkey or
performing certain tricky acts like walking on a rope etc., another common
pattern is where the child paints himself like Gandhi and asking for money.
Being physically handicapped and using this to beg is also
something that is seen very common while begging. Most of the times, it is seen
that the child is pretending to be handicapped and is not actually so.
Sometimes children are forced to lose their limbs so that they can be a medium
for begging throughout their life. These kinds of atrocities are also done by
certain gangs that operate begging about which we will be discussing later in
the report.
Religion is also used as a medium for begging in children
where the child is either in attire that represents certain religion or the
child is seen carrying photos of Gods while begging.
Factors responsible for child begging:
There are varied factors that influence these children to
choose begging as a means of earning money. Some of them are discussed below.
One of the major reasons that are seen is that the family is
from below the poverty line and usually the parents are the one who choose
begging for their children. The money that is earned by the child by begging is
used to support the family financially.
One of the other reasons is that the child is an orphan and
is directed towards begging by the other children or the families that are
already into begging.
It is also seen that begging is operated as an organized
crime by a gang. They buy or rent children to use them for begging and thus the
children get involved in the vicious circle. And often it is impossible for
them to break out of it.
Effects of Child Begging:
The entire child's holistic development is majorly disrupted
in this issue. Some factors are discussed below.
The child's health and mental health is affected negatively.
Different domains of the child's development like behavior, education,
psychological development and various other domains are affected.
There is also a high possibility that the child is exposed
to issue that are not appropriate for his/her age. For example getting into
drugs leading them into drug addicts or early exposure to sex are huge risks
for the child well-being.
Children who are involved in this cycle will automatically
guide their next generation into same situation of begging.
These children are often seen adapting to anti- social
behavior leading them to involve in issues like thefts, crime and other
malpractices.
Statistics of Child Begging in Visakhapatnam:
In Visakhaptanam district, there are approximately 450 to
500 Child Begga₹ The ratio of Girl beggars to the Boy beggars is 1:1 which
means that there are equal number of girls and boys who are into begging.
Certain areas where the Child Beggars are seen that most are railway station, bus complex, beach, road signal junctions, temples etc. These migrated families
don't stay in one place and are seen travelling from one area to another. So
tracing them and keeping a trace of them is often a challenge.
Policies and legislation on Child Begging and its Violation:
Children Care and Protection Act, Sec (a) and Sec (b) of
Juvenile Justice Care &amp
earlier called as Juvenile Act, is the act that exists for these children.
Children below 18 years, both girls and boys come under this act. Earlier the
age limit was 15 years for girls and 18 years for boys but now it has been made
as 18 years for both the genders. The Act states that the children who are
involved in begging are counted as neglected children and the children can be
moved to rehabilitation centers for their positive development. Parents who are
identified as a part of this and if we have an identified testimony will have
to be counseled and explained about the well-being of the child. Our project is
designed as per these guidelines.
What do
we do?
GenerationYuvaa has started a Child Home in temporary
residence to provide a shelter for street children, orphans and street beggars. We
are still in process of raising funds a permanent dream home which we would
name it as Generation Yuvaa Child Home.  The
strength right now is capped to 50 children due to lack of funds. These
children are provided with basic facilities like shelter, clothing and food
along with education. Some of these children who are old enough to go to school
are funded for their education. Along with this, the child overall development
is also focused by indulging them in various physical activities and play.
Certain standards are followed while preparing food keeping the nutrition norms
in mind. Along with this, weekly health checkups are done by medical
professionals.
Interventions by GenerationYuvaa:
Spreading awareness: GenerationYuvaa
focuses on spreading a lot of awareness about child begging to bring the focus
on the issue that it is a major social issue that needs to be worked on. This
is done using various ways like spreading pamphlets, rallies and other
resources.
Orphan Child accommodation
and education: OrphanChild beggars are accommodated in our rented residence.
Child and parental counseling:  At
times when parents are involved in child begging, they are counseled. The
organization follows ethical counseling which means that the child or the
parent is never pressured to be a part of the session and the confidentiality
of the cases are not disclosed without permission. In certain cases, where
the child is interested in education but is not financially capable of going to
school, GenerationYuvaa sponsors the child's education.
Public Awareness:
GenerationYuvaa has adapted different ways to reach to
public. Some of them are
·
Pamphlets
·
Rallies
·
Posters
·
Media (print/
online/ news)
·
Public talks
(schools/ colleges/ talks)
·
Skits
Find us on the Internet, Social Network and Media:
Website:
www.genyuvaa.com
Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/generationyuvaa
YouTube:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuPJ4GSFm3kB2ZGidu6VxVg
Media:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IXb3bkngmnM
What you can Donate?
Time is the most precious thing which cannot be retrieved
once it is passed. So if you can spend few minutes of your valuable time to
read the above and get awareness.
MONEY:
·
Food &

Accommodation costs per Child:
Monthly: ₹ 2000 ($ 30)
Yearly: ₹ 24,000 ($ 360)
·
Education costs:(Includes School fee, Books &

expenses and other miscellaneous charges)
Monthly: ₹ 1200 ($ 20)
Yearly: ₹ 14,400 ($ 240)
*Miscellaneous:Clothes,
Sports kits, toys, Books &amp
kids collection/useful books for kids), Sandals, Shoes &amp
column2: Socks. Special classes:Dance, YOGA, Generation Yuvaa Social

column1: Force (GYSF), Painting, Singing etc.
We are also raising funds for our dream permanent GenerationYuvaa
Child Home:
Low cost model dream GenerationYuvaa permanent Child Home
·
Estimated cost to construct a low cost
model GenerationYuvaa Child Home is ₹ 5,000,000 ($ 75,000)
What we expect from you to donate:
100 Bricks or 2 Cement bags = ₹ 650 ($
250 Bricks or 5 Cement bags = ₹ 1,650 ($

or unconscious. Children are made unconscious by giving them some unconscious
causing drugs and then beg from the people for their recovery and taking them
to hospital.
The other side of this story is that often these children
are not their own, they were either purchased from poor families or kidnapped
from different places of India. Many of these children die or lose their mental
balance due to this regular poisoning.
Another pattern that is noticed is where the child is
begging directly by amusing people with the help of an animal like a monkey or
performing certain tricky acts like walking on a rope etc., another common
pattern is where the child paints himself like Gandhi and asking for money.
Being physically handicapped and using this to beg is also
something that is seen very common while begging. Most of the times, it is seen
that the child is pretending to be handicapped and is not actually so.
Sometimes children are forced to lose their limbs so that they can be a medium
for begging throughout their life. These kinds of atrocities are also done by
certain gangs that operate begging about which we will be discussing later in
the report.
Religion is also used as a medium for begging in children
where the child is either in attire that represents certain religion or the
child is seen carrying photos of Gods while begging.
Factors responsible for child begging:
There are varied factors that influence these children to
choose begging as a means of earning money. Some of them are discussed below.
One of the major reasons that are seen is that the family is
from below the poverty line and usually the parents are the one who choose
begging for their children. The money that is earned by the child by begging is
used to support the family financially.
One of the other reasons is that the child is an orphan and
is directed towards begging by the other children or the families that are
already into begging.
It is also seen that begging is operated as an organized
crime by a gang. They buy or rent children to use them for begging and thus the
children get involved in the vicious circle. And often it is impossible for
them to break out of it.
Effects of Child Begging:
The entire child's holistic development is majorly disrupted
in this issue. Some factors are discussed below.
The child's health and mental health is affected negatively.
Different domains of the child's development like behavior, education,
psychological development and various other domains are affected.
There is also a high possibility that the child is exposed
to issue that are not appropriate for his/her age. For example getting into
drugs leading them into drug addicts or early exposure to sex are huge risks
for the child well-being.
Children who are involved in this cycle will automatically
guide their next generation into same situation of begging.
These children are often seen adapting to anti- social
behavior leading them to involve in issues like thefts, crime and other
malpractices.
Statistics of Child Begging in Visakhapatnam:
In Visakhaptanam district, there are approximately 450 to
500 Child Begga₹ The ratio of Girl beggars to the Boy beggars is 1:1 which
means that there are equal number of girls and boys who are into begging.
Certain areas where the Child Beggars are seen that most are railway station, bus complex, beach, road signal junctions, temples etc. These migrated families
don't stay in one place and are seen travelling from one area to another. So
tracing them and keeping a trace of them is often a challenge.
Policies and legislation on Child Begging and its Violation:
Children Care and Protection Act, Sec (a) and Sec (b) of
Juvenile Justice Care & Protection Act, 2000 (Amended 2006) which was
earlier called as Juvenile Act, is the act that exists for these children.
Children below 18 years, both girls and boys come under this act. Earlier the
age limit was 15 years for girls and 18 years for boys but now it has been made
as 18 years for both the genders. The Act states that the children who are
involved in begging are counted as neglected children and the children can be
moved to rehabilitation centers for their positive development. Parents who are
identified as a part of this and if we have an identified testimony will have
to be counseled and explained about the well-being of the child. Our project is
designed as per these guidelines.
What do
we do?
GenerationYuvaa has started a Child Home in temporary
residence to provide a shelter for street children, orphans and street beggars. We
are still in process of raising funds a permanent dream home which we would
name it as Generation Yuvaa Child Home.  The
strength right now is capped to 50 children due to lack of funds. These
children are provided with basic facilities like shelter, clothing and food
along with education. Some of these children who are old enough to go to school
are funded for their education. Along with this, the child overall development
is also focused by indulging them in various physical activities and play.
Certain standards are followed while preparing food keeping the nutrition norms
in mind. Along with this, weekly health checkups are done by medical
professionals.
Interventions by GenerationYuvaa:
Spreading awareness: GenerationYuvaa
focuses on spreading a lot of awareness about child begging to bring the focus
on the issue that it is a major social issue that needs to be worked on. This
is done using various ways like spreading pamphlets, rallies and other
resources.
Orphan Child accommodation
and education: OrphanChild beggars are accommodated in our rented residence.
Child and parental counseling:  At
times when parents are involved in child begging, they are counseled. The
organization follows ethical counseling which means that the child or the
parent is never pressured to be a part of the session and the confidentiality
of the cases are not disclosed without permission. In certain cases, where
the child is interested in education but is not financially capable of going to
school, GenerationYuvaa sponsors the child's education.
Public Awareness:
GenerationYuvaa has adapted different ways to reach to
public. Some of them are
Pamphlets
Rallies
Posters
Media (print/
online/ news)
Public talks
(schools/ colleges/ talks)
Skits
Find us on the Internet, Social Network and Media:
Website:
www.genyuvaa.com
Facebook:
https://www.facebook.com/generationyuvaa
YouTube:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuPJ4GSFm3kB2ZGidu6VxVg
Media:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IXb3bkngmnM
What you can Donate?
TIME:
Time is the most precious thing which cannot be retrieved
once it is passed. So if you can spend few minutes of your valuable time to
read the above and get awareness.
MONEY:
Food &
Accommodation costs per Child:Monthly: ₹ 2000 ($ 30) Yearly: ₹ 24,000 ($ 360)
Education costs:(Includes School fee, Books & stationery, Travel
expenses and other miscellaneous charges)Monthly: ₹ 1200 ($ 20) Yearly: ₹ 14,400 ($ 240)
*Miscellaneous:Clothes,
Sports kits, toys, Books & stationery (Books apart from academics include
kids collection/useful books for kids), Sandals, Shoes & Socks. Special classes:Dance, YOGA, Generation Yuvaa Social
Force (GYSF), Painting, Singing etc.
We are also raising funds for our dream permanent GenerationYuvaa
Child Home:
Low cost model dream GenerationYuvaa permanent Child Home
Estimated cost to construct a low cost
model GenerationYuvaa Child Home is ₹ 5,000,000 ($ 75,000)

Hey!
Thank you for putting aside a few minutes to check this out!
Binté is going through a very tough time financially speaking and
is struggling to make ends meet in order to study her passion, law at university.
She has
been living in the UK since she was 7 however after a delayed wait for her
passport, she is being classified as a foreign student which means that she has
to pay for everything up front including course fees, accommodation and food. Which is a pretty big feat if you come from any normal income household  and are only 19 with no savings. This

leaves her having to take out regular loans and results in her only being able to apportion £50 a month to pay for food and resources!

The money raised will be going towards these costs, although it won't cover it all ( she will still need to work full time for 3 months over the summer break) it will make a phenomenal difference in enabling her to pay for it.
The loans are not safe-netted like they are for the rest of us
students when we use Student Finance England
column2: when you have no money/ are not earning enough you still have to pay.

column1: Plus You pay it back with a hefty interest.
Personally, I have donated to many crowd-funded causes before. I really like it’s concept
there is no middle man
column2: there are no over-heads so your money goes solely to the cause.

column1:
Now guys it’s up to you!

I am going to be
cycling in April to the Brecon Beacons which is approx. 110 miles from Coventry to show

my support.

 I didn’t decide to do a sponsored sky dive or anything of that
nature because it can be viewed as a bit of fun and I really wanted to
demonstrate to you that I am not self-interested in that manner and that I’d really like people to get involved and how important it is
of a problem that I will cycle all that way and train for months to get
that point across.
A burden shared is a burden lightened.

Each donation is a massive help! 

Please share to spread the word!

Thank you!!!!



P.s

Seems do-able right?

Well if we can share and encourage others to support, I'm sure we'll smash it!

And thank you so much for your support!!!

Kids Investing in Opportunity

My name is Kayden and I'm 9 years old. My little brother Kiran, my friends and I are launching a campaign called the #PowerOfYouAndMe. 100% of this campaign's proceeds will be donated to Opportunity International Canada.

This is about us kids pooling our money together (taking a little bit from our Christmas money, birthdays, allowances, etc.) and investing it into other people's businesses around the world, so we can help people get out of poverty.  Us kids can make a big change together!

<div>

column1: <h3>A note from Kayden's mom to parents, family &amp
column2:
friends:

Thank you so much for sharing Kayden and Kiran's campaign with your kids.
column3: >My hope in helping them put this campaign together was three-fold:

column1: 1. That they would learn more about how to think like an entrepreneur themselves, as they work to help other entrepreneurs around the world.

2. That this project would create an opportunity for us to discuss the power of investing money - not only in understanding how it works, but also in the financial and social good that can come from this, especially when there is strength in numbers (pooling money together).
3. And, that they would feel empowered, learning that they have the ability to identify a need, and do something about it, to move the needle and bring about positive change.
If you and your kids are able to join this campaign, I hope that they can also benefit in these ways.
Please share your kids' experiences with this campaign in the comments section of this page and use the hashtag #PowerOfYouAndMe on social media if you can.  We'd love to hear more!

","Kids Investing in OpportunityMy name is Kayden and I'm 9 years old. My little brother Kiran, my friends and I are launching a campaign called the #PowerOfYouAndMe. 100% of this campaign's proceeds will be donated to Opportunity International Canada.This is about us kids pooling our money together (taking a little bit from our Christmas money, birthdays, allowances, etc.) and investing it into other people's businesses around the world, so we can help people get out of poverty.  Us kids can make a big change together!
Plus, when you donate here, you can get some totally awesome perks too:
What does Opportunity International Canada do?

This amazing organization fights global poverty through micro-financing (incredibly, 98 percent of these loans are paid back). They help nearly 12 million people in 28 developing countries expand businesses, create jobs for their neighbors and build a safety net of savings and insurance for their families and community. If you want to know more about how ""micro-financing"" works at Opportunity International Canada, check out this video:

Help us spread the word on social media: If it's cool with your mom or dad, help us spread the word through their social media accounts.  Ask them to take a picture with your family and friends who are donating with you, and share it using the hashtag: #PowerOfYouAndMe.
A note from Kayden's mom to parents, family & friends: Thank you so much for sharing Kayden and Kiran's campaign with your kids. My hope in helping them put this campaign together was three-fold:
1. That they would learn more about how to think like an entrepreneur themselves, as they work to help other entrepreneurs around the world.

2. That this project would create an opportunity for us to discuss the power of investing money - not only in understanding how it works, but also in the financial and social good that can come from this, especially when there is strength in numbers (pooling money together).
3. And, that they would feel empowered, learning that they have the ability to identify a need, and do something about it, to move the needle and bring about positive change.
If you and your kids are able to join this campaign, I hope that they can also benefit in these ways.
Please share your kids' experiences with this campaign in the comments section of this page and use the hashtag #PowerOfYouAndMe on social media if you can.  We'd love to hear more! Thanks again!
|","Toronto, Canada",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-kids-give-back-as-micro-financiers/pica
0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h2><b style=""background-color: initial
column3:
>The Whole n' Happy is the first online, multi-dimensional mindfulness school in the world. 

It's made to empower our future generation to connect to their own truth in this world.

It's an online space to learn, engage, and explore who you are, on the inside and out.  

It's a comprehensive approach to learning made to empower our children and prepare them for our future world. 

 

We do this by providing students, teachers and parents a series of engaging online courses with aligned mindfulness meditations, and a community of like-minded educators who are inspired to educate our children in new ways.

 

 

Our online courses are paired with a mindfulness app (for the classroom or home) and an easy-to-read handbook that describes each mindfulness strategy in detail and gives suggestions for simple implementation.

​
column5:
/>

 

With each skill or strategy, there are aligned audio meditations and creative journal pages made specifically for self-exploration!

 

And our immersive, on-site trainings at schools bring the techniques to real life with an interactive Mindfulness Toolkit to help teachers and students better understand how the practices relate to their own lives.

column1: Who We Are and What We Do:
Hello. My name is Kelsey Beth. I am an international educator, designer, mindfulness activist, and citizen of the world.
I want every child to be seen and met exactly as they are.
I want our future generation to know and develop their own truth and purpose for being on this planet.
I want to transform the way we Educate our children and our future, from the inside-out.

This vision grew from my experiences working and teaching around the globe. During this time, I transformed from a young, and passionate teacher to a stressed-out and unhealthy educator, who felt the intense demands of our constantly changing Education Systems.
I was teaching a curriculum I didn’t believe in and administering standardized tests that was against what I believed was good for the children.
I spent my breaks doing administrative work instead of planning and truly being there for the kids.
My Vision of Education empowers individuals and allows their natural talents and passions to unfold, instead of placing them in a box, on a scale, or assigned to a number.
With Your Support:
With your support, we will be able to:
<ul>
• Launch the first-ever sustainable, online mindfulness school in the world
• Provide series of engaging online mindfulness courses with aligned, audio meditations for teachers and parents, so they can bring the techniques back to their workplaces and homes

• Hire and pay the best animator in the world (estimated $16,000) to help us bring our multiple series of children's meditations to real life with eye-catching animated videos and mindfulness meditations

• Hire and pay an amazing web designer (estimated 15,000) for our interactive, multi-dimensional virtual online school - so teachers, students, and parents can access the content from anywhere in the world
• Hire and pay and illustrator and graphic designer ($6,000) to make the last, finishing touches on our creative journals and mindfulness task cards made for self-exploration
• Hire and pay an editor (estimated $6,000) to proofread our 16-Week Mindfulness Handbook for teachers and parents
• Buy video equipment for our multiple series of online courses ($4,000)
• Create an easy-to-use mindfulness app of our meditations, journal pages, and animated videos for classrooms and homes (estimated $5,000)
• Provide materials and on-going support, materials (curricula, journals, task cards, training materials) for our program in our pilot schools ($6,000)
• Provide for travel costs between our pilot schools ($2,000)
With your support, we will be able to bring our life-changing work to kids, teachers, and parents around the world.
How Mindful Kids Will Change Our World:
When I brought this program to my own classroom in the previous years, I have  seen fundamental shifts in how the students related to themselves, others, and their environment.
Mindful kids will change our World because they:
<ul>
• Can breathe through difficult situations and are aware of their own behavior and emotions
• Have a greater sense of focus and larger attention span
• Are able to think in different ways in order to solve problems on their own
• Experience reduced stress, anxiety, and reactivity to difficult situations
• Are able to trace their own thoughts and explain how their thoughts are related to their own  feelings, or actions
• Have an improved sense of confidence and self-worth and are able to acknowledge their own strengths
• Experience a greater sense of calm and inner peace, as well as improved sleep
• Have a deep awareness and understanding of themselves
• Are able to connect with others in meaningful ways
• Experience greater mental, emotional, and physical well-being, positive emotion, and social connections
