Short Summary

I am Rusty Rhodes, a pastor, educator, filmmaker, and president of the Christian Youth Film Society. I've teamed up with Joe Brown, Executive Director, and Scott Garcia, Board Member/Mentor, with a mission to influence our culture for the better. We have dedicated ourselves to equip the next generation of filmmakers who are loyal to Jesus, pursue truth with vigor, and create narrative art that honors the author of life and reality. We want to see talented young people sharpen their craft of great storytelling and enter the culture to create positive changes for Christ. Our current project will begin production during our 2016 Making Movie Makers for Christ Film Camp. The movie, a comedy-western entitled ""Treasure Hunt,"" will be used to train young people behind and in front of the camera, give opportunities for discipleship, and produce a lasting product that thousands of families will enjoy! You can be a part of something that has lasting influence!

The story is about Lily and Earnest O'Brien who are in financial trouble because of Lily's get-rich-quick schemes. So even though Lily hates her cousin Sadie, when Sadie offers a chance to find a hidden stash of wealth they make an uneasy alliance and face danger in the desert. The movie explores the theme offered by Jesus in Matthew 6:19-20, ""Do not lay up for yourselves treasures on earth where moth and rust corrupt and where thieves break in and steal. But lay up for yourselves treasures in Heaven.""
<h3>What We Need &amp

There are many people volunteering their time and talent to this production. But that doesn't negate many costs associated with a production like this. We need $9750 to cover costuming, makeup, props, sets and set dressing, some equipment rentals, location scouting, transportation to five different locales, the food and boarding of horses and people, and expendables.
All those who donate $25 or more will receive a free download of our recent project FOUR HUNDRED NINETY-ONE.
All those who donate $50 or more will receive the FOUR HUNDRED NINETY-ONE download and a free TREASURE HUNT download after its June 2017 premiere.
All those who donate $75 or more will receive the above two free downloads and two free tickets to the premiere of TREASURE HUNT.
All those who donate $100 or more will receive the two free downloads, two free premiere tickets, and their names in the credit roll of the movie.
All funds raised will go to the successful production of TREASURE HUNT
The Impact

We are about making a difference in the lives of young people who will then make a positive difference in our world! While we help them develop their talents for Jesus we want to develop their character as well. The final product will be something you'll be proud to have been a part of. But there is intrinsic and eternal rewards  as well as we influence lives for the sake of Christ!

The Christian Youth Film Society has mentored young men and women who are now working in Hollywood and in their churches -- using their talent to glorify God! We've inspired teens for 23 years and this is one more opportunity to join us in this mission
<h3>Risks &amp

Making a movie is a difficult task. Making a great movie takes a herculean effort! Our pre-production continues to be thorough. But the logistics of shooting in the beautiful environs of the Alabama Hills, Mojave Desert, and the valley and foothills of Kern County over several months will bring unexpected challenges. We have built a team -- and are expanding that team -- to make this project a success. We have been successful with 23 years of festivals, multiple film camps, several workshops, and other productions. We are privileged to work with positive people who bring their best and simply persevere until we succeed.
Other Ways You Can Help

We will have many needs as we progress through this project that are beyond financial. Already, many have stepped up and volunteered and/or loaned their expertise, services, and property to make us a success. Stay connected on Facebook (The Treasure Hunt Project) and/or twitter (@rustywriter2) to see how you can help.
BE A PART OF SOMETHING THAT WILL TRANSFORM LIVES AND CHANGE OUR WORLD FOR THE BETTER! GO ON A TREASURE HUNT WITH US AND LAY UP TREASURES IN HEAVEN!

Frank Dausen Swai

I was born in the beautiful land of Tanzania in the slopes of Mount Kilimanjaro in 1989. I live with my all parent where my father has a small farm where he grows coffee, maize, beans and bananas. My mother is a home mom and has health problem so I request you to pray for her. Due to the drought our family has been passing in a difficult life but am happy my parent struggled much until I finished my university studies in November 2014. It has been challenging to get job here as it depend on who you know and not what you know that is (networking). Due to this situation am now working hard so that I can start my own tour company in Tanzania. (http://www.steppedogsadventures.com). Through my struggling I trust that will make it happen!
Daines Peter Mdee

She is my wife to be and starting from February she will be my wife until death will separate us. She was born in the beautiful land of Tanzania about 466km away from where I was born. She got her education from primary school to college and now has certificate of pharmaceutical in Medicine Dispensing. She is still looking for a job so please pray for her!
Where we met?

I met Daines when I was high school. I fall in love with her and happy she accepted me to be her boyfriend. Our relationship has 6 years now and happy though we have been passing in a difficult times God has been on our side.
Why are we getting marriage?
God created us to live in this world and fill it. We love each other very much so we want to live together until death separate us. Please pray for us.
When are we expecting to get marriage?
We are checking calendar but proposed date is 2nd March 2017 or 9th March 2017
Is there any wedding has been done in your family?
If we will succeed it will be the first wedding to be done in our family so please help us make it happen!
What we need for our wedding
We need the following things to make our dream come true
1. Wedding gown and shoes for my wife to be....................................$350
5. MC &
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:
• Please share this with anyone that might know us and would like to contribute
Thanks everyone for being with us through these exciting and crazy times. Cheers!

ABOUT

This conference is organized by the newly formed Brown Psychedelic Science Group, a group of medical students, psychology graduate students, and undergraduate students at Brown interested in the scientific exploration of the healing potential of psychedelics. Please reach out to us at Brownmedpsychedelics@gmail.com if you have any questions or would like to be involved! (Or just to say hello). Thank you!
We're honored to host our conference at Alpert Medical School of Brown University. We humbly ask for $3500 to directly fund the travel and accommodation of our valued speakers.
Speakers:

Casey Paleos, MD - Clinical Assistant Professor of Psychiatry, NYU School of Medicine
Egolysis As An Explanatory Model For The Therapeutic Effect Of Psychedelic Medicine

Stephen Ross, MD - Associate Professor of Psychiatry, NYU School of Medicine

The NYU Psychedelic Research Group: past, present, future

Rick Doblin, PhD - Founder of Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS)

Phase 3 MDMA/PTSD research and the route to legal psychedelic therapy clinics in America

Katherine Maclean, PhD - Director of the Psychedelic Education and Continuing Care Program at the Center for Optimal Living in New York City
Psychedelic Education &
column2:
Integration: A Harm-reduction Approach to Promoting the Safe, Therapeutic Use of Psychedelics

Matthew Johnson, PhD - Associate Professor of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences, Johns Hopkins School of Medicine
The Return of Psychedelic Medicine: Psilocybin in the Treatment of Addiction and Cancer-related Distress

column1:
IMPORTANCE

 

Academic meetings and research inquiries on psychedelics aid in the dissemination of accurate knowledge concerning safety and constructive use, contribute to informed public policy and affect legislation to  maximize public health. This symposium will take place days after a large gathering of scientists and policy makers at Psychedelic Science 2017 conference in Oakland, California.  Our speakers will be bringing with them fresh ideas and themes in psychedelic research that arise in Oakland for attendees of this conference to engage with and expand upon. Through your generous donations, we hope to bring these conversations to our institution for the first time to engage audiences who do not have the privilege to attend other conferences on these topics taking place across the country and around the world.
What We Need

The conference budget includes travel expenses, accommodation, and honorarium for our speakers.  Our group is also working hard to raise funds for food and other conference expenses. We have been able to secure a modest grant from our generous alumni association for the event. However, we will need the support of private donors and sponsors to meet our goal. The $3500 that we are asking for will go directly toward accommodating the keynote speakers.
Other Ways You Can Help
We appreciate all forms of your support:

- Help us spread the word! Please share this indiegogo campaign and the event details (links below) with corporate or private donors who would love to support Psychedelics in Science and Medicine. We also encourage you to share this campaign on your social media sites.

Facebook event page: https://www.facebook.com/events/1803541663244496/

Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/psychedelics-in-medicine-tickets-30671388950

Email us with questions: brownmedpsychedelics@gmail.com

Thank You!

Short Summary
Hi! I'm Dr. Tamara Pizzoli. I'm a children’s literature author, art curator, and producer who was born and raised in Texas and has lived in Rome for over a decade.

As a former kindergarten teacher, I have a particular love for stories, and for the past few years I've dedicated my personal and professional life to storytelling through producing quality content across various mediums. Though I love making documentaries and web series, my greatest passion is writing and publishing books for children via my publishing house, The English Schoolhouse (theenglishschoolhouse.com).

Since beginning to write full-time in 2014, I've penned and published fifteen titles (and counting), and I've been fortunate to have my books featured on several prominent platforms including My Brown Baby, HuffPost, and Afropunk regularly.

In 2016, I self-published Tallulah the Tooth Fairy CEO. One year later the title was signed to the premiere imprint Farrar Straus and Giroux at MacMillan. And on International Women’s Day this year it was announced that Tallulah the Tooth Fairy CEO had been optioned to be made into a live-action film produced by Gabrielle Union and John Sacchi, the former Vice President of Lionsgate.
https://deadline.com/2019/03/gabrielle-union-5-...
The book has also received a significant literary nod, a Kirkus starred review, in which it was deemed ""funny and provocative"".
https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/tama...

I'm thrilled that Tallulah the Tooth Fairy CEO is already creating such a significant amount of buzz. Here we have a Black tooth fairy who is a mogul, sports an afro, frequents museums and has a board of directors. I believe both the text and imagery are the type of quality fiction all children should be exposed to early and often.

I've set a goal to ensure that the story of Tallulah the Tooth Fairy CEO ends up in as many hands and hearts as possible this summer. I'm setting out on a book tour with my assistant and will be visiting many cities on the east coast and in the south starting on the book’s rerelease date, July 30. I would love your support to make the tour, and Tallulah, a huge success.
Books like Tallulah have large societal implications and relevance. Here are some alarming statistics regarding representation in the world of children’s literature:
-Only 7% of new children’s literature in 2017 were written by Black, Latinx or Native authors.
-In 2018, the CLPE in the UK found that only 1% of children’s books depicted a main character who was Black or minority ethnic.

It’s not enough to simply be aware of these stats. When we are presented with individuals who are working steadily to make a difference, we hold a powerful position to assist in active problem-solving. The answer seems clear to me: we need more—more presence, creation, and support.
<h3>What We Need &amp
So here's the goal: 20K in 20 Days.
Say it with me. 20K in 20 Days.
We can do this! We gotta do this!
Here's why--

The funds raised will assist with travel and lodging, transportation, book purchases and deliveries, marketing and appearances at festivals, museums and bookstores. Festival appearances in particular cost a pretty penny. We will be at Afropunk in Brooklyn as well as at the Essence Festival in July (stop by our table and say hello if you're attending either or both!)

And should we (fingers crossed) exceed the goal, we can add more cities to our tour schedule, print and manufacture fun freebies for kids, like buttons and stickers and bookmarks, and visit summer and charter schools with books in hand.
We welcome support and contributions from individuals, small businesses, and large corporations.
This week we secured our first corporate sponsor, the fashion house Stella Jean Roma (it's also my favorite brand).
So here are the PERKS:

First and most important, you'll be supporting multicultural content and positive imagery. You'll be contributing to what kids deserve--more great stories that they can see themselves and others in. And you'll be assisting in helping to get the word out about a wonderful book that deserves to be on top (Tallulah's words...not mine).
$25 or greater
-You'll receive a digital THANK YOU
$150 or greater
-You'll receive a handwritten THANK YOU mailed to you and a small personalized digital art portrait
-You'll receive a handwritten THANK YOU
-a personalized portrait
-a signed tour poster
-a signed copy of the book
$1,500 or greater
-You'll receive a handwritten THANK YOU
-a personalized portrait
-3 signed tour posters
-5 signed copies of the book
$5,000 or greater
-Enjoy a 1/4 page advertisement placed in every signed book on the tour
-Your company listed as one of our book tour sponsors on The English Schoolhouse’s website
$10,000 or greater
-Enjoy a 1/2 page advertisement placed in every signed book on the tour
-Your company logo listed on our website
-2 linked social media posts in during the month of September
-a blog post highlighting your sponsorship
-10 books signed by Dr. Pizzoli for giveaways or promotion for your company
-your company logo or name featured on our event table at each event
$15,000 or greater
-Enjoy a full page advertisement placed in every signed book on the tour
-Your company logo and description prominently featured on our website
-2 linked social media posts monthly during September, October and November 2019
-15 books signed by Dr. Pizzoli for giveaways or promotion for your company and a classroom set of books donated to the school of your choice
-Your company logo or name featured on our event table at each event
All love and support is welcome and deeply appreciated.
The Impact
So many kids, much like the adults who raise them, tend to believe what they see and what they read. Together, we can impact how not only the classic tooth fairy is perceived, but authors as well.
Personally, I know I'm on the right track when I get messages like this one:
A picture is worth a thousand words...
At my house, the tooth fairy has a name. It's Tallulah...
Together we can change hearts and minds of little ones and big ones alike.
<h3>Risks &amp
Welp, all of my meditations recently have been geared toward only thinking positive, and expecting things to go wonderfully well. So I'm going to go that route and move on to the next section...
Other Ways You Can Help
If you love Tallulah and what we're doing with this campaign, make like Bob Marley and
PASS IT ON!
Like it, share it, love it, tweet about it, check up on it, blog about it, and please tell your friends and family!
Don't be bashful! Pass around a third collection plate at church, ask a Girl Scout to let you hold some money for another good cause--whatever it takes!
You can follow the campaign's progress here, of course, but I'm also on Instagram (@tamarapizzoli) and FB (Tamara Pizzoli) and will be updating everyone regularly.

Also, if you're so inclined, please contact your local library and bookstore and ask them to pre-order/order copies. Our team is open to recommendations for school and bookstore visits so send those our way as well. Inquiries or suggestions can be emailed to info@theenglishschoolhouse.com.
So, I hope to see you all this summer! And thank you so much for your time and support!

So many kids, much like the adults who raise them, tend to believe what they see and what they read. Together, we can impact how not only the classic tooth fairy is perceived, but authors as well.
Personally, I know I'm on the right track when I get messages like this one:
A picture is worth a thousand words...
At my house, the tooth fairy has a name. It's Tallulah...
Together we can change hearts and minds of little ones and big ones alike.
Risks & Challenges
Welp, all of my meditations recently have been geared toward only thinking positive, and expecting things to go wonderfully well. So I'm going to go that route and move on to the next section...
Other Ways You Can Help
If you love Tallulah and what we're doing with this campaign, make like Bob Marley and
PASS IT ON!
Like it, share it, love it, tweet about it, check up on it, blog about it, and please tell your friends and family!
Don't be bashful! Pass around a third collection plate at church, ask a Girl Scout to let you hold some money for another good cause--whatever it takes!
You can follow the campaign's progress here, of course, but I'm also on Instagram (@tamarapizzoli) and FB (Tamara Pizzoli) and will be updating everyone regularly.

Also, if you're so inclined, please contact your local library and bookstore and ask them to pre-order/order copies. Our team is open to recommendations for school and bookstore visits so send those our way as well. Inquiries or suggestions can be emailed to info@theenglishschoolhouse.com.
So, I hope to see you all this summer! And thank you so much for your time and support!",10.0,0,"4 Campaigns
|","New York, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/tallulah-the-tooth-fairy-ceo-on-tour/pica

Arduino is the world’s most popular open-source electronics tool, used every day by millions of people for experimenting and learning electronics. Thanks to the support of the maker community, anyone can share their knowledge and learn from thousands of other projects. You can create anything using basic components like switches and LEDs, or more advanced components like digital interfaces and wireless communication modules. The only limit is your imagination!

Makers around the world have asked themselves the same question: where do I find reliable and easy to use circuit diagrams for my projects? I've spent years tinkering and making stuff with Arduino, ARM mbed, ESP8266, etc and one of the things that always annoyed was how difficult it was to find reliable, simple to read and aesthetically pleasing circuit diagrams, reference tables and pinouts.

Back in 2013 I began designing my own and making them available for free on my website pighixxx.com. I have created so far more than 300 high quality circuit diagrams and pinouts that are used by more than 500,000 makers worldwide. The feedback from the community has been amazing and it has encouraged me to create more and more content. The only problem is that they're not very convenient to use on your computer screen where the programming environment should be the main open window. Also, printing the diagrams can only add more clutter to your desk.
We've been working hard for the past months to deliver a great product that will solve these problems.
ABC: Basic Connections
ABC: Basic Connections is a completely redesigned selection of the best circuit diagrams, reference tables and pinouts from pighixxx.com, plus many new unreleased designs.

The book is a collection of neat, easy to read circuit diagrams and pinouts that will show you how to properly connect almost anything to your Arduino, ARM mbed or ESP8266, etc. compatible boards. ABC: Basic Connections is great for both beginners and professionals and it can be used as a resource for teaching electronics.
Press

Learn how to connect LEDs, decoders, shift registers, 7-segment displays, mux/demux, light bulbs, DC motors, solenoids, relays, buzzers, IR detectors and emitters, LCDs, encoders, keypads, temperature sensors, and so much more!

The book will contain more than 100 high quality, 200gsm, coated, A5 (8.27x5.83 in) sheets inside a custom ring binder, with multi-color tab dividers. The sheets are removable giving you the flexibility to use only the ones you need for each project, minimizing the clutter on your desk. There is enough room for 50 additional sheets, allowing you to add your own printed sheets to the collection, as well as additional sheets from the “expansion kits” we are planing to release in the future.

The first pre-release units were delivered to us by our manufacturing partner a couple of weeks ago and I must say they look amazing! The pictures don't do justice to how great it looks and feels. Bear in mind that these pre-release copies were printed using digital printing technology. Also, the colors may look duller due to the color grading applied to the pictures. The books will be printed using offset printing technology, achieving much more vibrant colors and professional quality results!

We want to support local manufacturing in Spain, that's why we partnered with a printing company that has been making high quality print media for more than 35 years in the south of Madrid. By doing this, we can also reduce lead times for manufacturing and shipping, and oversee the full production to ensure that the book will meet our strict quality standards.
Extra content

You're not only receiving a book with high quality circuit diagrams. Every page on the book will have an online tutorial website with additional diagrams, bill of materials, theory, tips, code, etc. We're using our own link shortening service 0-1.es for that purpose.

Fritzing breadboard diagrams can either look good, or look like a total mess, depending on who designs them. But they don't teach you anything about the circuit at first glance, what you do when you use them is copy the diagram on your breadboard mechanically...

Breadboard diagrams will be available online as well, but we encourage you to assemble the board using the circuit diagrams and use the breadboard diagrams only to make sure all the connections are properly made and nothing is missing.
Those who purchased the first edition of ABC (ABC: The Book) will be able to access the online content at no extra cost!
Stretch goals
Two stretch goals were unlocked during the Kickstarter campaign, the following features will also be included with the book!!
Current state of the project

The book is currently undergoing a thorough review process. With the feedback we're receiving from our reviewers, plus your feedback during the campaign, we will be able to have the book ready by the end of the campaign. Our manufacturing partner will be notified in advance and the manufacturing process will begin right after the campaign ends. We are confident that all rewards will be shipped in August.

Shipping will be done with one fo the best global fulfilment companies. We're doing everything we can to offer affordable shipping to all of you, but unfortunately it's not easy to do it for some countries, considering the complexity of the logistics and that the book weighs almost 1kg. ABC: Basic Connections will be shipped from the US to our US backers.

Back in 2013 and thanks to more than 2800 backers on Indiegogo, I was able deliver more than 4000 units of ABC: The Book around the world. Unfortunately, no more copies were printed after the campaign.

ABC: Basic Connections features a completely redesigned version of each circuit diagram found in the 2013 edition of ABC, plus many more unreleased designs. More than 100 sheets (200+ pages!), more than double compared to the 2013 edition of ABC.
Disclaimer
I have no relationship with Arduino (the company). When I say ""Arduino"", I'm referring to the ecosystem and the community.

I would like to remark that right after the rewards of my ABC: The Book campaign back in 2013 were delivered, and after countless headaches and less hair on my head, I severed all ties with smARtMAKER, Inc., the company that was responsible for managing the fulfilment and the campaign. We have absolutely no relationship with them. For this campaign, my team and I are 100% in charge of design, publishing and fulfilment.
Risks and challenges

Our manufacturing partner has proven to be reliable and reachable at all times. It's a family run business that has been producing high quality print media for the past 35 years. They are based in the south of Madrid, a short drive away from our office. We have toured their company and manufacturing facilities and inspected some of the finished products they were making and the results look and feel amazing. However, will be overseeing the manufacturing process actively to make sure everything is done according to our specifications.

Back in 2013 and thanks to more than 2800 backers on Indiegogo, I was able deliver more than 4000 units of ABC: The Book around the world swiftly and hassle-free. For this campaign, lead times will be shorter and everything will be under our direct supervision.

In order to make this book affordable enough, we need to print at least 2000 copies. Printing in Europe is more expensive than doing it in China, we need your help to keep the costs low, please share this campaign with your friends and colleagues and help us spread the word!! :D
With your feedback, we can make the book even better! Please send us your comments at feedback@abcthebook.com

If the campaign is successful, I will be dedicating much more time to making more and more content. Thank you very much to all of you for supporting the creation of more circuit diagrams and pinouts for the past years!

Background

In 2005, two retired educators who passionately agreed that young families in Jacksonville, NC need more activities to do with their children that are fun and educational began a journey. Within a year, a committee was formed and a mission was developed to create a special place for play and learning in Jacksonville and the surrounding area.

With the space selected, the organizing committee of the museum engaged school children to name the facility. A kindergarten student at Swansboro Elementary School entered the contest with the idea she wanted an ""amazing museum"" in her community. She suggested that the ""Zing"" in amazing and the ""Zumm"" in museum make up the name ""Zing Zumm"".  Therefore the museum name will be: Zing Zumm Children's Museum of Jacksonville.

Now that the Fire Station on Barn Street will be the location for the Zing Zumm museum, we are proceeding with our Capital Campaign to raise funds to renovate, hire a director and open the doors for the new Children’s Museum.
Our goal!
It is simple. The organizing committee has set out to raise $400,000. We have begun raising funds in the community and have about $85,000 in pledges.
Funds will be used as follows:
$175,000 to renovate the entire 3,500 square foot space
$170,000 for permanent, interactive, hands on exhibits
$55,000 for start-up operating costs

With your help the vision for Zing Zumm will soon be realized. Please carefully consider the benefits to our community and make a contribution to the campaign. While gifts of any amount are needed and welcome, early significant contributions will establish momentum and provide a pathway to success. Thank you!

<h3><b style=""letter-spacing: 0px

Besides having engaging, hands-on exhibits for visitors, the museum will eventually offer the following to members of the Jacksonville community and the region. It is important to note that many of these services are revenue generating and will support the ongoing operations of Zing Zumm.

Our Community

Jacksonville, NC is a young community with many military families.  These families sacrifice so much for our country and the museum would be a great asset for them. The military population is young and their children need a place like Zing Zumm. The museum would serve as a place to have fun and forget the stresses associated with having parents deployed and serving in other capacities.
Along with our young families, many of our citizens are retired veterans living on a very limited fixed income thus our opportunities for fundraising can be very challenging.
<div>
Camp Lejeune and the New River Air Station  is home to an active duty, dependent , retiree and civilian employee population of approximately  190,000.

Housing Education Workshops
individuals to build a dignified human life. With secure and stable housing,
individuals are more likely to contribute to a region’s economic growth, pursue
education, build a solid family structure, obtain better personal health, and
experience a higher quality of life. A significant barrier to adequate shelter
is lack of educational services for homeless individuals or individuals at-risk
of becoming homeless. To address this barrier, the London Housing Registry has
designed a Housing Education Workshop and are seeking funds to begin the
implementation of these workshops across London communities.
What We Need &

Our fundraising goal is $2500, your donations will fund 24 Housing Education Workshops.  If we don't reach our entire goal, the funds will be spent entirely on running as many Housing Education workshops as possible (each workshop will cost approximately $100).
Your donation will get you one of many unique and exciting perks, check them out!

column2: >** You may also request a charitable receipt in lieu of a perk over $100 ! **

column1: <blockquote>

The London Housing Registry’s experience and interactive approach with both the clients and the landlords is an essential part of our community. This is a vital service that has been helping those in desperate need since 1984. Those at risk of becoming homeless or currently homeless will be further driven into anonymity without the Registry’s help.”

-London Property Manager
Our Impact
Your funding will allow Housing
Education Workshops to run once a month for approximately 12 months. Each hour
and a half long workshop will consist of a lecture portion and a question and
answer period. These interactive workshops will host 10 to 20 individuals per
workshop and will cater to a variety of populations facing barriers to maintaining adequate
housing. These populations include but are not limited to first time renters,
individuals with no established credit or who cannot supply a cosigner,
individuals who struggle with financial literacy, and those who have difficulty
managing roommate relationships.
Workshops will follow a detailed program
with topics that include tenant rights and responsibilities in accordance with
the Residential Tenancies Act, how to fill a rental
application, what to look for when viewing an apartment, housing options, fire safety, how to stretch
a dollar, apartment insurance, city
by-laws, landlord responsibilities, avoiding eviction, understanding lease
agreements, roommate accord and agreements, pet care skills, cleaning your
apartment, recycling, and personal safety.
<blockquote>
I was handed your phone number by my boss. Your knowledge sent me in the
right direction. I was eight months pregnant and homeless and now on my
way to bringing my baby into a safe and comfortable environment. I felt
at a dead end and was grasping at straws when you literally held out
your hands. I came back to London after 14 years and was empty-handed,
homeless, alone and with child. I am now feeling secure, warm and on my
way to a new life of love and support. Your guidance and knowledge of
community services is so needed and I am definitely a small but success

story.”

-Pregnant Female Client

Our Challenges

The number one hurdle for the London Housing Registry to provide programming is funding!  Your contributions will directly impact our community here in London by helping individuals maintain adequate housing through education!
<blockquote>

I have used this service over a dozen times. The London Housing Registry and their staff were helpful and efficient in helping me find a new place that I now reside at that I can afford and am happy with. They have always been there in my times of need.”

-Single Male Client

Other Ways You Can Help Us

If you cannot contribute, or even if you can, please give us a shout out on your social media pages and help us get the word out!
<a href=""http://londonhousingregistry.com/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"">

Evan Oglesby &
column2:
Brandi England

Evan Oglesby played 5 seasons in the NFL and during this time founded the Evan Oglesby Foundation in 2008, giving away scholarships to teens entering college and then opened the EO CENTER to give anyone under the age of 19 a safe place to come get healthy, have fun and stay safe.

column1: Brandi England began speaking around the world when she was only 17 years old, her passion to inspire millions of teens to find their self worth and in turn pass it on to the future generations.

Together Evan (www.evanoglesbyfoundation.org) and Brandi (www.globalteenwealth.org) created a live program in Toccoa, Georgia which provides youth a the tools to an active, healthy and successful lifestyle.

Our Campaign is important to us because upon launching, we currently have 60 teens in the program, and are overwhelmed by the positive response from the community. Over 1000 students are now on the waiting list for the program... and that's just in North East Georgia. Imagine if we could get this in every high school in America? We could literally change thousands of lives.

For each teen in the programs (Teen Wealth + Fit Kids/Healthy Teens) it costs $20 for the printing of the books, $20 for the yearly magazine printing and $10 per CD pack. That's $50 to change the life of a teen forever.

To get all 1,000 teens access to the program basics, we need $50/teen for materials. To help all 1,000 teens on the wait list, we need $5,000.

Now... the goal is to reach more than 1,000. The goal is to reach every young person across the world that is struggling.

Once we have 1,000 teens in the program, we wont stop there... we are also raising another $5,000 to help us develop an online training platform for these exact programs.  The $5,000 includes filming and editing of the videos, as well as web developer fees to put the entire platform online to reach all nations.

Imagine if:

- 1 million teens around the world are EMPOWERED, CONFIDENT and READY for life after high school.
- 1 million teens live a life of health and fitness while sharing their knowledge of nutrition with their own families.
- 1 million teen entrepreneurs who are money savvy business owners and compassionate donors to other non-profits and teen entrepreneurs around the world.
IMAGINE THE IMPACT... every single adult we talk to says ""I wish I had your program when I was a kid""... let us help today's youth become tomorrows leaders. Leaders in health, wellness and life.

We don't have all the answers...

However we have 60 kids who are right now stepping out of their boxes to become confident and inspired. We can see the sparkle in their eyes, some for the first time.
Why trust us to make the change?

Evan currently has over 300 young men and women in his center every month, and since 2008 has given away 16 scholarships, won various awards for his philanthropic work, and continues to speak on stages across the United States to inspire even more.
Brandi has spoken on 3 continents, to over 50,000 people in her lifetime. She is the host of nationally syndicated radio show Teen Wealth with Voice America and Author of What Happy Teens Know.

But its not us that's making the difference, its the kids in the programs. They are returning to school with a spark in their step, they are going home with renewed vision for their futures and they are bringing us to tears with their stories of overcoming struggle.

There are many ways you can help :)
- volunteer your time to write in our magazine or share your story on our radio show.
- spread the word on Indiegogo, Twitter, Facebook, Instagram
- write to us with suggestions (we are always expanding our programming).
- sponsor a teen for $10/month.
- donate, even $1 helps us help more teens.

","Evan Oglesby & Brandi EnglandEvan Oglesby played 5 seasons in the NFL and during this time founded the Evan Oglesby Foundation in 2008, giving away scholarships to teens entering college and then opened the EO CENTER to give anyone under the age of 19 a safe place to come get healthy, have fun and stay safe.
Brandi England began speaking around the world when she was only 17 years old, her passion to inspire millions of teens to find their self worth and in turn pass it on to the future generations.

Together Evan (www.evanoglesbyfoundation.org) and Brandi (www.globalteenwealth.org) created a live program in Toccoa, Georgia which provides youth a the tools to an active, healthy and successful lifestyle.

Our Campaign is important to us because upon launching, we currently have 60 teens in the program, and are overwhelmed by the positive response from the community. Over 1000 students are now on the waiting list for the program... and that's just in North East Georgia. Imagine if we could get this in every high school in America? We could literally change thousands of lives.

For each teen in the programs (Teen Wealth + Fit Kids/Healthy Teens) it costs $20 for the printing of the books, $20 for the yearly magazine printing and $10 per CD pack. That's $50 to change the life of a teen forever.To get all 1,000 teens access to the program basics, we need $50/teen for materials. To help all 1,000 teens on the wait list, we need $5,000. Now... the goal is to reach more than 1,000. The goal is to reach every young person across the world that is struggling.Once we have 1,000 teens in the program, we wont stop there... we are also raising another $5,000 to help us develop an online training platform for these exact programs.  The $5,000 includes filming and editing of the videos, as well as web developer fees to put the entire platform online to reach all nations.
Imagine if: - 1 million teens around the world are EMPOWERED, CONFIDENT and READY for life after high school.
- 1 million teens live a life of health and fitness while sharing their knowledge of nutrition with their own families.
- 1 million teen entrepreneurs who are money savvy business owners and compassionate donors to other non-profits and teen entrepreneurs around the world.
IMAGINE THE IMPACT... every single adult we talk to says ""I wish I had your program when I was a kid""... let us help today's youth become tomorrows leaders. Leaders in health, wellness and life.

We don't have all the answers...  However we have 60 kids who are right now stepping out of their boxes to become confident and inspired. We can see the sparkle in their eyes, some for the first time.
Why trust us to make the change?

Evan currently has over 300 young men and women in his center every month, and since 2008 has given away 16 scholarships, won various awards for his philanthropic work, and continues to speak on stages across the United States to inspire even more.
Brandi has spoken on 3 continents, to over 50,000 people in her lifetime. She is the host of nationally syndicated radio show Teen Wealth with Voice America and Author of What Happy Teens Know.

But its not us that's making the difference, its the kids in the programs. They are returning to school with a spark in their step, they are going home with renewed vision for their futures and they are bringing us to tears with their stories of overcoming struggle.

column6: >The Innovation Center is a  business and leadership focused mentorship program to support fresh and young graduates realize their dreams and contribute to improving social, economic and health welfare of the society.

column3: >I am Alex Mokori, during the week I work as a Program Manager in an NGO in Uganda but during the last 12 months, I have spent most of my free time serving as a volunteer mentor and building a program to support  young graduates who want to pursue social entrepreneurship in Uganda.

column2: >I like many of you are fascinated about the prospect of raising fresh young and youthful leaders. Every time I remember the pain parents, guardians, friends or even donors go through in raising money to educate children hoping one day they will graduate to help them, their own siblings, communities, countries and the world at large, I forced to share the little I have to help. I am not yet a parent so I may not know exactly how painful it is to sacrifice everything you have to give your loved one education but I know what it feels like to have creative mind and dreams that you can't realize because you have no starting point or anyone to help you shape your dreams.

>Picture the parents of these impoverished children living deep in Amuria district in Uganda sacrificing everything they got to educate their sons and daughters hoping one day they will save their village when after University. Do you know how much trauma those parents have when those children graduate to unemployment and eventually to alcoholism, HIV and accidents due to frustrations?

column5: >You my friends are changing the world of these fresh graduates, their families and generations to come. I am sure the Innovation Centre will forever groom creative young change agents and innovators who'll contribute to solving one of the most painful social challenges of the 21st century: increased low self esteem due to unemployment.

column8: >The world needs social change champions NOW

column1: Social change champions and creative thinkers are in short supply today. Indeed the Global Nutrition Report 2014 called for  the recognition, supporting and expanding the number of national nutrition champions as one of the ten actions to accelerate the world's progress on nutrition.  At the Innovation Centre we are more concerned about creating great leaders, champions of change and critical thinkers so they can create more  young and energetic leaders. The first lot of the youth are getting special and intense training as leaders who will eventually become mentors and coaches for the younger youth enrolled in the centre. Each of them will recruit, mentor and help at least five younger ones with start up or incorporate them into existing teams. There is no better way to help change future leaders than by engaging those who have walked in their own shoes. Today I am a joyous and selfless young leader greatly because Dr. Robert Mwadime and other selfless leaders have invested their time in mentoring me. I am certain Dr. Mwadime and others who are still alive to see their fruits mature are the happiest people and can gracefully retire without regret. Not many of the young professionals have such opportunities these days. Seeing the positive change in the first lot of the youth in the centre, I like others who have visited the centre are more than certain the approach taken in the centre will surely create more social change champions and creative leaders!

column4: >How is the centre changing the world today?

column1: In October 2014, I used my savings to rent a house to host the centre. I and a colleague (Fred) started using our evenings and weekends to mentor the youth on key technical and soft skills. As result they have developed business and social ideas among which is the Promoting Local Nutrition Solutions which won the second Amplify Challenge in OpenIDEO.  Other ideas being prototyped include CityBorn project, Mushroom project, Nutrition Business Process Outsourcing for hospitals, Nutrition Studio and Sustainable School feeding project (See the image below). Seeing these youth progressing professionally and socially through increased self confidence, self-esteem, creativity and other soft skills that they did not get in University and the continued requests by others still in university and other unemployed graduates confirms the centre is worth more and will contribute to addressing global social change challenges. While others are mainly focusing on creating jobs for the youth, we are concerned about imparting the ideology of social change and unique leadership to our young youth so they grow to help others to help more communities. These youth and the centre are indeed destined to change the world one step at a time.

column1: <span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
<blockquote>

column5: >I am a volunteer mentor, a social entrepreneur and a chief dream seller  to the youth in the Innovation Centre but I work in an NGO. For the past one year I have spent my free time online communities of social entrepreneurs such as OpenIDEO to design ideas to help the smart unemployed youth in Uganda who look up to me for mentorship.
column6:
> I prefer to call myself a dreamer who dreams his pictures at night and paints them early in the morning. I am so passionate about creating empowered and critical thinking young leaders that I spend most of my spare time reaching out to them. I am always prepared to volunteer and listen to a young person so as to understand better their dreams and hopes. I believe to change the world and make it better for all, we need to create a generation of passionate leaders with a big heart for people.
When I joined University

column1: to study Human Nutrition in Tanzania in 2003, I was not sure where I would get a
job in this field. In August 2003 during holidays, I attended Uganda Nutrition
Action for Nutrition (UGAN) meeting in Kampala where Dr. Robert Mwadime delivered a key note address.
<blockquote>
<span style=""color: rgb(119, 119, 119)
column5: >y all means he made  me realize there is light at the end of my University studies. I approached him and asked him to mentor me.He did not reject and has continued holding my hands till today. I got my first job through him and are currently where I am because of his sacrifices. Unlike me today  about 20% of nutritionists who make it through universities get employed in Uganda. With high University admissions for nutrition, getting mentors for each student is impossible. I know of several unemployed professionals with substantial experience gained from the street who can make good mentors but lack the necessary leadership and attitude. I am leading this campaign because I want these great young men and women to take the button from me and reach out to other younger future leaders and champions of change. Today I call upon all of you irrespective of where you are to rally behind these youth and help change the leadership, mentorship and business landscape for young people in Uganda. You will forever feel you shared what you have to keep the dreams of these young people alive.

column1: <h4><span style=""color: rgb(119, 119, 119)
column3: >Read their live stories and how they making a difference already

column1: <div><span style=""color: rgb(119, 119, 119)
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column6: >                Michael Senyonjo, Knowledge and Design Manager

column1: <blockquote><span style=""background-color: initial

I have worked as a graphics designer but dropped the boss and went freelance after graduating a nutritionist and failing to get employed in the field for lack of experience. Along the way I met Jamiru, my classmate and close friend at university who introduced me to this group of young, motivated and determined colleagues at the Innovation Center. I

fitted in the team well and my best passion is that I get to put my graphics knowledge to use in health promotion, something I have always considered but was figuring out how. I am currently developing the Nutrition Studio, a media project highly based on nutrition and health concepts affecting most of us and our relatives. This is an awesome opportunity and a fun place to be as I am sharing my design expertise while getting mentored on more technical and soft skills.

column5: >Shakira Nabawanga, Operations Manager

column1: <blockquote>

column7: >I was working as an administrator before joining the centre having failed to get a job in my profession for over 2 years of searching. I thank all my colleagues whom I thought along with in creating this centre. I

column1: have always wanted to practice my profession but had no opportunity now with innovation centre am starting to realize my dream.

column5: >Josephine Murungi, Strategic Information Manager

column1: <div>
<blockquote>
I was frustrated with job hunting which I did
for almost a year and was home before I was invited to join the Innovation centre by a colleague, I had no idea about what I was to do but I had the passion and enthusiasm

like most youth. Now, I am being mentored and gaining skills in Monitoring and Evaluation and I am part of a team of youth that are creative and innovative. I feel every youth should have an opportunity to be part of this.

column3: >Life is a journey that everyone has to make. It comes with challenges, easy parts, lessons to learn and above all decisions to make. Joining the Innovation Center was a decision that has led me to achieving my dream of  creativity and realized the potential in me through the mentorship and guidance I get every single day. I would regret ever missing this opportunity. Before joining the centre I was seated home awaiting for internship opportunities in NGOs.

column6: >Ronald Kateregga, Clinical Nutritionist

column1: <blockquote>

The best feeling you can ever have in life is to earn a living from something you enjoy doing.Joining the Innovation Centre straight after University was a real blessing to me because it has been an opportunity for me to learn more life skills.Unlike most of the young people in this country, I have had a chance of being mentored and has been a great experience including making the most important decisions in my life.

column6: >Jamiru Mpiima, Program Coordinator

column1: <blockquote>
Before I joined the innovation center I was running a virtual mobile nutrition consultancy through a Facebook page. Getting together with other colleagues at the Innovation Centre
column2: we want to make a difference in the lives of other young nutritionists by holding their hands and showing them the way while we mine the nutrition gold in Uganda. Right now I am the programs coordinator at the center.

column6: >Sheila Nanyanyizi, Clinical Nutritionist

column1: <blockquote>
I joined the nutrition innovation Centre immediately after University, this invitation came at the time when all I  could do was to work as a seasonal research
assistant but now I feel I can do more especially in  Nutrition Business Process Outsourcing team which am learning from the  centre with Anna and Ronald.
<div>
<i style=""letter-spacing: 0px

Before joining Innovation Centre, I used to do research assistant jobs in different fields and a part time dietitian at Life link hospital. Joining the Innovation Center was like an opportunity for me  to blend my nutrition into other fields where it would work for me even better. Currently  I am working on a mushroom project at the centre where I have learnt how to grow mushrooms as an income generating enterprise. I am so happy to work with the energetic and creative young people like me.
<div><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
<div>

I had not yet graduated by the time my colleague invited to join the Innovation Centre. Joining this team was a dream come true because having been on a job search not so long, I was at the verge of taking up jobs that will enable me support and meet my needs irrespective of what they entailed. I feel this opportunity came at the right time when I still had the passion for nutrition.

Since my childhood, I have been in love with agriculture. This love for the economic backbone of Uganda continued through my education cycle having done agriculture as a subject from Senior One to University. Joining the Innovation Centre has created a platform for me to both mentor and get mentored in more skills other than
agriculture and this has been a great experience sharing knowledge as well as learning more every day. I am currently supporting the team in urban farming and sustainable school feeding program.
<h3><span style=""font-style: normal

column2: >I am excited seeing the current lot of the youth grow in technical and soft skills. My hope is to have this lot mentored as mentors for the upcoming new recruits so they can ably manage the centre and their peers with support of senior mentors and other great business people who have made it in areas the youth are incubating it. The model we are nurturing is simple: a mentor gets a mentee then mentee recruits a mentee and the chain of leadership continues. I would want to see each of the project grow, bring in income, employ more youth and directly impact urban and rural communities. The target is to have the first 30 youth in the Innovation Centre within the next 12 months. The support provided will help the team develop and finalize the Soft skills manual, get senior mentors to support and retain incubation space for the youth. On behalf of the team, I say thank you for your kind support.

column1: <div>
<ul>
","A mind of a graduate is a terrible thing to waste!

Please help us raise $ 7,431 to support these young graduates retain where they can converge to innovate life impacting ideas. The Innovation Center is a  business and leadership focused mentorship program to support fresh and young graduates realize their dreams and contribute to improving social, economic and health welfare of the society.

I am Alex Mokori, during the week I work as a Program Manager in an NGO in Uganda but during the last 12 months, I have spent most of my free time serving as a volunteer mentor and building a program to support  young graduates who want to pursue social entrepreneurship in Uganda.

I like many of you are fascinated about the prospect of raising fresh young and youthful leaders. Every time I remember the pain parents, guardians, friends or even donors go through in raising money to educate children hoping one day they will graduate to help them, their own siblings, communities, countries and the world at large, I forced to share the little I have to help. I am not yet a parent so I may not know exactly how painful it is to sacrifice everything you have to give your loved one education but I know what it feels like to have creative mind and dreams that you can't realize because you have no starting point or anyone to help you shape your dreams.

Picture the parents of these impoverished children living deep in Amuria district in Uganda sacrificing everything they got to educate their sons and daughters hoping one day they will save their village when after University. Do you know how much trauma those parents have when those children graduate to unemployment and eventually to alcoholism, HIV and accidents due to frustrations?

You my friends are changing the world of these fresh graduates, their families and generations to come. I am sure the Innovation Centre will forever groom creative young change agents and innovators who'll contribute to solving one of the most painful social challenges of the 21st century: increased low self esteem due to unemployment.
The world needs social change champions NOW

Social change champions and creative thinkers are in short supply today. Indeed the Global Nutrition Report 2014 called for  the recognition, supporting and expanding the number of national nutrition champions as one of the ten actions to accelerate the world's progress on nutrition.  At the Innovation Centre we are more concerned about creating great leaders, champions of change and critical thinkers so they can create more  young and energetic leaders. The first lot of the youth are getting special and intense training as leaders who will eventually become mentors and coaches for the younger youth enrolled in the centre. Each of them will recruit, mentor and help at least five younger ones with start up or incorporate them into existing teams. There is no better way to help change future leaders than by engaging those who have walked in their own shoes. Today I am a joyous and selfless young leader greatly because Dr. Robert Mwadime and other selfless leaders have invested their time in mentoring me. I am certain Dr. Mwadime and others who are still alive to see their fruits mature are the happiest people and can gracefully retire without regret. Not many of the young professionals have such opportunities these days. Seeing the positive change in the first lot of the youth in the centre, I like others who have visited the centre are more than certain the approach taken in the centre will surely create more social change champions and creative leaders!
...But there is a small challenge to address
The rent for meeting and working space for the youth runs
out in two months
column2: the team lacks soft-and technical skills manuals and senior mentors to actively and continuously help them. The team is seeking your support  so they can retain the working space. With $ 5,000 the centre will have rent for the next 12 months. An additional  $ 4,000 will see the team successfully launch the technical and soft skills  training program, reach out to at least 30 other smart, educated and unemployed youth, create employment for others while positively changing lives of many other people in different communities in Uganda. Through this initial support, the youth expect to create business projects which will sustain the centre with minimum or no reliance on donation.

column1: When you help the centre stay alive, you will:
Join other global selfless people who have chosen to be dream makers, heroes and someone
who is allowing emerging creative talents to change Uganda for decades to come.

To keep you reminded of your heroic contribution to the world, the youth will provide you  beautiful  Ugandan art pieces, t-shirts, certificates, personalised thank you messages and links to the centre's progress. Our highest contributors will receive specially produced video of the unique features and people that make Uganda the Pearl of Africa.  See the designs below:
Sticker
T-shirt
Video
How did it start?
Like other NGO employees, I am
constantly approached by young graduates for employment. I wish I could give

them the jobs but I don’t where they can buy the required experience. In June-September 2014,  I started evening and weekend meetings with 15 youth who had graduated two years ago but did not have jobs. The goal of the meetings was to catalyze thoughts on how best these youth could pool own knowledge and skills to generate income through viable ideas such as nutrition process business outsourcing for hospitals, urban farming, design and development of creative communication materials and and  other social change enterprises. The youth agreed to start an innovation centre. In 2014 while doing an online course-How to change the World, prof. Michael B. Roth shared the upcoming youth employment challenge by Clinton Global Initiative and OpenIDEO, I submitted the idea to the platform and it won the challenge.
How is the centre changing the world today?

In October 2014, I used my savings to rent a house to host the centre. I and a colleague (Fred) started using our evenings and weekends to mentor the youth on key technical and soft skills. As result they have developed business and social ideas among which is the Promoting Local Nutrition Solutions which won the second Amplify Challenge in OpenIDEO.  Other ideas being prototyped include CityBorn project, Mushroom project, Nutrition Business Process Outsourcing for hospitals, Nutrition Studio and Sustainable School feeding project (See the image below). Seeing these youth progressing professionally and socially through increased self confidence, self-esteem, creativity and other soft skills that they did not get in University and the continued requests by others still in university and other unemployed graduates confirms the centre is worth more and will contribute to addressing global social change challenges. While others are mainly focusing on creating jobs for the youth, we are concerned about imparting the ideology of social change and unique leadership to our young youth so they grow to help others to help more communities. These youth and the centre are indeed destined to change the world one step at a time.
What social and economic challenges is the centre solving?
Uganda
has the world’s highest population of young people under 30 years — 78 percent.
The country also boasts of the high youth unemployment in Africa at 62 — 83
percent. It is estimated
40,000 graduates are passed out of Ugandan universities each year, but only
8,000 or 20 percent get jobs.
International Labour Organization blames
unemployment of graduates on the mismatch between the skills the graduates get with what the market demands.
Lack of guidance at home and university,
absence of role models and mentors for inspiration and guidance
self-confidence and other soft skills make today’s youth more
vulnerable in spite of acquiring lots of technical skills.

This is where the Innovation Centre comes in. The youth will recruit younger youth who are in vocational institutes and Universities into the leadership and mentorship program where they will receive training on soft skills for a year. As they undergo training on soft skills and social change mentorship, they also receive support to nurture social change and business ideas so that by the time they complete studies they can launch their start-ups.

Each viable idea will have its own team members with a leader who will run it as an independent project with direct benefit to the community. Because employers, business companies, teaching institutions, development partners and youth will work as partners, the centre will continue transforming dreams of the youth into highly demanded solutions to community needs.
What risks are we anticipating?
The young graduates could get frustrated because the ideas are not translating into direct social and economic impact within a short period of time
The companies and NGOs we anticipate partnering with to provide more hands on experience for the recruited youth in the centre could fail to take them up and provide guided mentorship
The centre may become too small for the youth within two years yet the rent within the central district is too expensive to afford
Non-response from senior mentors to support the youth in the centre due to the centre's inability to financially compensate them for their time
Our greatest fear is not the failure to mentor the youth but ensuring their start-ups succeed and create social change impact.
How else can you help US?

Any help in form of partnerships, gifts in kind, technical materials, design support, online mentorship and connections to those who believe in our dream. Some times the smallest of the actions matter most.

Mentoring on how to be an independent consultant to NGOs, how to develop expertise that can be packaged into a training to generate income, how to do focus groups so they can contract with organizations, how to conduct ideation sessions so they can sell those services to others, etc
Pick any of the current ideas and link to companies, customers and other stakeholders who can help the youth through buying the products or services.
Spread the word: Share Innovation Centre on Facebook and Twitter, tell your friends and work mates in an email or through word of mouth
Stay connected: Follow the Innovation Centre on Facebook and Twitter, then share our top updates with your friends
Post our campaign: If you love our campaign, use this as your profile picture on your facebook, twitter, google+, instagram, whatapp and other social media networks until the campaign ends
Place the announcement on radio or television: Help us direct more audience to the campaign through your radio, newspaper, magazine or other print media.
Why am I doing this?
Alex Mokori, volunteer youth mentor

I am a volunteer mentor, a social entrepreneur and a chief dream seller  to the youth in the Innovation Centre but I work in an NGO. For the past one year I have spent my free time online communities of social entrepreneurs such as OpenIDEO to design  ideas to help the smart unemployed youth in Uganda who look up to me for mentorship. I prefer to call myself a dreamer who dreams his pictures at night and paints them early in the morning. I am so passionate about creating empowered and critical thinking young leaders that I spend most of my spare time reaching out to them. I am always prepared to volunteer and listen to a young person so as to understand better their dreams and hopes. I believe to change the world and make it better for all, we need to create a generation of passionate leaders with a big heart for people.When I joined University
to study Human Nutrition in Tanzania in 2003, I was not sure where I would get a
job in this field. In August 2003 during holidays, I attended Uganda Nutrition
Action for Nutrition (UGAN) meeting in Kampala where Dr. Robert Mwadime delivered a key note address.

By all means he made  me realize there is light at the end of my University studies. I approached him and asked him to mentor me.He did not reject and has continued holding my hands till today. I got my first job through him and are currently where I am because of his sacrifices. Unlike me today  about 20% of nutritionists who make it through universities get employed in Uganda. With high University admissions for nutrition, getting mentors for each student is impossible. I know of several unemployed professionals with substantial experience gained from the street who can make good mentors but lack the necessary leadership and attitude. I am leading this campaign because I want these great young men and women to take the button from me and reach out to other younger future leaders and champions of change. Today I call upon all of you irrespective of where you are to rally behind these youth and help change the leadership, mentorship and business landscape for young people in Uganda. You will forever feel you shared what you have to keep the dreams of these young people alive.
Read their live stories and how they making a difference already
Michael Senyonjo, Knowledge and Design Manager

I have worked as a graphics designer but dropped the boss and went freelance after graduating a nutritionist and failing to get employed in the field for lack of experience. Along the way I met Jamiru, my classmate and close friend at university who introduced me to this group of young, motivated and determined colleagues at the Innovation Center. I

fitted in the team well and my best passion is that I get to put my graphics knowledge to use in health promotion, something I have always considered but was figuring out how. I am currently developing the Nutrition Studio, a media project highly based on nutrition and health concepts affecting most of us and our relatives. This is an awesome opportunity and a fun place to be as I am sharing my design expertise while getting mentored on more technical and soft skills.
Shakira Nabawanga, Operations Manager

I was working as an administrator before joining the centre having failed to get a job in my profession for over 2 years of searching. I thank all my colleagues whom I thought along with in creating this centre. I
have always wanted to practice my profession but had no opportunity now with innovation centre am starting to realize my dream.
Josephine Murungi, Strategic Information Manager
I was frustrated with job hunting which I did
for almost a year and was home before I was invited to join the Innovation centre by a colleague, I had no idea about what I was to do but I had the passion and enthusiasm

like most youth. Now, I am being mentored and gaining skills in Monitoring and Evaluation and I am part of a team of youth that are creative and innovative. I feel every youth should have an opportunity to be part of this.
Racheal Natumanya, Community Nutritionist

Life is a journey that everyone has to make. It comes with challenges, easy parts, lessons to learn and above all decisions to make. Joining the Innovation Center was a decision that has led me to achieving my dream of  creativity and realized the potential in me through the mentorship and guidance I get every single day. I would regret ever missing this opportunity. Before joining the centre I was seated home awaiting for internship opportunities in NGOs.
Ronald Kateregga, Clinical Nutritionist

The best feeling you can ever have in life is to earn a living from something you enjoy doing.Joining the Innovation Centre straight after University was a real blessing to me because it has been an opportunity for me to learn more life skills.Unlike most of the young people in this country, I have had a chance of being mentored and has been a great experience including making the most important decisions in my life.
Jamiru Mpiima, Program Coordinator
Before I joined the innovation center I was running a virtual mobile nutrition consultancy through a Facebook page. Getting together with other colleagues at the Innovation Centre
column2: we want to make a difference in the lives of other young nutritionists by holding their hands and showing them the way while we mine the nutrition gold in Uganda. Right now I am the programs coordinator at the center.

column1: Sheila Nanyanyizi, Clinical Nutritionist
I joined the nutrition innovation Centre immediately after University, this invitation came at the time when all I  could do was to work as a seasonal research
assistant but now I feel I can do more especially in  Nutrition Business Process Outsourcing team which am learning from the  centre with Anna and Ronald.
Afra Kampere, Economic Strengthening projects

Before joining Innovation Centre, I used to do research assistant jobs in different fields and a part time dietitian at Life link hospital. Joining the Innovation Center was like an opportunity for me  to blend my nutrition into other fields where it would work for me even better. Currently  I am working on a mushroom project at the centre where I have learnt how to grow mushrooms as an income generating enterprise. I am so happy to work with the energetic and creative young people like me.
Anna Nyadoi, Clinical Nutritionist

I had not yet graduated by the time my colleague invited to join the Innovation Centre. Joining this team was a dream come true because having been on a job search not so long, I was at the verge of taking up jobs that will enable me support and meet my needs irrespective of what they entailed. I feel this opportunity came at the right time when I still had the passion for nutrition.
Brian Kibirige, Horticulturalist

Since my childhood, I have been in love with agriculture. This love for the economic backbone of Uganda continued through my education cycle having done agriculture as a subject from Senior One to University. Joining the Innovation Centre has created a platform for me to both mentor and get mentored in more skills other than
agriculture and this has been a great experience sharing knowledge as well as learning more every day. I am currently supporting the team in urban farming and sustainable school feeding program.
Conclusion and next steps

I am excited seeing the current lot of the youth grow in technical and soft skills. My hope is to have this lot mentored as mentors for the upcoming new recruits so they can ably manage the centre and their peers with support of senior mentors and other great business people who have made it in areas the youth are incubating it. The model we are nurturing is simple: a mentor gets a mentee then mentee recruits a mentee and the chain of leadership continues. I would want to see each of the project grow, bring in income, employ more youth and directly impact urban and rural communities. The target is to have the first 30 youth in the Innovation Centre within the next 12 months. The support provided will help the team develop and finalize the Soft skills manual, get senior mentors to support and retain incubation space for the youth. On behalf of the team, I say thank you for your kind support.",24.0,0,"1 Campaign

column2: >“Our vision is to make Spring Dales Public School one of the finest so our children can receive quality education right at their doorstep, without facing emotional separation from their parents and their village.""

column1: Where is Spring Dales Public School?

Spring Dales Public School (SDPS) is located in the village of Mulbekh which is located in the Himalayan area of Ladakh (""land of high passes"")- in the state of Jammu and Kashmir in northwestern India. Mulbekh is a treacherous seven hour drive from the state capital of Leh.
What are the challenges to education in Ladakh?
column2: >In 2010, we (Martin and Kate) were fortunate to establish a close relationship and collaboration with Mr. Tsewang Norboo, the Principal of Spring Dales Public School (SDPS). In his small village of Mulbekh we heard him speak passionately about the unique culture, language and identities of a traditional Tibetan Buddhist society that is struggling to educate their children in this harshly remote Himalayan region.
column3: >The more Principal Norboo explained his community's deep concern that the exodus of young people being educated elsewhere is threatening the future of their community, the more we felt compelled to lend our skills to the community in any way they needed.
column5: >Please take a few moments to watch these brief clips that effectively highlight the significant challenges to remote traditional Tibetan Buddhist societies, like Mulbekh, and the effects of children being educated so far away from their families and communities (Zanskar valley is close to the Mulbekh valley):
column8:

column2: >Original trailer for a film called Journey from Zanskar (Warrior Films, 2010)
>What is the community's solution?
column3: >The Mulbekh community has an ambitious and bold solution to lower the exodus of young people from their remote region.
column4: >Providing equal access to quality, local education means the region's children and youth don't have to leave their parents, siblings, grandparents, families and communities for larger centres elsewhere in India. By slowing this mass exodus, and by providing a school curriculum that emphasizes a blend of traditional and modern education, the sharing of knowledge between generations is able to flourish.  All of this directly supports the revitalization and vitality of the unique Ladakhi culture, traditions, language, Buddhist faith, local economies, and identities.
column5: >Building a quality school campus (including student accommodation) for the region will attract more students to be educated locally. This will dramatically slow the region's exodus of young people to larger centres, and will also attract quality, permanent teachers, thus lowering the high teacher turnover, while increasing stability for the students.
column6: >Given the harsh climate - where temperatures can rise to 30+ degrees celsius in the summer and drop to -30 in the winter with no heating system - passive solar and rammed earth technologies were chosen as they use local materials and provide unprecedented year-round comfort. Students will no longer have to take their classes sitting outside on the ground in the winter (inside is too frigid to hold a pencil)!
column7:
>
The old classrooms are so cold and dark that classes are often taught outside in the colder months.
column9: >SDPS Class 10 student being recognized for academic achievement with her classmates looking on. Assemblies are held outside in the colder months as indoors is too cold.

column13: >This summer we would like to start construction - foundations only - of the next building!  Once completed the new Computer and Science Laboratory building will accommodate four classrooms - Computers, Biology, Chemistry, Physics. As with the previous two buildings, this new building is entirely based on the use of passive-solar energy and uses primarily local resources.  Enhanced traditional techniques - such as rammed-earth walls, clay roofing, wooden window decorations in the ancient Ladakhi style - are used.

column22: >What does your support mean to the community?
column23: >Providing quality, local education means the region's children and youth don't have to leave their parents, grandparents, families and communities for larger centres elsewhere in India. Slowing this mass exodus of children encourages the sharing of knowledge between the generations, directly supporting the revitalization of the unique Ladakhi culture, traditions, language, Buddhist faith, local economies, and identities. Spring Dales Public School emphasizes all these important pieces in their curriculum and daily activities.
column27: >Your support will mean that the Computer and Science Laboratory building is the next step in the completion of the region's premier school campus. Improved scientific and technological knowledge and skills means the students won't have to leave their communities for quality education, and will have more options for their personal and professional development in the future.
column28: >Importantly, a quality and well-equipped computer and science lab building will also help the school to stay in operations after Spring 2019, when the next government inspection is scheduled for permitting.
column29: >It is difficult to explain how much each action of support means to this community. Their gratitude is immense, expressive and so heartwarming!
column30: >What do you get for your generous support?
column31:
>Satisfaction 
You will get the satisfaction of directly supporting a meaningful project in one of the most unique areas of the world.
column32:
