column7: or just by simply telling your friends about us and getting the word out.

column1: ","We are a group of students from the Law & Paralegal Studies Club in City Tech, and we really need your help to raise a $1,000 to help City Tech's legal students visit the U.S. Supreme Court in Washington D.C. and witness a hearing in our country's highest court.
Petitioner: The Law and Paralegal Studies Club (""the club"") at  New York City College of Technology.
Procedural History: The Law & Paralegal Studies Club (""the club"") has made their trip to Washington D.C. an annual tradition since 2008.
Issue: Due to the club's limited funding, the total cost of the trip is expensive, an each student would have to pay $200--an amount that many of our students simply do not have.

Analysis: Legal students are required to read and analyze U.S. Supreme Court cases on a regular basis, but the majority of our students might never get to witness one of these cases in real life. We believe that our students will be encouraged to continue their legal goals through this trip--the same way artists get inspired in the Louvre. Our students are very excited about the trip, they all have worked very hard in their legal classes and deserve an opportunity to learn how our court system works...

We have created a budget for our trip, and the cost amounts to nearly $8,000 for 20 students. City Tech, a public CUNY college, granted the club $3,600. If we were to charge $200 per student, we would only have a $500 deficit
column2: however, we are aware that due to the low wages and high cost of living in New York City, the trip will be a financial burden for many of our students. As a club, we are trying different fund-raising methods to alleviate the cost of the trip for the students. Our club members are currently participating in various fundraising activities to help reduce the cost of the trip, such as food sales and bake sales (we are known for our empandas!)
column3: however, our food-sales do not produce a lot of money. We need your help:By generously donating to our Washington D.C. campaign, you will help:

column1: Reduce the cost of the trip from $200 to $100 per student
help pay their travel expenses and accommodations for three days and two nights (Amtrak alone is $3,200!)
Pay two group dinners for our students

We want all our friends and family to know that all funds will be use to pay travel and accommodations--our priority--even if we do not reach the $1,000 goal. If we do reach our goal, the proceeds from our food sales will pay two group dinners for our students.We want to assure you that the club is working hard to raise money for the trip, and not just solely relying on the work of others. We had food sales and bake sales every other week, and we have one more to go on March 31st. Check out some our successful food sales and bake sales. Jean, our club's secretary serving Spanish food.Students and professors stayed up all night cooking delcious food. Our St. Patrick's Bake Sale.

The St. Patrick's bake sale/food sale was a success.If  you can't donate right now, you could always support us by telling your friends about our campaign to get to Washington D.C. Sharing this page through different networking platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, or via email is extremely helpful
column2: or just by simply telling your friends about us and getting the word out.",10.0,1,"1 Campaign

Short Summary
PeaceJam is a global organization that provides a platform for Nobel Peace Prize Laureates to mentor youth that want to change the world. This is done through regional conferences.

Our club is made up of underprivileged and refugee youth from around the world. They are a very passionate about this club but will not be able to afford to go to this inspirational conference without your help!
Our conference will cost just over $4500.
For every $230 we raise, another student will be able to attend the conference that otherwise wouldn't have had the opportunity.
What We Need &
Below is the extensive breakdown of where fundraising money will go.
Just below that is the simple math used for this fundraiser.
Registration is $90 per student and $120 per Chaperone
We hope to bring 17 students and 3 chaperones
We need to rent three 7 passenger vans at $265 each,
Gas will cost about $74 per fill up. We will need 6 fill ups to total $444.
Hotel rooms run at about $100 per night. We need 6 rooms for 2 nights each totaling $1200
All food is included either by Winooski High School or the PeaceJam conference. We only need to provide one meal on the way home. This will be $10 per person which comes out to $170
90 x 17 students = $1,530
120 x 3 advisors =  $   360
100 x 6 rooms =     $1,200 for two nights
74 x 6 gas stops =  $   444
10 x 17 food stop = $   170
FOR THOSE WHO DONATE....
$5 - a thank you note signed by all of this year's PeaceJam group
$10 - a picture of this year's club with a thank you note written by one of our members
$20 - an email containing a video of our club thanking you, by name, for your support
Limited!!!

For the first 10 people that donate $50+ will receive all of the above and be listed in our culturally inclusive calendars as an outstanding supporter.

The Impact

This conference is so important to club members! This will be the first experience many of the students have networking and collaborating with peers that share their passion.

The club has been able to attend in the past and when they did it was a life changing experience! They came back more inspired than ever. It was the first time they realized that their efforts truly can make a difference. They saw that there were other teens that believed as deeply as we do that the world can be more peaceful if we work hard!
Risks &
column2:
Challenges

The conference is in March. We hope to have the money raised through our various fundraisers but we understand that success is not guaranteed. If we do not make it this year all funds raised will be saved for next year's conference.

column1:
Other Ways You Can Help

The power of social media can be just as helpful as a dollar.
Whether or not you can afford to donate please post this to your social media pages! The more people that can see this and donate, the less we will need from each individual sponsor.
Thank you so much for your support!

Ourselves, our ideas and our goal.

For a long time, I, Mark, have wished to channel my expertise
into an endeavour close to my heart.  I
am an electronics engineer of over 25 years experience and for some time now have
had the desire to unite my hobby with my profession.  Hence my choice of company name.
With the aid of a small, skilled and dedicated team, and the aid of indiegogo
contributors, I believe now is the right time to follow my passion.
Unity Hifi was born from a genuine love of music.  Not just the form itself but also from the
experience of hearing a faithful reproduction, the perfections and the
imperfections that are seldom captured and presented as intended in an
increasingly digital era.
At Unity, our philosophy is to preserve that pleasure, to embrace the
technologies of yesteryear yet pair them with our experience, both as engineers
and innovators.  So that we can create a
piece of equipment that reproduces all the purity and presence to an absolute
audiophile quality, yet is driven with the precision and efficiency of

engineered design, and styled to suit, both audibly and visually.

---

Your pledge, our promise.

""To deliver a high-end piece of equipment that compliments any hifi system"".

A prototype of our phono-stage pre-amp is in the final stages of development and we have reached the point where we are looking for funding to aid with manufacturing, marketing and development of this and further projects in the future.


Pledge to us and you will be not only be supporting a traditional UK based company, using UK made components
column2:
You will be fostering electronic engineering and craftsmanship, and most importantly, nurturing further employment opportunities.

Not only that but some of the pledges will get the opportunity to own a high-grade piece of audio equipment that is comparable to much more expensive items in it's class
column3:
perhaps of particular interest to hobbyists and collectors is the fact that such an item will be a rare item, and an investment in itself.

Full funding is our ultimate aim, however we are prepared to scale our production as per the funds we receive, as this is as much a labour of love as it is a financial enterprise.

This is a pledge to a project for any lover of music, for some it will be an affordable audiophile solution, recreating the refined sound they are accustomed too
column4:
for others it will open up a whole new experience of listening pleasure.

""Ultimately with your aid we will craft a piece of equipment that encompasses a rich, quality sound, intelligent engineering and a unique styling
column5:
all at a disruptive price-point.

Thank you from all us of at Unity"".

","Ourselves, our ideas and our goal.For a long time, I, Mark, have wished to channel my expertise

column1: into an endeavour close to my heart.  I
am an electronics engineer of over 25 years experience and for some time now have
had the desire to unite my hobby with my profession.  Hence my choice of company name.
With the aid of a small, skilled and dedicated team, and the aid of indiegogo
contributors, I believe now is the right time to follow my passion.
Unity Hifi was born from a genuine love of music.  Not just the form itself but also from the
experience of hearing a faithful reproduction, the perfections and the
imperfections that are seldom captured and presented as intended in an
increasingly digital era.
At Unity, our philosophy is to preserve that pleasure, to embrace the
technologies of yesteryear yet pair them with our experience, both as engineers
and innovators.  So that we can create a
piece of equipment that reproduces all the purity and presence to an absolute
audiophile quality, yet is driven with the precision and efficiency of

----Englisch Version below----

Worum
geht es in diesem Projekt?
Es
handelt sich um einen Comic, bei dem Zeichner und Autorin gemeinsam
mit jungen Lesern die Geschichte zweier jüdischer Mädchen in
Deutschland erzählen.
Sie
heißen Hanna und Rozsika und waren die Großtanten der Illustratorin
Inbal Leitner und der Berliner jüdischen
Kantorin und Sängerin Avitall Gerstetter. Sie beschreibt das Leben
der beiden, wie es war, bevor es in Auschwitz ein zu frühes Ende
fand. Illustriert wird es von Tobi
Dahmen.
Damit
beginnt der Comic und liefert so die Basis, auf der die Geschichte
von Hanna und Rozsika weiter erzählt werden kann. Daran sollen sich
die jungen Leser beteiligen, indem sie sich überlegen, wie das Leben
der beiden hätte aussehen können, wenn sie nicht umgebracht worden
wären. Sie können ihrer Einbildungskraft dabei freien Lauf lassen,
ausmalen und ausspinnen, wie es ihnen in den Sinn kommt, auch
über andere Opfer der Shoah recherchieren und sie in die Geschichte
einbinden. In einem Blog werden ihre Ideen gesammelt und dann bei der
Fortführung des Comics umgesetzt.
So
wird in einem interaktiven künstlerischen Prozess zerstörtes Leben
dem Vergessen entrissen, wieder wachgerufen und fiktiv weitergeführt.
Die Beteiligten schaffen ihm auf diese Weise einen Platz in ihren
Gefühlen und Gedanken. Mit ihrer Fantasie stehen sie auf gegen die
Dumpfheit von Zerstörung und Gewalt und erheben einen Protest des
Lebens gegen den Tod.
Ziele
und Zielgruppe
Der
Comic soll einen Beitrag zu einer neuen Form der Gedenkkultur
leisten, die junge Menschen einbezieht. Seine Hauptfiguren sind ihnen
durch ihr Alter nah. Deshalb fällt es ihnen leicht, sich in sie
hineinzuversetzen. Und da auch sie noch den Großteil ihres Lebens
vor sich haben und darüber nachdenken, wie es einmal aussehen wird,
können sie sich gut Gedanken über das Leben der Figuren machen.
Durch die Beschäftigung damit bekommen sie ein Gefühl für den
Verlust, der durch den Tod dieser Menschen entstanden ist und werden
sensibilisiert für ähnliche Vorgänge und ein gesellschaftliches
Engagement, das dagegen auftritt.
Der
Comic, vor allem die Mitarbeit daran, ist vorrangig für Mädchen und
Jungen ab 12 Jahren gedacht.
Grundlegend richtet er sich aber an alle, die dieses Medium mögen,
auch an jene, die es in der Kinder- und Jugendarbeit einsetzen wollen

wie Lehrer, Erzieher und Sozialarbeiter.

Der Comic soll weltweit in den Sprachen Deutsch und Englisch erscheinen.
Warum sollte jemand dieses Projekt unterstützen?
Es
ist ein Erinnerungsprojekt
für die Zukunft, denn es vereint
die Nachkommen der Opfer und der Täter in ihrem Bemühen, der
vergangenen Schrecken zu gedenken und sich für eine lebenswerte Welt
einzusetzen. Die Verantwortung dafür tragen wir gemeinsam.
Was passiert mit dem Geld bei erfolgreicher Finanzierung?
Mit
dem Geld soll die Finanzierung ermöglicht werden für:

<span style=""background-color: initial
Wer steht hinter dem Projekt?
<b>Avitall
Gerstetter,
studierte Gesang und Klarinette an der Universität der Künste
(Berlin) und Englisch an der Technischen Universität (Berlin). In
New York wurde sie zur Kantorin ausgebildet. Die erste jüdische
Kantorin in Deutschland (tätig
an der Berliner Synagoge in der Oranienburger Straße)
ist
auch als Sängerin und Musikerin aktiv. Sie schreibt Songs, die
jüdische Tradition mit modernen Musikstilen verbinden, arbeitet mit
internationalen Musikern wie Dominic Miller, dem Gitarristen von
Sting, zusammen und gibt in Deutschland, England, Italien und den USA
Konzerte. Daneben initiiert sie Projekte interreligiöser
Verständigung.
Tobi
Dahmen,
studierte Visuelle
Kommunikation an der Fachhochschule Düsseldorf mit Schwerpunkt

Illustration. Neben Arbeiten für Presse und Werbung illustriert der in Utrecht lebende Künstler Kinder- und Jugendbücher und kreiert Cartoons, Comics und Graphic Novels. Für „Sperrbezirk“ erhielt er 2007 den ICOM Independent Comic Preis in der Kategorie realistischer Kurzcomic.


----Englisch Version ----

What is this project about?

It’s about a comic, where illustrator and author together with young readers and writers tell the story about a Jewish girl in Nazi Germany.

The girl is called Rozsika. She was the great aunt of Berlin’s Jewish cantor and singer Avitall Gerstetter. The comic starts with Avitall’s description of Rozsika’s life up to the day of her fatal death in Auschwitz. Rozsika’s story will be continued to be told. Young readers become part of the story by thinking about what Rozsika’s life could have been like, hadn’t she been murdered. The young authors are free to use all their imagination and to do research on other victims of the Shoah they would like to involve in their personal stories. The idea is to collect all ideas in a blog and print the best stories in the next editions. The aim of this process is to revive destroyed lives through interactive creative writing, making them become fictionally alive. The writers give these people a place in their thoughts and share their feelings. By using their phantasy, the young authors stand up against stupidity of destruction and violence.
column5:
>

This comic is a contribution to a new way of remembrance-culture, inviting young people to be part of the victim’s stories. The main character is about the same age, which makes it easy for them to share their feelings and thoughts. They have in common, that they too have the greatest part of their lives still in front of them and they can share dreams and thoughts well when invited to think about what the character’s futures might have looked like and what it means to lose someone you love in such a dreadful way. It makes them more sensitive for similar situations and social engagement against such political and social developments.
column9:
>Target group

This comic is a contribution to a new way of remembrance-culture, inviting young people to be part of the victim’s stories. The main character is about the same age, which makes it easy for them to share their feelings and thoughts. They have in common, that they too have the greatest part of their lives still in front of them and they can share dreams and thoughts well when invited to think about what the character’s futures might have looked like and what it means to lose someone you love in such a dreadful way. It makes them more sensitive for similar situations and social engagement against such political and social developments.

Not only boys and girls from the age of 12 are invited to write the continuation of the story, but also teachers and people who work with children and the Youth are very welcome to get their students involved.

The comic will be published in German and English.

Why should anyone support this project?

It’s a remembrance-project for our future, where descendants of the Shoah victims and descendants of the perpetrators both try to remember the dreadful history and stand up for a world worth to be living in. Both sides are responsible for a safe future.

What will be financed with the money?

The money will be spend on:

column1: • illustrations by a professional illustrator
• editorial report
• printing of the comic
• translation of the comic into English
• travel expenses

Who stands behind the project?

Avitall Gerstetter
column3:
>studied voice, the piano and the clarinet at the University of the Arts (UdK Berlin) and English at the Technical University (TU Berlin). She was ordained as a cantor in New York in 2001. Avitall is Germany’s premier Jewish female cantor (Synagogue Oranienburger Strasse Berlin). She is a singer and a songwriter (German, English, Hebrew and Yiddish). Avitall combines Jewish tradition with modern arrangements. She has been working with international musicians like Dominic Miller (Sting’s guitarist) and gives concerts throughout the world. In addition, she has been initiating interfaith projects.

Hi! We are students at Bethany College in Lindsborg, Kansas. Our names are Aaron, Kaylie, Luke, and Jacob. Together we make up the Outdoor Ministry Curriculum class. This class is run in partnership with camp Tomah Shinga, in Junction City, Kansas. As a class, we have made it our goal to send 20 kids to camp this summer.

By supporting this campaign, you will be providing youth with the experience of a lifetime. Our goal is to raise $7,000 to be able to send 20 youth to camp. Check out our awesome perks that you will receive when you support us.

• Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
• Like Tomah Shinga on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and Instagram @tomahshinga

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div> <blockquote>
The biggest problem facing today's saxophone isn't the horns being made today.  It's not the reeds.  It's not the mouthpieces.  It's not the big box retailers or even the cranky repairers.
It's INFORMATION.

The real knowledge about how the saxophone works, how best to care for it, how to evaluate one for purchase, how they are made, and how to repair them is sequestered and locked away in the heads of a smaller and smaller number of people.  Meanwhile, the amount of bogus information- fed by economic incentives to sow and grow bullshit- spreads, obscuring the good stuff and making it an epic task to separate the chaff from the truth.  We live in a world with more saxophonists than ever before, and more choices in gear than ever before, but the knowledge hasn't grown and taken hold the same way.  The result is that we are awash in a sea of mediocrity, and good products and services compete with bad ones on a playing field skewed in favor of ignorance.
<div>

The solution?  Take all of the information that has typically had a high price and is hard to find - everything there is in a top-level saxophone repairman's head - and make it free.  Open.  Give it to anyone who takes the time to learn it, let it propagate, and let's start to level the playing field.
And I'm working on it- and have been for years.  But the thing that is in short supply is more time.  And that's where you come in.
<div>
<div>
Hi, my name is Matt Stohrer and I repair saxophones for a living.  And I want to tell you everything I know.

I love the saxophone, and I especially love helping other people have the best saxophone experience they possibly can.  I spend my free time writing articles and making videos to help saxophonists understand their instrument.  Articles such as The Unprofitable Valley, Understanding Key Fitting: Hinge Tube and Post Facing, Conn 6M ""transitional"" Saxophones,  The Tool Set For Beginning In Saxophone Repair, and over 40 more.  Videos like the Quik 'n Easy Leak Detector, Repairman's Overview: C-melody Saxophones, Saxophone Repair Topic: Buescher Snap-On Resonators, King Super 20 Saxophones, The Best Saxophone Pads, and over 60 more.

But all of this is just a start.  I want to go so much farther - to put online an entire library of articles and videos that cover every aspect of saxophone repair, vintage saxophones, buying used saxophones, and even eventually to build a saxophone myself and share everything I learn along the way including tools, measurements, and CAD drawings so that anyone with too much time on their hands could build one themselves.

Of course, this information will likely be useful to you individually.  But it also has a chance to really change things on a larger scale.  Because if this information was easily accessible to consumers, the knowledge gap between consumers and those that sell, repair, or manufacture saxophones would shrink.  Consumers would have the ability to make more informed choices, directing the market towards true quality.   Instead of wondering about what you paid for in a repair or neglecting something necessary because you can't understand why it would need done, you'd be able to share a common language with the repairer and make an informed decision that would make both of you happier with the transaction.  Instead of being surprised months after buying a vintage horn finding out that the neck has seen major repairs in the past, you'd know what to look for and how to avoid the pitfalls of buying used, directing your purchase towards trustworthy and accurate listings.   And maybe, just maybe, when buying a new horn one day in the future, instead of choosing between 100 mediocre saxophones that are basically the same except for the color, you might get to choose between many high-quality saxophones that are fundamentally different in design- almost like walking into a music store in 1935.

This is why I have begun to build the Open Source Saxophone Project.  Currently in embryonic form, this will be a useful and informative hub of saxophone information, integrating everything I have already done and adding a lot more, making it a bedrock of free in-depth knowledge for anyone to see that is easy to read, understand, and all in one place.  It will be the first and most obvious stop on the internet for anyone wanting to learn about how saxophones work, closing the knowledge gap between those who make or sell them and those who buy them.  This will permanently change the way this industry works by giving the power back to you, the consumer- arming you with the tools and knowledge to make good decisions with regard to your saxophones, whether as a consumer buying a new one or as a professional repairer fixing up an old one.

So what's stopping me?  The answer is time.  I get paid for fixing horns, not spreading knowledge, and between my job and my family, my limited spare time means that my articles and videos are slow going, typically with one to two per month being made.  If I could temporarily replace my repair income and focus on writing and making videos for a chunk of time, I could get a dozen done in a week - maybe more.

So what I'm asking is for you to give me a paid vacation from my regular job so I can work on the Open Source Saxophone Project and turn it into a useful and informative hub of information integrating everything I have already done and adding a lot more, making it the first and most obvious stop on the internet for anyone wanting to learn about how saxophones work, a bedrock of free in-depth knowledge for anyone to see that permanently changes the way this industry works by giving the power back to you, the consumer.
So How Much Is Needed?

Well, I've got it figured that $1500 raised here will fund me fully for a week - including the fees assessed by Paypal and Indiegogo, as well as the cost of materials and supplies and ""perks"" to be given out to those who donate.  So my goal for this campaign is for two weeks: $3000,  though I will take anything I'm given, and work with whatever we can put together.  However if the amount is larger than the goal, I will take off more time and write and do much, much more.  After all, the desired end result of the Open Source Saxophone Project is to host enough content to enable a talented, motivated and persistent individual to build their own saxophone from scratch!  So there is a lot of room to grow, and a lot of time I can fill if given the opportunity.

What Can You Expect As A Donor?

    However much ""paid time off"" from my regular job of fixing saxophones that I can accrue through this campaign, I will put towards working full-time (probably a little more than full-time) on writing articles and making videos, which will be visible online on YouTube and on the Open Source Saxophone Project.
Currently, I am able to spend a few hours a month on this stuff.  If the goal of this project was met and I had two weeks off regular work, I could put in about 90 hours
column2: this would fast-forward my content creation by at about a year and bring the Open Source Saxophone Project to a place where at least most of the basics of saxophone repair - like how to overhaul a physically clean saxophone from start to finish including disassembly and cleaning, some dentwork, soldering, pad installation, pad seating, adjustment materials, and mechanical work such as swedging - were fully described and documented on video, so that repairers could have a well-documented point of view to add to their own and so that consumers could have an idea of what they should expect when they spend their money on an overhaul.

column1: I could also fill a lot of gaps in my Repairman's Overview videos and also get started doing videos/articles examining the basic concepts and definitions of saxophone repair - what does it mean when a horn is repadded?  What does relacquering really do?  How can you tell a relacquer from an original finish instrument?  How do you correctly install a pad?  What is key fitting?  How do you use a leak light correctly?  How should you go about selecting a saxophone to purchase? I could go on and on and on - and with your help, I will.
This project is based upon something I love: teaching people about the saxophone.  These articles and videos will get done eventually- it is my chosen mission.  You can just help it go a lot faster.
Because with a better educated consumer, there won't be room to be lazy anymore.
","The biggest problem facing today's saxophone isn't the horns being made today.  It's not the reeds.  It's not the mouthpieces.  It's not the big box retailers or even the cranky repairers.
It's INFORMATION.

The real knowledge about how the saxophone works, how best to care for it, how to evaluate one for purchase, how they are made, and how to repair them is sequestered and locked away in the heads of a smaller and smaller number of people.  Meanwhile, the amount of bogus information- fed by economic incentives to sow and grow bullshit- spreads, obscuring the good stuff and making it an epic task to separate the chaff from the truth.  We live in a world with more saxophonists than ever before, and more choices in gear than ever before, but the knowledge hasn't grown and taken hold the same way.  The result is that we are awash in a sea of mediocrity, and good products and services compete with bad ones on a playing field skewed in favor of ignorance.

The solution?  Take all of the information that has typically had a high price and is hard to find - everything there is in a top-level saxophone repairman's head - and make it free.  Open.  Give it to anyone who takes the time to learn it, let it propagate, and let's start to level the playing field.
And I'm working on it- and have been for years.  But the thing that is in short supply is more time.  And that's where you come in.
Hi, my name is Matt Stohrer and I repair saxophones for a living.  And I want to tell you everything I know.

I love the saxophone, and I especially love helping other people have the best saxophone experience they possibly can.  I spend my free time writing articles and making videos to help saxophonists understand their instrument.  Articles such as The Unprofitable Valley, Understanding Key Fitting: Hinge Tube and Post Facing, Conn 6M ""transitional"" Saxophones,  The Tool Set For Beginning In Saxophone Repair, and over 40 more.  Videos like the Quik 'n Easy Leak Detector, Repairman's Overview: C-melody Saxophones, Saxophone Repair Topic: Buescher Snap-On Resonators, King Super 20 Saxophones, The Best Saxophone Pads, and over 60 more.

But all of this is just a start.  I want to go so much farther - to put online an entire library of articles and videos that cover every aspect of saxophone repair, vintage saxophones, buying used saxophones, and even eventually to build a saxophone myself and share everything I learn along the way including tools, measurements, and CAD drawings so that anyone with too much time on their hands could build one themselves.

Of course, this information will likely be useful to you individually.  But it also has a chance to really change things on a larger scale.  Because if this information was easily accessible to consumers, the knowledge gap between consumers and those that sell, repair, or manufacture saxophones would shrink.  Consumers would have the ability to make more informed choices, directing the market towards true quality.   Instead of wondering about what you paid for in a repair or neglecting something necessary because you can't understand why it would need done, you'd be able to share a common language with the repairer and make an informed decision that would make both of you happier with the transaction.  Instead of being surprised months after buying a vintage horn finding out that the neck has seen major repairs in the past, you'd know what to look for and how to avoid the pitfalls of buying used, directing your purchase towards trustworthy and accurate listings.   And maybe, just maybe, when buying a new horn one day in the future, instead of choosing between 100 mediocre saxophones that are basically the same except for the color, you might get to choose between many high-quality saxophones that are fundamentally different in design- almost like walking into a music store in 1935.

This is why I have begun to build the Open Source Saxophone Project.  Currently in embryonic form, this will be a useful and informative hub of saxophone information, integrating everything I have already done and adding a lot more, making it a bedrock of free in-depth knowledge for anyone to see that is easy to read, understand, and all in one place.  It will be the first and most obvious stop on the internet for anyone wanting to learn about how saxophones work, closing the knowledge gap between those who make or sell them and those who buy them.  This will permanently change the way this industry works by giving the power back to you, the consumer- arming you with the tools and knowledge to make good decisions with regard to your saxophones, whether as a consumer buying a new one or as a professional repairer fixing up an old one.

So what's stopping me?  The answer is time.  I get paid for fixing horns, not spreading knowledge, and between my job and my family, my limited spare time means that my articles and videos are slow going, typically with one to two per month being made.  If I could temporarily replace my repair income and focus on writing and making videos for a chunk of time, I could get a dozen done in a week - maybe more.

So what I'm asking is for you to give me a paid vacation from my regular job so I can work on the Open Source Saxophone Project and turn it into a useful and informative hub of information integrating everything I have already done and adding a lot more, making it the first and most obvious stop on the internet for anyone wanting to learn about how saxophones work, a bedrock of free in-depth knowledge for anyone to see that permanently changes the way this industry works by giving the power back to you, the consumer.
So How Much Is Needed?

Well, I've got it figured that $1500 raised here will fund me fully for a week - including the fees assessed by Paypal and Indiegogo, as well as the cost of materials and supplies and ""perks"" to be given out to those who donate.  So my goal for this campaign is for two weeks: $3000,  though I will take anything I'm given, and work with whatever we can put together.  However if the amount is larger than the goal, I will take off more time and write and do much, much more.  After all, the desired end result of the Open Source Saxophone Project is to host enough content to enable a talented, motivated and persistent individual to build their own saxophone from scratch!  So there is a lot of room to grow, and a lot of time I can fill if given the opportunity.

What Can You Expect As A Donor? However much ""paid time off"" from my regular job of fixing saxophones that I can accrue through this campaign, I will put towards working full-time (probably a little more than full-time) on writing articles and making videos, which will be visible online on YouTube and on the Open Source Saxophone Project.
Currently, I am able to spend a few hours a month on this stuff.  If the goal of this project was met and I had two weeks off regular work, I could put in about 90 hours

Hi, my name is Ryan Stanton! I am an aspiring voice-over artist looking to break into the industry! I have over a decade of professional performing experience and have traveled the world performing for a wide variety of audiences.

column1: I have focused the last 8 years developing my professional career in sales and marketing, NOW it is time to shift some of that hard earned experience toward my passion to become a voice-over artist!

I am here on indiegogo to share my voice with you and to find support to further my education and training development in the field of voice-over. I know that to grow, you have to improve. Attending workshops, training classes, 1on1 coaching sessions etc, will drastically improve my vocal range and help to be the stepping stone to the NEXT level of success I seek in this industry! Check out some of my recent work on http://soundcloud.com/rstantonvo 

With your support I will be able to improve my craft and bring new found vocal strength and relevance to the table! Industry education will enable me to compete for higher ranked job opportunities which will further develop my skills!

The Education and Training Breakdown

My mission is to raise $2900 CAD in generous contributions from folks like you! Your contributions will be going towards the following education courses in particular order:
• $395 CAD - LEVEL 1 - The Voiceover Adventure (Introduction) - May 2015
• $450 CAD - LEVEL 2 - Performance for Microphone - June 2015
<li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2: >(class schedule for below has not been released - should start July 2015)

column1: • $450 CAD - LEVEL 3 - Becoming the Voice Artist (You are the Character)
• $450 CAD - LEVEL 4 - Making Magic with Your Voice (Tell me a Story)
• $450 CAD - LEVEL 5 - Demo Prep (Graduation)
Above info can also be found at http://www.voicespotwcs.com/
In addition to the above, there are 1on1 voice coaching sessions and demo recordings (a voice artists resume) that are key elements in this mission to level up:
<li>$1700 CAD - Ten voice coaching sessions -<span style=""background-color: initial
• $649 CAD - DEMO RECORDING - (1) :60 Commercial Demo Editing, Music/Sound Effects, Mixing $399.00/demo (copy rate), Copy provided by EBAP $125/demo, Directing provided by EBAP $125/hr (1hr minimum)

There are many other expenses involved both for equipment purchases and studio upgrades I will be required to invest in down the road. Training and Education is #1 - and I am so happy you are on this journey with me! 
 

PERKS - Made just for you!

RSVO... T-SHIRT Perks for you and the family! For a super cool contribution, I have awesome stand alone RSVO Mission Shirts (male, female, youth, and infant available), See Perks for more details!

column5: >* Male, Female, and Youth Versions Available! *

column2: >* Infant One Piece - 6, 12, and 18 Month Sizing Available! *

column1: In addition, I have also provided unique PERKS to help assist with longer voice-over projects you may have now or in the future. Please check out my PERKS section for more details!
column5: >If I do not reach my entire goal - the funds raised will continue to go to the education and courses I highlighted above. I am serious about getting my education under my belt to ensure all my existing and future clients are given the best performance available for their brand!
column9:
>The Impact You Will Have!

By supporting my campaign, you will help the development of my voice-over career, and help bring my voice to life so I can share it with clients all over the world!

column1:
I have recently completed a voice-over for a new kickstarter campaign. The product is called the Illume ArcLighter. Please visit their website at http://www.arclighter.com/#intro - the video voice-over was provided by me!

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

Although there are always risks involved when starting any new opportunity - the challenge is to face it head on and focus on what you are already good at and look for support from others to strengthen the rest! I stride for new levels of excellence and to continue to develop my craft and challenge myself to improve each and every day! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Outside of offering support for my campaign through generous contributions, you can also share my story with others in your network by sharing my campaign page on your social networking platforms such as facebook, twitter, tumblr, pinterest, linkedin and more!

column1:
Please use the Indiegogo share tools for help spreading the word!

Thanks so much for stopping by my campaign page and I look forward to sharing my mission with you!

Ryan Stanton

86 Years of Serving the Community
We believe that when everyone has access to the resources they need, the world will become a much better place. The Cambridge Community Center helps to make that possible.

CCC has been enriching our neighborhood for 86 years. We volunteer our time to the Center because we believe in its mission: promoting cooperation and empowering youth, individuals, and families through year-round community enrichment.
We provide K-8 Out of School Time Programming primarily to underserved populations because regardless of income, race, or inequity, all children deserve high quality programming.

How You Can Help

Every year we spend over $30,000 on food, including meals for children, snacks, and monthly family dinners. With the help of a team of dedicated volunteers, we also provide children with weekly nutrition, gardening and cooking classes. In the last thirty days, we held 13 gardening classes, served 1,716 snacks, and spent $

column2: >Your donations will feed our children for an entire year, help us expand our nutrition programming, and buy seeds, tools, and plants for our 500 sq. ft. of organic growing space. With your help, we can accomplish a sustainable and healthy future for the children and families of our community.

We believe that when everyone has access to the resources they need, the world will become a much better place. The Cambridge Community Center helps to make that possible.

CCC has been enriching our neighborhood for 86 years. We volunteer our time to the Center because we believe in its mission: promoting cooperation and empowering youth, individuals, and families through year-round community enrichment.
We provide K-8 Out of School Time Programming primarily to underserved populations because regardless of income, race, or inequity, all children deserve high quality programming.

How You Can Help Every year we spend over $30,000 on food, including meals for children, snacks, and monthly family dinners. With the help of a team of dedicated volunteers, we also provide children with weekly nutrition, gardening and cooking classes. In the last thirty days, we held 13 gardening classes, served 1,716 snacks, and spent $500 on juice and milk alone.

Your donations will feed our children for an entire year, help us expand our nutrition programming, and buy seeds, tools, and plants for our 500 sq. ft. of organic growing space. With your help, we can accomplish a sustainable and healthy future for the children and families of our community.

column1: <div style=""text-align: justify
<h3 style=""text-align: center
<div>
During
my PhD I have worked and studied for creating a new design approach (H+) which
augments people’s social interaction considering humanity first. To implement
this approach in real life I have decided to work with children with
disabilities, especially those that have autism.
big necessity for interactive wearable products for children with autism which can
help them to have better social and communication skills.

column2: >The motivation to create the “+me” device begins

column1: with a scenario that happens many times as part of a long, sometimes heart-breaking,
story of children with autism having difficulties to communicate with their
family. The main purposes are to enhance the motivation of the child to
communicate, to improve his/her basic interaction skills with others, and to
extend the child’s ability to communicate and play with others while keeping
engaged in every-day activities. It is an interactive transitional object
directed to enhance social interaction and communication between a child with
autism and an adult. The “+me” device is a soft (100% cotton fabric)
interactive collar pillow that provides visual, auditory, and haptic sensorial
feedback. It has embedded pressure sensors, color changing lights, and small speakers.
The features can be remotely controlled to adjust the type of feedbacks
the pillow returns.

column4: >We are considering electronic circuits and components in the smallest sizes possible, embedded into the product, making it comfortable to hold and use. The device will communicate through Bluetooth® with a tablet or smartphone for the feedback control.

column1: <li>
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
• presented in ""Web Blog, StartupItalia"",
<li><span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
• participated in ""AISC, 2014"",

• published in ""Özcan B., Sperati V., Caligiore D., Baldassarre G. Motivating Children with Autism to Communicate and Interact Socially Through the ""+me"" Wearable Device. In: Nea Science - Giornale Italiano di Neuroscienze, Psicologia e Riabilitazione, vol. 5 pp. 59 - 65. Neapolisanit, 2014""
<span style=""letter-spacing: 0px
column2: >We NEED YOU! to have the first working prototypes.

column1: As a small, nonprofit team, our main goal is to
provide children with autism means to improve their communication skills with
their loved ones.
We are, at the moment, in a very early prototyping
phase and we would like to create several prototypes and test them in order to
guarantee that they work as intended. We would like to test the prototypes with
children as soon as possible in order to improve the product according to their
reactions and feedbacks and also from the parents and therapists. This testing
phase will only occur with the approval and supervision of professionals in the
field. To be able to have useful data we are considering to have 10
prototypes so we can make the first tests in 2 phases: The 1<sup>st</sup>
phase with only 2 children to see the major problems with the device, and then using
the remaining 8 prototypes (already updated at this point) to test with 8 more
children.
Basically, to have the first working prototypes, it is
required to have the textiles, tailoring, electronic bio-sensors and
components, software development to control the prototypes through the tablets
(this part will take time but it will be done by the team members), among
other things. All these couldn't be possible without your helping hand.
We will dedicate a single page in the product's web
page for all the supporters and publish their names there (for those that wish
We want to create 10 prototypes for now and we estimate
that each prototype will cost around €300 with all the expenses included.
At this moment we cannot give a deadline with results
since it depends on several factors, mainly on the free time of the
professionals and families involved.
Any help is more than welcome. You can help us further
by sharing our project (you can see the ""G+, twitter, facebook, thunderclap"" links just below the video and we'll be on Thunderclap) with your friends to make people aware of it and support
it! THANK YOU so much!
Thunderclap!: https://www.thunderclap.it/projects/22513-help-autism-to-communicate?locale=en
","Who are we?
Me and Valerio met in March 2014
during my visit to their laboratory (LOCEN - Laboratory of Computational Embodied Neuroscience, coordinated by Gianluca Baldassarre) in The Institute of Cognitive Sciences and
Technologies, National Research Council of Italy. Since I'm an interaction
designer and he is a Psychologist and a programmer, we thought that if we worked
together it could be a good idea in terms of developing the concept that I had
been thinking for a long time. We started to create the earlier prototype in
his laboratory where we had access to various equipment and materials.
Beste Ozcan & Valerio Sperati
Why are we doing this?
During
my PhD I have worked and studied for creating a new design approach (H+) which
augments people’s social interaction considering humanity first. To implement
this approach in real life I have decided to work with children with
disabilities, especially those that have autism.
I have noticed that there is a
big necessity for interactive wearable products for children with autism which can
help them to have better social and communication skills.                    WHAT IS ""+me""?
The motivation to create the “+me” device begins
with a scenario that happens many times as part of a long, sometimes heart-breaking,
story of children with autism having difficulties to communicate with their
family. The main purposes are to enhance the motivation of the child to
communicate, to improve his/her basic interaction skills with others, and to
extend the child’s ability to communicate and play with others while keeping
engaged in every-day activities. It is an interactive transitional object
directed to enhance social interaction and communication between a child with
autism and an adult. The “+me” device is a soft (100% cotton fabric)
interactive collar pillow that provides visual, auditory, and haptic sensorial
feedback. It has embedded pressure sensors, color changing lights, and small speakers.
The features can be remotely controlled to adjust the type of feedbacks
the pillow returns.

We are considering electronic circuits and components in the smallest sizes possible, embedded into the product, making it comfortable to hold and use. The device will communicate through Bluetooth® with a tablet or smartphone for the feedback control. The prototype has been:
presented in ""Maker Faire, 2014"" ,
presented in ""Web Blog, StartupItalia"",
interviewed by ""Superabile Magazine"",
participated in ""AISC, 2014"",

published in ""Özcan B., Sperati V., Caligiore D., Baldassarre G. Motivating Children with Autism to Communicate and Interact Socially Through the ""+me"" Wearable Device. In: Nea Science - Giornale Italiano di Neuroscienze, Psicologia e Riabilitazione, vol. 5 pp. 59 - 65. Neapolisanit, 2014"".
We NEED YOU! to have the first working prototypes.
As a small, nonprofit team, our main goal is to
provide children with autism means to improve their communication skills with
their loved ones.
We are, at the moment, in a very early prototyping
phase and we would like to create several prototypes and test them in order to
guarantee that they work as intended. We would like to test the prototypes with
children as soon as possible in order to improve the product according to their
reactions and feedbacks and also from the parents and therapists. This testing
phase will only occur with the approval and supervision of professionals in the
field. To be able to have useful data we are considering to have 10
prototypes so we can make the first tests in 2 phases: The 1st
phase with only 2 children to see the major problems with the device, and then using
the remaining 8 prototypes (already updated at this point) to test with 8 more
children.
Basically, to have the first working prototypes, it is
required to have the textiles, tailoring, electronic bio-sensors and
components, software development to control the prototypes through the tablets
(this part will take time but it will be done by the team members), among
other things. All these couldn't be possible without your helping hand.
We will dedicate a single page in the product's web
page for all the supporters and publish their names there (for those that wish
so).
We want to create 10 prototypes for now and we estimate
that each prototype will cost around €300 with all the expenses included.
At this moment we cannot give a deadline with results
since it depends on several factors, mainly on the free time of the
professionals and families involved.Other Ways You Can Help
Any help is more than welcome. You can help us further
by sharing our project (you can see the ""G+, twitter, facebook, thunderclap"" links just below the video and we'll be on Thunderclap) with your friends to make people aware of it and support
it! THANK YOU so much!

Mentoring Partnership Of New York

We transform New York City children's lives by providing them the opportunity to have a mentor.  For over 20 years, we have provided free or low cost services to community leaders, teachers and non-profit professionals seeking to start and build safe and successful mentoring programs.

  • We serve over 50,000 NYC children through over 240 Mentoring Programs

Summary

My name is Shawn McClondon, I am the Executive Director of a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization in San Diego that trains disadvantaged youth how to discover their voice and to utilize
advanced social media skills to develop a platform to amplify that voice for career advancement, entrepreneurial endeavors and to create change within

themselves or in the communities in which they live. We are raising money to create The Greatest Trophy Ever Made that will be given to the winners of a competition to create the most engaging socially conscious social media campaign between high schools located in disadvantaged communities in the Greater San Diego area.

Where the money will go

Every dollar raised will go to creating The Greatest Trophy Ever Made or that we can buy, and that best represents the uniqueness of the competition. If we are lucky enough to exceed our target amount, that extra money will go toward creating scholarships.

The Impact

We want The Greatest Trophy Ever Made to be the crowning acknowledgement each year for a new group of disadvantaged youth that have harnessed the power of social media to make the greatest impact in their community. The trophy will become the preeminent prize for social engagement by San Diego high school students, changing hands each year.  We would like it to be a beacon for how technology can be used to positively effect our future.
The Event

We will be planning a fund raising event to acknowledge participants of our competition sometime in the month of June that will culminate with the presentation of the social media campaign trophy. Updates will be found on our website.

Please Share

If you are not interested in donating please tell someone else about our project by sharing this. Please contact us if you are interested in supporting the fundraising event. You can also follow the progress of our project by searching hashtag #TheGreatestTrophyEverMade on Facebook and Twitter.

column1: Math Corps Detroit provides our model

develop and combine with our core values of compassion, hard work, and high

standards.

-------------------------------------------------$75 perk.2 outtakes and final cut of tutors and 7th graders thanking donors.  SPOILER ALERT:  youthful exuberance present in these 15-seconds videos.
OUR STORY

Math Corps Philadelphia will launch its first Summer Math Camp for Philadelphia middle school and high school students (July 6-30, 2015 at Drexel University).Building upon the success of our winter Super Saturday Math Program, we aim to raise the math achievement (typically from the 40th
percentile to the 80th percentile) of twenty  7th graders.
Approximately 2/3 of your contributions will fund stipends for our 10 high
school tutors and 2 college interns.  The other 1/3

of your contribution will provide lunch and supplies for the summer participants.  Our leaders (co-founders David Shen, Chalon Downs, and Nneka Kirkland) are volunteers for the summer program.  We work as college math and science instructors at Temple University and St. Joseph's University.
A PROVEN MODEL & A SANCTUARY
Math Corps Detroit provides our model
and inspiration. For 20+ years they have brought urban Detroit students from
the 30th percentile to the 90th percentile in math achievement. Adopting this
model 3 years ago, Math Corps Cleveland  students have
gone from the 40th percentile to 80th percentile in math achievement.
Each high school student will tutor and mentor two 7th grade students.  Two college
interns will supervise and mentor the high school tutors.  Strong Big Brother/Big Sister relationships
develop and combine with our core values of compassion, hard work, and high
standards.Urban youth have a rough go of it in Philadelphia.  Gun violence, drugs, low expectations, and underfunded,
impersonal schools take their toll.   Math Corps Philadelphia provides a sanctuary from these.  We learn to care for each other.  As a family, we face challenges and achieve goals
together.RESULTS... MORE THAN MATH
Our Super Saturday Math tutor, Tahmid, says,
Albert Einstein said,  'A life lived for others is a life worthwhile.’”
7th grader Joshua describes Math Corps Philadelphia in one
word:  HAPPINESS.
We believe there is a unique greatness in everyone.
We believe the Chinese saying:  “Feed a person a fish, feed them for a
day.  Teach a person to fish, feed them
for a lifetime.”Math Corps Philadelphia is about more than math.
See Ideas-We-Should-Steal-MathCorps
CHANGING LIVES
For 20+ years, Math Corps Detroit has changed lives.  In Philadelphia, our Super Saturday Math
surprises us with dramatic shifts in people.
An “F student” is on the cusp of discovering he is a “B
student.”  A high school tutor discovers his inner self wanting to help others.  A lost college girl discovers a renewed sense of
optimism.  A 59 year old comes alive.
CHALLENGES AND RISKS
We are a start-up, a fledgling standing on its feet.  This first year is a critical year.  We had great success with Super Saturday Math.  We
expect greater success with our Summer Math Camp.  In 5-7 months, IRS will get through its backlog to approve our tax exempt 501
(c ) 3 status.  Then foundation grants
will sustain us. (Co-founder, David Shen, has won
both a writing award and several foundation grants for another 501 (c) 3
organization).  Funding the Summer Math Camp today is crucial for our future success.  Without help from our supporters, the program could be halted.
HOW YOU CAN HELP
DONATE  to our campaign today.  Every dollar counts. (11 donors have  pledged to match the first $1324.)
Not everyone has money
to give. Share our campaign with a friend, co-worker, relative, colleague, or associate. One may become our next big donor.  And  you'll have helped us tremendously.
Other Ways You Can Help
Encourage us via Twitter and Facebook
Like our Facebook Page
Follow us on Twitter
Recommend a high school tutor, who will earn a stipend to tutor and mentor two 7th grade students for 4 weeks in July.
Refer a 7th grade Philadelphia student who needs us (all math levels).  Summer math camp is FREE.
FEEL OUR VIBE. RISE WITH US.
Taste our tweets,
posts, photos, and videos.
Twitter | Blog | Facebook | YouTube",8.0,0,"3 Campaigns

The Kalamazoo Peace Center is a hub for student and community organizing.

The Kalamazoo Peace Center has an office inside the Wesley Foundation of Kalamazoo. Over the past 30 years we've organized around issues of social, economic, and environmental justice. The Wesley Foundation is moving, and we want to move with them!

Why do we need a Peace Center? There is no 'Peace Studies' on Western's campus. There is no 'Labor Studies' on campus. There is no space for peacemakers to come together to make events, campaigns, or programs happen. The Wesley Foundation allows us to plan events in their space consistently, and gives us flexibility to host progressive, worthwhile events and train leaders in the peace movement.

By contributing to this campaign, you're investing in a physical, public space for students and community members to meet, create, laugh, share, commune, and mobilize around peace and justice issues. This office will be the people's office!
All of the money will be used to pay for the office. After we solidify all funds, we will have a Peace Center office rent-free for the rest of eternity.

Our humble perks are a conglomerate of benefits folks receive by being a part of the Peace Center Collective. Although, if you contribute $1000, as experienced organizers we will mobilize on a peace and justice issue of your choosing.
If we do not reach our entire goal, all of the money contributed will still go towards the cost of our office.
column2:
>The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

column1: Our office will be a safer space that is open to the public for all peacemaking purposes. Essentially, our new office will also be the people's office, where all are welcome to come and educate, agitate, organize and mobilize around any issue of peace and justice.

In the last few years, we have seen the collective grow in active members. We have brought speakers like Andrea Gibson, Boots Riley,  Amy Goodman, Vandana Shiva and The Yes Men. We have brought delegations of students to the School of Americas' Watch, sent groups to protest in Lansing and Washington DC. We have organized anti-racist teach ins and direct action learn shares.  We have vigiled and walked to ground the drones.  We have offered more programming to the public about feminism and LGBTQ topics. We have become a more diverse group. We have connected students to movements for justice in Kalamazoo and beyond.  KPC members have transitioned on to work in Neuroscience, the No More Deaths campaign,  Social Work, Greenpeace, Michigan Coalition Against Tar Sands, and Anti-Racist Organizations such as ERACCE.  We believe for social justice to be realized, students need avenues to practice it. Students need safer spaces to organize, dream and build together. We are asking for our support to make this dream of ours, a new office space within the Wesley Foundation of Kalamazoo, a reality.

Although we need to make $50,000 , we have a donor who is going to match our donations dollar for dollar for up to $25,000. We already have $9,300 raised over the past few years. We have a fundraising plan called Peace Partners to get another $10k from local organizations, churches, benefit concerts and private donors. If we can reach our funding goal on this page, we will be able to pay for the office.

Don't have the money to give to our capital campaign? Come to our office and volunteer your time with the myriad of projects and events we plan! Email us at organize@kzoopeacecenter.org for volunteer opportunities. Check out our webpage www.kzoopeacecenter.org to see the types of things we''re working on now.
And of course, please share this campaign with folks who you think may be able to give!

Amount Notice/Edit

Indiegogo will not let me change the amount, but I only need to raise $5 400 not $11 000  as my fundraising partner and I have decided to hold separate indiegogo campaigns. Sorry if there is some confusion!

Short Summary

Hello! My name is Cassie Racicot and I am a 16 year old girl. I am trying to raise money for a mission trip to rural China where I will be helping teach kids how to speak english and I will get to explore all that China has to offer. The trip is 19 days long (21 with travel) and it is in association with Free The Children's Me to We program. This trip costs $5 400 CAD and I need a $750 deposit by May 31st. I will be going on this trip in Summer 2016 and I'm so excited. Besides this Indiegogo, I am raising money in my school and in my community. I am also working on getting a part time job so I can raise money also. Your support will be greatly appreciated and I want to show to the world that a teenager CAN make a difference in this world.
If you would like more info on this trip, please visit:
http://www.metowe.com/volunteer-travel/youth-tr...

The money I am receiving will go to:

  • Flights/Travel
  • Accommodations 
  • 3 Meals daily
• Bottled Water
• Entrance fee to activities
• Language Lessons
• Leadership training
• A trip Facilitator
<li>24/hr Emergency<span style=""background-color: initial

Basically, your money goes towards everything I'll need to get there and what I'll need while I'm there.

The Impact

Your money will go to an amazing cause. I am working to raise money so that I can teach Chinese children how to speak english. When people think of China, they think of a populated place that is far more advanced than Canada. People don't see that there is a whole other side to China where people live in complete poverty and don't have access to education. With my help, I will teach these children valuable lessons and a language that they will be able to use to get out of poverty.

Risks &
column2:
Challenges

This is a lot of money. I understand how hard it is to donate your money with today's costs and temptations, but please consider donating. This mission trip means so much to me and it is an experience of a lifetime. I really want to help these children and to prove to the world that a teenager CAN make a difference in this world. As many of you know, I have pretty bad asthma and since I'm going to China, I'll have to do lots of walking. I'm working very hard on building my stamina and strengthening my lungs. I WILL get in shape so I can do this mission trip because it means the world to me.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, you can:

  • Share this campaign
  • Get your friends and family to contribute

Thank you so much for your support!

I am also working on getting a part time job so I can raise money also. Your support will be greatly appreciated and I want to show to the world that a teenager CAN make a difference in this world.
If you would like more info on this trip, please visit:
http://www.metowe.com/volunteer-travel/youth-tr...
Where The Money Is Going
The money I am receiving will go to:  Flights/Travel Accommodations  3 Meals daily
Bottled Water
Entrance fee to activities
Language Lessons
Leadership training
A trip Facilitator
24/hr Emergency contact

Basically, your money goes towards everything I'll need to get there and what I'll need while I'm there.   The Impact Your money will go to an amazing cause. I am working to raise money so that I can teach Chinese children how to speak english. When people think of China, they think of a populated place that is far more advanced than Canada. People don't see that there is a whole other side to China where people live in complete poverty and don't have access to education. With my help, I will teach these children valuable lessons and a language that they will be able to use to get out of poverty.   Risks & Challenges  This is a lot of money. I understand how hard it is to donate your money with today's costs and temptations, but please consider donating. This mission trip means so much to me and it is an experience of a lifetime. I really want to help these children and to prove to the world that a teenager CAN make a difference in this world. As many of you know, I have pretty bad asthma and since I'm going to China, I'll have to do lots of walking. I'm working very hard on building my stamina and strengthening my lungs. I WILL get in shape so I can do this mission trip because it means the world to me.   Other Ways You Can Help If you aren't able to donate, you can:  Share this campaign Get your friends and family to contribute   Thank you so much for your support!",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Ottawa, Canada",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/cassies-me-to-we-mission-trip-to-china/pica

I am center manager at a local makerspace here by E4D (http://e4d.io). I take care of the overall growth of all other makers here and help them if they face any technical difficulties. I also build my own projects, mostly in electronics out of locally available waste.
column5: >Harish, just like me, loves to make cool electronic hardware. He comes from a neighbouring village, travelling approximately 10 kilometres to reach here, after being in college for 10 hours each day.

column1: Our families are very poor, but thanks to the makerspace, we get all the opportunities to explore and learn. We are trying to establish ourselves as fantastic electronic engineers, even though formal education does not allow us to have that.
Our makerspace (See our Makerspace video here!):

Owing to our interests in hardware, we have been invited for the 11th International Fab Lab Conference, at MIT, Boston (USA) - http://fab11.org and we need your help to get there. The  conference invites incredible makers who have emerged from fablabs and digital fabrication education over the last 12+ years, who have made significant social, economic and community impact in the world and who are inventing the future. From the White House to Google to Barcelona to Togo, these makers are changing the world around us. It’s a golden opportunity to represent India and our makerspace at FAB11. Here's our letter of invitation:
""We want to prove that although we are poor, and live in a village, we can be just as amazing.""
What We Need &
To be able to make it to MIT in August, we need to arrange for travel funding for ourselves. Since, our families cannot afford such a huge amount, we request you to help us out.
Breakdown (3 persons - 2 students, 1 volunteer):
Two way Airfare*3 = $4600

column3: >not able to reach our goal
column4: >, then we will try to send students as many as we can to MIT. If we raise too little for that, then your money will be used to help sustain our makerspace (students are not required to pay for using the space).

column1: If we raise excess, then we will try to increase the number of people visiting MIT from the village, make our workshops extra cool and buy some hardware for our space.

[

Fab Conference Workshop: In the context of the recent Nepal earthquake, we will design Shelter, Communication , Medical and Power generating aids which makerspaces can make and send to help provide relief to Nepal’s disaster struck village community.

Fab Festival Workshop : We are organizing a full day event at MIT, where people would collaboratively build a Forest of Insects from simple coin cell, LEDs, Buzzers, vibration motors, resistors. People can come to the desk, make their own bug and place it in the 'forest'.

The Impact

Visiting MIT is a dream for us. We know that a lot exists in the world of technology that we are unaware of. We want to see what we can aspire to do and become in future. Also, our story will inspire more folks from our village to join the makerspace and choose a brilliant future for themselves. It may give courage to the girls and women to become part of the movement for self-education without biases.

We believe in our makerspace and what it can do to change our lives. Over a period of months, we are now able to read, speak and write good English, use the Internet to learn, create open source projects and engage more people to join us. We have seen kids as young as 10 years old learn to repair RC cars, program arduinos and make circuits on paper. We have also seen older men and women design boats and launch them in the water.
All of this without anyone teaching them or a teacher even being present. Your contributions will help us further our efforts in the technological empowerment of our village.
We encourage women to participate actively in the makerspace:
We have basic carpentry tools, electronics equipments and lots of old hardware!
Every maker has access to a laptop in the space! Thanks to Labdoo and friends.

column3:
/>

We regularly host Build Nights, where we build with solar panels, Chibitronics, Strawbees and lots more fun materials, supported by Instructables.

column1: People across all backgrounds and ages, work in a bias free, self-customised environment of learning.
<div>
Being from a rather backward rural area in India, going out of the country is somewhat a far-fetched dream for us. We have, with great difficulty, convinced our parents to make the trip.
Our passports are getting ready and we are doing our best to get them done quickly.

The biggest challenge for us is that we have little money to spend, which is in no way sufficient for us to make it all the way to the US. But with our friends at E4D, and the larger network of makers around India and the US, and you, we feel that we can solve this puzzle together.
If you are facing difficulties in contributing money through Indiegogo, please feel free to send a mail to abhijit@e4d.io !

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you are not able to contribute monetarily (we, more than anyone else, know what that means). You can still contribute by -
Spreading the word and sharing our campaign (there are some cool sharing tools with indiegogo).
Sending some love and hugs our way :)
*This campaign has been edited by volunteers at the space, but the video, story and texts have been designed by the students themselves.
","Short Summary

I am center manager at a local makerspace here by E4D (http://e4d.io). I take care of the overall growth of all other makers here and help them if they face any technical difficulties. I also build my own projects, mostly in electronics out of locally available waste. Harish, just like me, loves to make cool electronic hardware. He comes from a neighbouring village, travelling approximately 10 kilometres to reach here, after being in college for 10 hours each day.

Our families are very poor, but thanks to the makerspace, we get all the opportunities to explore and learn. We are trying to establish ourselves as fantastic electronic engineers, even though formal education does not allow us to have that.
Our makerspace (See our Makerspace video here!):
FAB 11

Owing to our interests in hardware, we have been invited for the 11th International Fab Lab Conference, at MIT, Boston (USA) - http://fab11.org and we need your help to get there. The  conference invites incredible makers who have emerged from fablabs and digital fabrication education over the last 12+ years, who have made significant social, economic and community impact in the world and who are inventing the future. From the White House to Google to Barcelona to Togo, these makers are changing the world around us. It’s a golden opportunity to represent India and our makerspace at FAB11. Here's our letter of invitation:
We want to prove that although we are poor, and live in a village, we can be just as amazing.""
What We Need & What You Get
To be able to make it to MIT in August, we need to arrange for travel funding for ourselves. Since, our families cannot afford such a huge amount, we request you to help us out.
Breakdown (3 persons - 2 students, 1 volunteer):
Two way Airfare*3 = $4600
Visas = $500
Indiegogo fees = $700
Food and travel = $1200
The organisers  and friends will support other costs. Some friends in Boston are also letting us stay in their homes, thereby saving on hotels.

We have some super sweet and personalised perks that we would be more than happy to deliver from the heart of Banjarapalya, ranging from DiY hand made cards, to skype calls and e-workshops with the makerspace, to free stays in our makerspace.
Kids making cute e-cards:
Also feel free to subscribe to our Newsletters:

If we are not able to reach our goal, then we will try to send students as many as we can to MIT. If we raise too little for that, then your money will be used to help sustain our makerspace (students are not required to pay for using the space).
If we raise excess, then we will try to increase the number of people visiting MIT from the village, make our workshops extra cool and buy some hardware for our space.

[Fab Conference Workshop: In the context of the recent Nepal earthquake, we will design Shelter, Communication , Medical and Power generating aids which makerspaces can make and send to help provide relief to Nepal’s disaster struck village community.

Fab Festival Workshop : We are organizing a full day event at MIT, where people would collaboratively build a Forest of Insects from simple coin cell, LEDs, Buzzers, vibration motors, resistors. People can come to the desk, make their own bug and place it in the 'forest'.]

The Impact Visiting MIT is a dream for us. We know that a lot exists in the world of technology that we are unaware of. We want to see what we can aspire to do and become in future. Also, our story will inspire more folks from our village to join the makerspace and choose a brilliant future for themselves. It may give courage to the girls and women to become part of the movement for self-education without biases.

We believe in our makerspace and what it can do to change our lives. Over a period of months, we are now able to read, speak and write good English, use the Internet to learn, create open source projects and engage more people to join us. We have seen kids as young as 10 years old learn to repair RC cars, program arduinos and make circuits on paper. We have also seen older men and women design boats and launch them in the water. All of this without anyone teaching them or a teacher even being present. Your contributions will help us further our efforts in the technological empowerment of our village.
We encourage women to participate actively in the makerspace:
We have basic carpentry tools, electronics equipments and lots of old hardware!
Every maker has access to a laptop in the space! Thanks to Labdoo and friends.
We regularly host Build Nights, where we build with solar panels, Chibitronics, Strawbees and lots more fun materials, supported by Instructables.
People across all backgrounds and ages, work in a bias free, self-customised environment of learning.
Risks & Challenges
Being from a rather backward rural area in India, going out of the country is somewhat a far-fetched dream for us. We have, with great difficulty, convinced our parents to make the trip.
Our passports are getting ready and we are doing our best to get them done quickly.

The biggest challenge for us is that we have little money to spend, which is in no way sufficient for us to make it all the way to the US. But with our friends at E4D, and the larger network of makers around India and the US, and you, we feel that we can solve this puzzle together.
If you are facing difficulties in contributing money through Indiegogo, please feel free to send a mail to abhijit@e4d.io !
Other Ways You Can Help We understand if you are not able to contribute monetarily (we, more than anyone else, know what that means). You can still contribute by -
Spreading the word and sharing our campaign (there are some cool sharing tools with indiegogo).
Sending some love and hugs our way :)
*This campaign has been edited by volunteers at the space, but the video, story and texts have been designed by the students themselves.",9.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Bangalore, India",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/village-students-selected-for-fab11-at-mit-boston--2/pica

 I’m stepping into the next phase of my
career and purpose and I’ve a challenge before me
$16K in the next TEN days! This will be the beginning amount that I
will need to get well on the road to bring to life some of my nearest
and dearest projects. I’m developing a new program to help first year
teachers from burning out, a couple of art projects/animation films, and
last but not least a project that involves using brain wave monitoring
to confirm the benefits of a practice I teach to expand people’s

capacity to learn and grow.

SO FOR THE NEXT TEN DAYS I’M OFFERING MY SERVICES AND ALL THAT I AM!!
I’m a coach, an artist, and a teacher and would like to offer my
services to anyone who could use them and would like you to help me in

this challenge I’m taking on.

As a coach and OM trainer, I
specialize in helping individuals and couples to find that deeper
connection and fulfillment in their relating.  I help them identify their
desires and challenges in connecting, and how to dissolve those to have
a deeper, more loving, and passionate relationship. Through the use of
the Orgasmic Meditation practice and other tools, the people I coach can
learn how to build and maintain a sustainable and fulfilling
relationship that fosters growth and exploration as a practice.

(Testimonials to follow)

I’m also an artist and have worked in
pen/ink, watercolor, and frescoes. Most of my work is around female

archetypes, such as Medusa, and also fantasy and horror pieces.

Please contact me for either of these services, and we can discuss prices.
For artwork, we can also discuss the nature and subject of the work.
To make donations please feel free to paypal me at:
rmartinez_a@yahoo.com. Any donations are greatly appreciated and will be
for the benefit of helping others have as much access to this work as

I’ve been privileged to receive.

If you know anyone who would
benefit from my services or any courses available through OneTaste

please contact me directly and I will be happy to reach out to them.

Thank you,
R>
