","Your Mission, Should You Choose to Accept It...Be a Champion of Compassion!""It has been discovered that a powerful antidote exists that can counteract the hate, hurt, and negativity that plagues our global community. This highly potent antidote is called “compassion,” and it exists within you.""_____________________________________________________________________________What are the Compassion Games: Survival of the Kindest?Compassion Games: Survival of the Kindest offers fun and creative ways to ignite and catalyze compassionate action in communities around the world. The Games amplify what is already working and inspires new ways to care for ourselves, each other, and the Earth. In the Compassion Games, competition becomes coopetition as we challenge one another to strive together to make our planet a kinder, safer, and better place to live!Compassion Games is a non-profit initiative that organizes an annual, international compassion coopetition that brings together players and teams who challenge each other to inspire compassionate action during the 11 Days of Global Unity (9/11 - 9/21). This year’s special focus was to support military families and first responders in partnership with 9/11 Day, Service for Peace, and the Corporation for National Community Service.  9/11 Day is the largest annual day of community service and engagement in the United States. The goal of this partnership is to keep alive the spirit of unity and compassion that arose in the immediate aftermath of the 9/11 attacks.The Compassion Games also support coopetitions and acts of compassion that take place throughout the year. The next Compassion Games event will be the annual ""Back to School"" coopetition beginning on December 1st (now known as Giving Tuesday) and ending on December 11th (the day of the last Apollo moon landing). The Games infuse the power of playfulness and compassion with the fun of friendly competition, offering a unique way to address the challenges of our time by actively living into a positive vision of our future!To date, players of the Compassion Games have served over 1 million people in 34 countries by more than 200,000 volunteer players. The Games have been played between cities, businesses, faith and interfaith organizations, schools, and even prisons. Participating teams in the Compassion Games perform acts of kindness and service, reporting on the number of volunteers, hours of service, money raised for local causes, and the number of people served, providing measurable results that can be improved upon, year after year.What We Aim to Do With Your Support!Compassion Games International (CGI) is striving to recruit 10,000 players - known as Agents of Compassion - and over 300 global compassion teams to disseminate the antidote to heal and revitalize our world. Together, we want to ignite a culture of kindness through the power of play and compassionate action.Your mission, should you choose to accept it, is to become a Champion of Compassion. By becoming a Champion, you can help attract and support players from around the planet to engage in acts of compassion that will serve millions of people throughout the year by playing the Compassion Games!Play as Well as Donate!

column1: Champions of Compassion are people who accelerate the spread of compassion around the planet. Champions recognize the fundamental importance of compassion - and “Survival of the Kindest” -  in our increasingly globalized communities, and wish to use their personal power to positively influence the development of a more compassionate world!Champions of Compassion Do the Following:
Donate to this crowdfunding campaign to make the Compassion Games possible, and choose from a variety of heartfelt and exciting perks!
Play your heart out in the Compassion Games!
Invite others to become Champion of Compassions, too!

Indie-GoGo makes it easy for you to share this campaign with others! Invite them to be a part of this movement of compassion, and to take part in building the legacy of the Compassion Games! Check out some of the share tools below!

Why Do We Need Funding?For the past 3 years, the Compassion Games has sustained itself on grass-roots ruggedness and small philanthropic donations. From students challenging one another to bring compassion into schools, to people in prisons showing kindness to one another with unprecedented incidences of no violence, the Games have surprised the world at their ability to adapt creatively to any community who wants to embrace and play them.We are positively thrilled with the volume of requests from communities to participate in the Games! With this campaign, we are raising $25,000 to help meet this expanding demand, as well as successfully accomplish the following:The $25,000 raised will help cover the cost of producing, hosting, and promoting new coopetitions during MLK Day, and in December through our ""Back to School"" event. They will go towards improving the player experience overall through an improved website and reporting experience, as well as creating exciting developments like ""Mission Training Modules"" that players can use to train their compassion muscles all year-long. We will build upon this year's efforts to serve military families and first responders, and cover more of the exceptional feats of compassionate actions from players and teams around the world to honor their resilience and dedication.These funds will support this recruitment campaign to enroll 10,000 Agents of Compassion, and providing the technical backbone support to enable thousands of people to sign up and organize teams.Lastly, these funds will help us provide personalized coaching and support for organizers and participating players. They will also help us to ensure that we are providing resources to teams that are in need of financial support. The more funds we raise the more players we can support!How the Compassion Games WorkPlayers can participate in the Compassion Games as an individual by performing acts of kindness, such as visiting someone who is sick, acknowledging the kindness of a stranger, cleaning up litter, or volunteering to support a local cause.Players can also join or organize a Team that may include friends, families, co-workers, classmates, congregants, or our neighbors, and can organize or join service projects to give back to our communities. Service projects can strengthen what is already taking place or lead to new projects, such as distributing clothing to the homeless, planting a community garden (and donating the food!), or helping a neighbor with home repairs.After the acts of compassion and service projects have been completed, teams and individuals report and reflect on their activities and outcomes on a Compassion Report Map to measure impact and inspire others to get involved. Through these Compassion Reports, we are able to measure and benchmark the collective impact that our actions have on our world, allowing us to challenge ourselves to be more compassionate than ever before as we build our capacity to bring compassion to life, year after year!Stories About the Impact of the Compassion GamesThe Compassion Games have inspired innovative and meaningful ways to engage communities. For example, Metro Detroit used the Games to identify many of the places in Detroit that they cherish and love. The goal was to heighten appreciation of their physical environment, their sense of social cohesion, and their experience of safety and peace within their neighborhoods as a regenerative response to racial violence. Mayor Greg Fischer from Louisville organized Give-A-Day during the Mayor’s Week of Service where 50,778 meals were packed by volunteers for Kids Against Hunger, 6 abandoned houses were renovated/new homes were built and 12,418 volunteers helped to clean up Louisville. In North Thurston County, Washington State, 50 schools participated by forming a currency, called “Coins of Compassion”, given to anyone who committed an act of kindness, whether that be a student, teacher, or administrator. In a women’s correctional facility in California, over 10,000 acts of kindness were reported and there was an unprecedented 11 days without violence.

Read the “Love the Hell Out of Metro Detroit” story here.Read the story about Mayor Greg Fischer and Give-a-Day here.Read the Coins of Compassion in Schools story here.Read how the Games were played in a Women’s Correctional Facility here.
How the Compassion Games Were Born
An Antidote to the ""Hunger Games"" of Our Time

In 2008, Seattle hosted a five day, free public event called the Seeds of Compassion with His Holiness the Dalai Lama, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and many other luminaries. Remarkably, it turned out to be the largest event in the history of Washington State. 2008 is also the year author and religious scholar Karen Armstrong won the TED Prize, of which winners are given one wish to change the world. Karen wished for a ""Charter for Compassion"" for our time, a Charter that would globally ratify the Golden Rule across cultures, religions, and secular traditions. In 2009, the Charter for Compassion was unveiled. In 2010, Seattle became the first city in the world to affirm the Charter for Compassion and embarked upon a ten-year campaign to transform itself into a compassionate city. (To date, over 350 communities around the world have also affirmed the Charter for Compassion.)Outside of Seattle, one city and its Mayor were particularly outstanding in taking on this challenge: the city of Louisville, Kentucky and its Mayor, Greg Fischer. The Mayor of Louisville boldly (and playfully) claimed that his city was ""the most compassionate city in the world, and would be so until proven otherwise."" The city of Seattle responded with a resounding ""What?! Game on!"" and the Compassion Games: Survival of the Kindest were born. (Note: Nobody can lose the Compassion Games, and as the more people play, the more people win!)In 2012 there were two teams in the Compassion Games, Seattle and Louisville. In 2013, two teams grew to nineteen, and in 2014, there were 159 teams from around the world who participated in the Compassion Games who collectively served over 1 million people with more than 100,000 volunteers.We are still calculating the tremendous results from the 2015 Compassion Games, but the early stats are in!
Over 190 teams played in this year’s 2015 Compassion Games.
Over 1,000 new individuals ""Agents"" signed up to play.
Over 300 events were posted to the calendar that were part of the Games.
Over 4,000 Secret Agents of Compassion received daily missions each morning of the Games.
The Compassion Games’ Facebook page grew from 2,500 Likes to 15,000+!
How Can Compassion and Play Change the World?

Why Does This All Matter?Compassion is the antidote to the fear, disconnection, and isolation of our time. Scientific research abounds in revealing the intrinsic human necessity for compassion to flourish in our personal, professional, and civic lives. As a profound source of power within each of us, playing with compassion inspires us to connect authentically with one another, rejuvenating our spirits as we actively live into a positive vision of our world, together.

The Charter for Compassion finishes with the following Call-to-Action:“We urgently need to make compassion a clear, luminous and dynamic force in our polarized world. Rooted in a principled determination to transcend selfishness, compassion can break down political, dogmatic, ideological and religious boundaries. Born of our deep interdependence, compassion is essential to human relationships and to a fulfilled humanity. It is the path to enlightenment, and indispensable to the creation of a just economy and a peaceful global community.”Help support the Compassion Games to bring this vision to reality. Game on!

Roots + Wings School of Art and Design is a unique,
locally grown art and design education organization located in Asheville, North
Carolina.  Our mission is to nurture and encourage
the natural creativity within students of all ages through innovative design,
dynamic art education and community collaboration.  We accomplish this through a diverse collection of programs that
serve multiple generations, encouraging and developing
imagination, creativity, innovation, critical thinking and confidence.
Roots + Wings will be opening its new Creative
Campus in Asheville’s Oakley neighborhood this summer. The campus will be
located on a one-acre site at 573 Fairview Road, where we are renovating a
9,000 square foot brick building, adding a new natural playground and new
landscaping to create an urban oasis with outdoor learning opportunities for
all ages. The new facility will allow Roots + Wings to grow and expand –
offering many more programs for ages 3 up through adults – and all on site in
one place. The new facility will also create opportunities for greater community
participation and outreach.  We
believe that working across multiple generations closes impossible gaps.  We have seen life-changing relationships
built through collaboration.
Therefore we see creativity, and the tools of art and design, as an opportunity
to bring about positive change to our communities and ourselves.
To complete our amazing new facility, our greatest
needs are creating a unique outdoor playground and learning environment, building
design lab classroom furniture (studio tables, stools, reading cubes and more),
and purchasing a new kiln and printmaking press.  We are launching this crowd funding campaign to give our
friends and community (near and far) a chance to participate in our Creative
Campus from the ground up.  Your
donations roll right into our mission of giving back by creating more. As a thank you for your donation, we
have some creative ways we would like to give back.  If financial giving isn’t an option at this time - but you
may have other gifts or ideas to offer to our campaign - please take a look at our wish list (at the end of this text) for other ways you
could help.
What is most important to note is that none of this can
happen without you.  Without our community and our relationships, we would
be nothing.  Thank you for
believing in us and supporting us in all we do.  Every day, we strive to spark the creative spirits within
our students and have had a positive impact on our community.  Then we ask
how can we do more?  Our new
Creative Campus is the answer to that question.
Why
Art and Design have the power to change lives.
In many communities and schools, the arts have been
sidelined due to budget cuts or time constraints.  But if it weren’t
for visual art, music or dance and architecture in our lives, many of our views
of the world we live in, and our knowledge of the past and our perceptions of
the future, would be drastically skewed.
What would life be like without the arts?
You may have heard the acronym STEM being mentioned
as the answer to closing the achievement gaps at schools by integrating more
Science, Technology, Engineering and Math  into school curriculums.  But increasingly, the new acronym is becoming STEAM - the
‘A’ in STEAM standing for the ARTS.
Finally people are realizing that art, design, music, dance and architecture are not “extras” or “specials.”
Rather, they are essential to fueling innovation and creativity in the STEM
subjects and integral to how we – as humans – experience and learn about the
world around us:
·
How
we process life
·
How
we engage others and our world
·
How
we solve the intricate problems of life
·
How
we create
·
How
we celebrate
·
How
we live
It is from this perspective that we set out on our
mission each day to help all of our students discover and explore their
creative voices through the multiple media and experiences of art and design.
More
about Roots + Wings programming at the Creative Campus
Along with continuing existing Roots + Wings programs, our Creative Campus
will open the door to new programming and community collaborations:
·  More Visual Arts Preschool classrooms
for ages 3-6
·  On-site After-school Community Design Lab program
(with snow day and teacher workday coverage) for grades K-5
·  Middle
and High School programs (including film and design-build opportunities)
·  Spring and Summer Creativity Camps and Design Studios
(including intersession programs for year-round schooling) for ages 3 through
grade 12
·  On-site INNOVATION HOUR™ field trips for
students from other schools, organizations and home school programs
·  Birthday
celebrations
·  Weekend classes and open studio time for all ages
·  Adult art retreats and workshops
·  Professional development for
teachers
·  Corporate team building programs and retreats
·  Music,
recording and film programs
<div>
<div>
Closing Thoughts
We
hope you will join with us as we expand our mission and programming at our new
Roots + Wings Creative Campus in Asheville. With your help, we will be able to
reach across multiple generations discovering, collaborating, creating and innovating
together.
If you
would like more information or want to discuss ideas for new programming or collaborations, please
contact Ginger Huebner at info@rootsandwingsarts.com
Thank
you!

and High School programs (including film and design-build opportunities)

celebrations

teachers

recording and film programs

We
hope you will join with us as we expand our mission and programming at our new
Roots + Wings Creative Campus in Asheville. With your help, we will be able to
reach across multiple generations discovering, collaborating, creating and innovating
together.

Short Summary

With so much going on in the world, it’s easy to feel overwhelmed. Earthquakes, tsunamis, famine, wars: the need for urgent help in the world seems endless. It’s difficult to see long-term investments as well, anything other than far away and long term. The fact is that children are born every day, despite everything else going on. They need food, love and education. Not for now, but for their future. This project is about investing in education to empower children in Uganda. It’s not about emergency aid, but about ensuring our children and our children’s children can fend for themselves and make the world a better place for themselves. It’s about helping others to help themselves.

Nelson Mandela once said that “Education is the most powerful weapon we can use to change the world”. Today, however, for far too many children, education is an expensive luxury. In south western Uganda, at the junction of the plain and mountain forests, lies Bwindi Park. It covers 32000ha and is known for its exceptional biodiversity, home to hundreds of species of trees, ferns, birds and butterflies, as well as many endangered species, including the mountain gorilla. The region is rich in natural resources, but many of its residents, including many children, live in poverty with limited access to schools.

Over the years, a primary school has been built and has seen over 2000 students through its doors. However, a lot of the students are not able to continue to secondary school because the distances to the nearest school are too great or because the school is too expensive. Some of these children actually walk the 5 miles to the nearest secondary school but tire quickly because they are hungry. Other orphaned children drop out because there simply is no money for them to continue their education.

This project aims at providing facilities for a secondary school close to the primary school so that children can continue secondary education easily and affordably, thereby lowering the drop-out rate and increasing access to education for many more children.

Six standard classrooms are needed at the secondary school, a school library, a science laboratory, a computer laboratory, an office, a staff room, a kitchen where meals for both the students and teachers will be prepared, dormitories to accommodate children from far areas and staff quarters.

Your contribution would help children complete their education and start making a difference in society.

Getting to school on time. Some children walks for three hours to get to school. They are coming for education.
TITLE OF THE PROJECT
Help children in Uganda to complete their schooling.
SCOPE OF THE PROJECT

Bwindi Impenetrable National Park is surrounded by approximately 10 primary schools. Some of the children that pass primary school join secondary schools that are very far from their homes. They are also expensive. This means that children from low income homes fail to attain secondary education. With a secondary school nearby, most of the children will get a chance of attaining education thereby helping in the transformation of the community.

The school will cater to the area surrounding the Bwindi Impenetrable National Park. It will lessen the miles children walk to and from secondary schools and even accommodate children from within and outside the Kanungu district. Children from the war torn region of the Eastern Part of the Democratic Republic of Congo will also be allowed in the school since it will also be nearer to them.
AIM

The aim of the school is to provide the possibilities of secondary education to children who are poor with the aim of making them self-reliant adults. Subjects like simple agriculture and wildlife conservation are important and will be incorporated into the curriculum as will studies in science and technology.
• To develop cultural, moral and spiritual values of life.
• To reduce the number of girls and boys dropping out of school.
• To develop students’ imagination, self-reliance and thinking power.
• To equip students with the knowledge of technology that is needed for development.
• To reduce the income gap existing among families and individuals by creating job makers.
• To teach the children sustainable living and increase yield in the farming community.
Who we are
We are 7 strong men and women on the Board of Directors and will ensure the smooth running of the school project.
We are:
<ul>
• Mr. Matsiko David (Founder and Director of Rugando Parents School),
• Mr. Rene Francis who works with Focused sun, Sweden,
• Ms Tumwehe Vitali an accountant,
• Mr. Ngabe Gervase a retired senior head teacher,
• Mr. Bakorekwa Emmanuel, a senior teacher with the government of Uganda,
• Ms Patience Nkunda, an Aspirant on Kanungu District woman Member of Parliament seat,
• Mr. Turyatunga Benson, a teacher at Rutenga Vocational Institute.
All of us are committed to bringing positive change and believe in the power of education to contribute to the well-being of society.
What We Need &

The goal of this campaign is to create a place where the kids of Bwindi can gather, develop and bring educational value into their lives. You can make a difference by contributing with a simple investment that can bring many benefits to so many kids, for many years.
Right now the parents of the children, and the board with a
clear idea back us up. We have momentum as we have the primary school in place.
Now we need your help!
WHAT IS
NEEDED?
The idea is verified and we have permission to build. The crowd funding
campaign will run through June until August 2015. To be able to build we need to reach our target. The building is scheduled to start October and be ready May 2016.

We will keep you posted on you Face Book.

We will need 30,000$ to get the materials and everything needed
to build and run the secondary School, based upon the proposals from local
civil engineers. Cement, bricks and steel are costly materials, but they will
bring many benefits to future generations. Maintenance costs are minimal with
the materials we are using, and will be done by the children’s parents and some

local builders.

Every
extra dollar we receive will be used on the surroundings to make, benches, buy bins,
prepare a vegetable garden for children’s lunch etc. All money will go to the
construction and running of the school!

<h3 style=""text-align: left
<h3 style=""font-weight: bold
<div>
I will be travelling to Uganda to work with a team
of teachers helping them create sustainable changes thus improving lives of
teachers and students. I have been given a creative yet challenging opportunity
to film 20 British teachers, 200 local teachers and students experience and the
impact that LRTT and Volunteer Uganda has in Bwindi, Uganda. I will be
responsible for filming in schools and teacher training sessions –
conducting interviews with students, teachers and volunteers – exploring and
filming the environment and local community and capturing the action of the
project.
Through filming, LRTT hopes to expand its capacity
in Uganda, Tanzania, Nepal, Cambodia, Guyana and India. Capturing the process
of teachers from the UK and US training teachers that very rarely have
access to continuing professional development enables a clear visual for future
teachers to be recruited as well as an opportunity for the rest of the world to
see the great work LRTT is doing.
""Film makers are vital to the
success of the LRTT project, which last year directly impacted on the education
of thousands of students."" LRTT.ORG
Many teachers in such countries are untrained or
have received very little training. Lack of professional development is a
result of young students of these countries receiving very low quality
teaching. This is part of the reason why there are 190 million children who are
in school but still cannot read and write.
To change this LRTT, Limited Resource Teacher
Training, take a team of 20 teachers and 12 filmmakers from the UK every summer
to these countries that spend a month in schools mentoring/coaching local
teachers as well as running workshops for them. They also observe lessons,
trying different strategies on classes to see which work best before training
the teachers to use them. Not only this but LRTT have ongoing online training
for these teachers after the team have gone so that their training is continued
and students have a far better education as a result.
WHY ME?
Having studied and lived in Uganda till the age of 11, I
understand the struggles and pressure the children in this country are faced
with. I moved to Manchester in 2000 and I didn't understand the teaching methods
as interactive teaching was a whole new concept for me. However, I was
encouraged to expand my ideas and think creatively. There was no right and or
wrong answer but through exploration and independent enquiry I was able to get
a good understand of the concept I was learning about rather than just
remembering the method to get the correct answer.
Academically in the UK, they was and is structure to
learning. Teachers ensured that students understood the topic and unit before
moving onto the next so that pressure of memorising questions and answers and
failing wasn't there.
It would be a privilege to see both practical and
academic forms taught and the impact this has on students’ education by going
to Bwindi and filming the LRTT team. For every child the best gift anyone can
give is education and it's the impact that defines them when older.

column1: EXTRAS!
I will be donating a lot of my own art supplies that I have collected over the years whilst studying art, fashion and graphics design.

However, this is not just a donation, it will be a way for me to interact with the students. The aim is to do a 10 minute tutorial towards the end of the day to stimulate their brains creatively by expressing what they have learned in class through art, whether it's drawing a pictorial spider diagram or making models.

I may not be a qualified teacher and I do not just want to go and help promote the work that LRTT is doing through the medium of film. Their aim is to support and train teachers to think more creatively about their lessons and I have a lot of ideas I would like to share with the team when in Bwindi.
Please help me raise as much as possible so that I can
support and promote the fantastic work that LRTT fellows do.

Sherpa from Monzo village in Pharak, Chaurikharka VDC*, Solukhumbu,
Nepal. Many might know Pharak as the region between the villages of Lukla and Namche in the Mount Everest area. I am also an environmental anthropologist, and a Lecturer at
Pennsylvania State University. I started this campaign because we need your
help to fulfill our relief and rebuilding needs.

column4: '>The first earthquake on April 25th (7.8 magnitude) severely

column1: damaged villages in Pharak. The second earthquake on May 12th (7.3 magnitude)
destroyed what was left after the first one.
mother’s village, Jorsalle, was totally destroyed
temporary shelters in neighboring Monzo, my father's village. [See Gallery for pictures of destroyed houses] In addition to fears of the
tremors, people are also shaken by rumors of Imja glacial lake outburst flooding. The thought of potentially catastrophic floods wiping out villages
continues to frighten villagers away from their homes more than a month after the first
earthquake.

column4: '>My husband and I just returned from Nepal after completing an assessment visit to over 100 houses and 30 villages in Pharak. We found

column1: that people are in need of shelter, medical care and food supplies.

column4: '>I am trying to raise funds to support not just my village but also the

column1: whole VDC, which consists of 38 villages, 834 households and 4600
people.

column5: '>*VDC: Village Development Committee, local level administrative body

column4: '>Our major need is funds. We have the manpower, volunteers who have worked nonstop since the first day
column5: we have the structure for delivery of supplies and

column1: goods
column2: and we have the communication network in place to facilitate the

column1: process. But we do not have sufficient funds to deal with a challenge of this
magnitude.

column4: '>Immediately after the first earthquake our community donated

column1: what they could and arranged for rice, oil, tarpaulins and tents to be
distributed. But, now and going into the future, we need your help!

column4: '>TO HONOR YOUR CONTRIBUTION, I will personally make sure every

column1: penny raised here goes to effectively help families in Pharak, with no funds demarcated for 'overhead.' I will actively
work this summer to support relief and rebuilding efforts for Pharak.

column4: '>WHAT YOU GET from donating to this campaign is the assurance that

column1: your money is going to an informed, prepared group working towards immediate
relief and long-term rebuilding.

column4: '>The greatest challenge at the moment is to work as fast as we

column1: can to meet the needs of families living in cold and crowded temporary
shelters
column2: and families who are unsure of even where the next warm meal will come

column1: from.

column4: '>To meet these challenges we need to raise sufficient funds. Our goal here of $10,000 is not enough, but we want to start with that.
'>Volunteers like me are working hard, but we need your assistance to

column1: help us overcome these daunting challenges.

column4: '>Other Ways You Can Help
'>If you want to help in other ways, please share this campaign

column1: with your friends. Every single “Like,” “Share” and “click” will help keep this
campaign moving. It will also let volunteers like me and many others on the
ground know that you care!

column4: '>Thank you very much.

column1: ","I am Pasang Yangjee
Sherpa from Monzo village in Pharak, Chaurikharka VDC*, Solukhumbu,
Nepal. Many might know Pharak as the region between the villages of Lukla and Namche in the Mount Everest area. I am also an environmental anthropologist, and a Lecturer at
Pennsylvania State University. I started this campaign because we need your
help to fulfill our relief and rebuilding needs.
The first earthquake on April 25th (7.8 magnitude) severely
damaged villages in Pharak. The second earthquake on May 12th (7.3 magnitude)
destroyed what was left after the first one. My
mother’s village, Jorsalle, was totally destroyed
temporary shelters in neighboring Monzo, my father's village. [See Gallery for pictures of destroyed houses] In addition to fears of the
tremors, people are also shaken by rumors of Imja glacial lake outburst flooding. The thought of potentially catastrophic floods wiping out villages
continues to frighten villagers away from their homes more than a month after the first
earthquake.
My husband and I just returned from Nepal after completing an assessment visit to over 100 houses and 30 villages in Pharak. We found
that people are in need of shelter, medical care and food supplies.
I am trying to raise funds to support not just my village but also the
whole VDC, which consists of 38 villages, 834 households and 4600
people.
*VDC: Village Development Committee, local level administrative body
What We Need & What You Get
Our major need is funds. We have the manpower, volunteers who have worked nonstop since the first day
column2: we have the structure for delivery of supplies and

column1: goods
column2: and we have the communication network in place to facilitate the

column1: process. But we do not have sufficient funds to deal with a challenge of this
magnitude.
Immediately after the first earthquake our community donated
what they could and arranged for rice, oil, tarpaulins and tents to be
distributed. But, now and going into the future, we need your help!
TO HONOR YOUR CONTRIBUTION, I will personally make sure every
penny raised here goes to effectively help families in Pharak, with no funds demarcated for 'overhead.' I will actively
work this summer to support relief and rebuilding efforts for Pharak.
WHAT YOU GET from donating to this campaign is the assurance that
your money is going to an informed, prepared group working towards immediate
relief and long-term rebuilding.
Risks & Challenges
The greatest challenge at the moment is to work as fast as we
can to meet the needs of families living in cold and crowded temporary
shelters
column2: and families who are unsure of even where the next warm meal will come

column1: from.
To meet these challenges we need to raise sufficient funds. Our goal here of $10,000 is not enough, but we want to start with that.
Volunteers like me are working hard, but we need your assistance to
help us overcome these daunting challenges.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you want to help in other ways, please share this campaign
with your friends. Every single “Like,” “Share” and “click” will help keep this
campaign moving. It will also let volunteers like me and many others on the
ground know that you care!
Thank you very much.
Pasang Y. Sherpa",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Pacific Northwest, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/nepal-earthquake-relief-help-pharak/pica

Summary

In India, poverty means no education. And no education means a life of exploitation even slavery. That's why we provide homes, food, clothes and education for poor kids. But we need help.

One of our homes in Guntur (India) is far from a good school--a school which offers high standard education thus providing the kids with skills for a better future.  We need a van to get the kids to &
column2: from school. (A friend has temporarily lent his van but this is not a permanent solution. We need our own van.)

column1: As founding president of Orphans First, I've seen how hard life if for impoverished kids in India. But I've also seen the incredible fruit of pouring into their lives to give them a future. These kids become ""our"" kids. We love them and want them to thrive. Some of our alumni have gone on to become nurses, teachers, pastors...thanks to quality care and education.
Will you please help and participate in this fundraising campaign so these children can continue their education? Will you help us buy a mini-bus van for the boys in Grace Home?
What We Need &
column2:
What You GetWe need about $ 9,000 to buy a decent van for the kids. If we do not reach our goal, any funds that come in will be put aside for the van. If we exceed our goal, those funds will be put aside for the upkeep of the van. The van will be driven by the house father.

And what do you get from it? You get the satisfaction of knowing that you helped change the life of a desperately needy child all the way over in India. The Bible says that he who gives to the poor lends to the Lord and in due time it will be given back to him (Proverbs 19:17).

column1:
The Impact

This is an opportunity for you to help change children's destinies -- to help provide them with the tools they need to be educated and to fulfill their dreams of living normal lives free from the hardships of poverty.
Our Record

Orphans First is a member of the Christian Alliance For Orphans (CAFO). We are highly accountable and have seen the lives of thousands of children changed over the years. Find out more on the website: www.orphansfirst.org.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Here are other ways to get involved.

  • Pray. Pray. Pray. Pray for these kids, for God to provide the van they need, etc.
• Share the campaign with your friends. Make a noise. Create a buzz on your social media. Maybe someone in your circle can help.

• You can also use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

    • Thank you for taking time to read this. I hope you can join us to help these kids.

    Janey DeMeo

    founder-president Orphans First

Anatomy, You and Me
I have the opportunity to dissect human cadavers for 5 days. I'm thrilled and nervous.
In return, I'd love to share with you what I know about anatomy! Particular the anatomy of how our bodies are connected (as opposed to just discrete pieces doing their discrete functions
column2: we don't really work like that, as any 2nd grader will intuit)!

column1: Lots to say on this. Have a look below, and to the perks on the side bar, if you want to know more.
Thank you!
More About This Project, and Who I Am

Hi, I'm Liam. I'm kind of an introverted-extrovert, philosopher nerd-jock of sorts. A big part of my life's work right now centers around bodywork, movement and education ... helping people come to more fully know themselves, largely by awakening the body. In my own study, I've learned so much from a huge spectrum of arts, from dance to somatic meditation to yoga to CrossFit to climbing and mountaineering.

What's really important to me in all this ""body"" stuff is our day-to-day human experience, so issues like chronic pain, or depression, or poorly-understood disorders are near and dear to my heart. So is the process of waking up to who we really are: less about what divides and more about what connects. (I could go on and on, but I'll leave it there

I feel pretty strongly that learning about our own bodies is such an important, and such an under-taught, skill. I mean, I learned more about my car in high school than I did my own flesh and blood! (Phew ... again, I could wax for awhile, but will keep rolling here.)
And so, this campaign. You can kind of get to know Montana by reading about it, but there's nothing like breathing in the mountain air.
So, too, in understanding the body.
This 5-day dissection lab will be my first time with this kind of direct work with a freshly deceased human body. (I'm very excited, and for sure a little nervous.)

With the emphasis on untreated cadavers, we really get to the heart of what I think is so important, and largely so lacking, in our current view of anatomy: how our body is so deeply interconnected. Literally. Physically. Bio-energetically and whatever else.
That's where my heart is at
column2: that's what I think is important to share with my fellow humans as we navigate our lives ... And collectively navigate a huge influx into our culture of chronic pain, psychological and emotional afflictions, and a — whatever side of the fence you're on with this, politically — very unstable and not-great-to-rely-on-for-long-term-heath healthcare system.

column1: Welcome aboard.
The Breakdown and Finances
<ul>
• $2500 tuition
• Estimating $100 a night for an Air BnB or something, plus $300 in travel to get to Tempe, AZ and back Missoula, MT.

• [edit: looks like I have a place to stay! Thanks, dear campaign contributors (several of you wrote, actually), so new campaign goal is only $2800. (I can't change the goal up top per Indiegogo's requirements.)

And just a note on why I'm asking for contributions in the first place: big picture: I spend a huge amount of my income every year on continuing education. I love it, and it helps me keep growing into being the best practitioner I can be. This year I'm already quite over budget, though this lab is such an immense opportunity, I really want to make it happen.
Here's to forever learning, growing, and sharing what we've learned!
The Perks
This is half the fun of a campaign like this, honestly.

I have spent a ton of time, energy and resources into becoming the best teacher I can be. And while it's an ongoing journey for sure, it's something I pride myself on: getting to the heart of the subject at hand, and transmitting that in not only an efficient way, but also a way that feels alive and fresh. (In Zen, they sometimes make the distinction between ""live words"" and ""dead words."" The former you feel in your body when you hear them, and are not just regurgitated information
And so ... most of the perks have to do with how I can share this knowledge of living anatomy, of the interconnected body, with you.
The class
Just wanted to spend a few lines here describing the online class.

It will be about an hour long, and will really emphasize the interconnected nature of what's underneath your skin. This as opposed to just talking about what individual muscles pull what bones, and the organs are down there and the gallbladder secretes bile, and here's the name of this and isn't that nice.

That kind of knowledge is, in my opinion, fine to a limited extent, and good to know to pass a test, but isn't even a decent description of the way the body actually works. It can be very mechanical and Cartesian, and that doesn't take us all the way as we are more like ecosystems than cars.
And so ... this class will be on that: how our ecosystems are put together, how they work, and what that means for you as a human being, parent, yogi, dancer, weightlifter ... Whatever applies.
It's a class for beginners, i.e. no prerequisites required.

That said, I think this will be cool for movement, bodywork or health professionals too. How we as professionals educate our patients/clients is so, so huge. And if you've ever been talked at by a healthcare provider, instead of talked to and with, you know what I mean.
Other Ways You Can Help (even if you can't contribute cash)
Share this campaign via email or messenger, or post on facebook.

Of course, a little note attached about what resonates with you about this — like for me it'd be something like this way of understanding of the body feels so important right now — goes a long way in connecting to your friends' hearts.
There's little share tools above the ""perks"" section that make this easy
Thank you!

Short Summary
My name is Britten Leigh Wolfe. I have always believed that home entertaining should seem effortless and laid back, yet, at the same time should somehow appear elegant and sophisticated.

I have deftly combined these two diverse approaches in creating the tabletop collections being offered by my new company Britten Couture Home, collections that are very much of the moment but also timeless. Now, I hope to expand her line with products that embrace form and function while giving back to the community.
What We Need &

After a year and a half of 2 failed manufacturing attempts overseas, she thought she had hit a major stumbling block. However, over a glass of red wine with her best friend, a innovative idea was born. Britten thought she might hit up a buddy who had a 3D printer to help produce some prototypes, but her friend suggested to check out a company that could manufacture products in all sorts of materials at reasonable cost and in the United States. Eureka!

The 3D printing company has a network of designers that could help transform Britten's 2D sketches into 3D files. After a little research and comparison, she found the perfect designer who understood exactly how to execute Britten's vision.

Britten hopes to raise funds to complete Phase 1 of her overall goal. While this phase exceeds the asking amount, Britten understands that most of the time potential supporters like to see tangible results at the onset. By contributing herself to the initial costs of this phase, she hopes you will see her commitment to seeing this project all the way through.
<ul>
• Phase 1: The costs of labor and production of 3D prototypes($3500)
• Phase 2: Mass production ($18000 including shipping and taxes)
• Phase 3: Photography for catalogs and printed materials ($5000).
Pledging comes with PERKS!!! From our signature napkins to a set of 3D printed napkin rings from this project, and much more!
The Impact

It's quite obvious that creating tablescapes are not curing diseases. However, dining is a key time to share with family and friends. It's the time of day, to put away the cell phones, come together and enjoy eachother's company and conversation.

As I have achieved a comprehensive and successful table linen collection, available at stores such as Barneys New York, Bergdorf Goodman and Gracious Home, I believe through opportunity, I can expand my business and make an impact (however big or small) on the lives of others.

I am so grateful and fortunate to have had plentiful arts education in my formative years. Had I not, I would not be where or who I am today. I started my own business as a single Mom, doing what I love! We all know how important the creative arts are for all aspects of childhood development, but the 1st to get budget cuts in school. That is why I have chosen to fight for children in New York City public schools to have access to arts in school.
Risks &

Since this is a new venture and a relatively new technology, there is some trial and error. The prototypes may come back with faults, the wrong size or aesthetically need to be adjusted. These will have to be edited and remade, incurring more costs.
To date, 17 items have been converted to 3D and 38 prototypes/samples have been ordered, totaling est. $1900 usd. Hoping they are perfect, but must have budget for error.

The biggest challenge is bulk manufacturing at a cost that will fit into a retail pricepoint that is on par with the entire Britten Couture Home line. This is what a majority of the funding will cover.
Some of the items are too pricey to print in metal, so those items have been prototypes in plastic and ceramic, with hopes to be able to shop around manufactures to produce in metal.
Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
<ul>
• Please get the word out and make some noise about this campaign. Post, tweet, give a shout out! Anything helps.
• There are some easy to use Indiegogo share tools! Just one click can make a difference.
